column2: The feature of this Bronx neighborhood that makes the most lasting impression is the series of open-air public stairways running up neighborhood hills.
“Bye Bye Birdie” (1963) and “High Time” (1960), both new on DVD from Twilight Time, look at emerging youth. “The Hanging Tree” was Gary Cooper’s last western.
The director Ira Sachs looks to his personal life, and the history of gay relationships on film, to inspire his new feature, “Keep the Lights On.”
Documentarians (and the Writers Guild) have different opinions about who deserves a writing credit in a documentary, or whether the form merits one at all.
The Blu-ray and DVD reissue of “Quadrophenia,” the film based on the Who rock opera, is part of a continued interest in the Mod culture and fashions the film revealed.
A selection of events.

Two pianists have different ways of stepping out: H J Lim audaciously recorded nearly all the Beethoven piano sonatas for her debut release, while David Greilsammer is focusing on a conceptual approach to boldly varied programming.
Created by Peter the Great but closed to the public until last summer, New Holland now draws visitors for everything from art to table tennis to a novel library.
New Haven’s Ninth Square has seen a surge in galleries, boutiques and creative energy.
New York is a place of innumerable home businesses. Chances are there’s one in the next apartment.
This new hotel across from the Santa Monica Pier gets high marks for its environmental efforts. But it needs to work on its customer service to justify the rates.
Its shopping earned it the nickname “Retail City.” Its ramen might be the best in Japan. And its food carts are a breed apart. So why haven’t more tourists discovered it?
The film director talks about discovering “the kind of places that are in front of your nose, but you don’t know much about.”
At the Colonel Harland Sanders Cafe and Museum, a pressure cooker named Bertha, a barrel with 11 herbs and spices and a shrine to the birthplace of a fast-food empire.
“The Way, Way Back,” a coming-of-age comedy by Nat Faxon and Jim Rash, is a project that carries sentimental value for them.
While Boise is home to thousands of people of Basque descent, there are very few Basques left on the state’s sheep ranges.
Once, there were hundreds, if not thousands of Basque sheepmen in the American West. Meet one of the few who remain.
A couple weds about six years after being introduced by his wife, from whom he was separated at the time.
A couple’s loft is on a block that is among the last remnants of an increasingly shrunken Little Italy.
Paul D. Ryan, the presumptive Republican nominee for vice president, favors grunge music and Coen brothers movies. But Is Generation X ready to assume the reins of power?
Ms. McCarthy backs female performers with her organization Gorgeous Ladies of Comedy, which has grown from a blog to an informal society with open-mike nights and support services.
The men who first ran cable signals into TV sets — from poles, not underground — were a hardy breed. Like the writer’s father.
Chan Marshall, who performs as Cat Power, has recorded “Sun,” her first new original album in six years.
Growing up one of four sisters was nothing like the way it was for the March girls.
The line jumper; the phantom tollbooth.
Toni Braxton’s Jewish roots; Hollande vs. Holland Tunnel; Mairo Batali’s Campari update.
Readers respond.
Remaining loyal to a terrible sports team can feel like a self-imposed prison. But it can also be an insight into your soul.
These young, hyperdigital musicians are not dependent on record labels. But they really need their laptops.
The Arizona governor says there are plenty of American citizens willing to work for low wages.
The coaches and players at Southern California went all-out in their efforts to persuade Silas Redd to transfer from Penn State and play running back for the No. 1-ranked Trojans.
An origami studio in Park Slope seeks to teach people of all ages how to master the traditional Japanese craft.
Taro’s Origami Studio in Park Slope, Brooklyn, guides the young and old through the Japanese craft of paper folding.
For those willing to put down millions to own an apartment in Manhattan, a high tolerance for some of the highest monthly charges in the world is almost a prerequisite.
Bonnie John and Gary Pelton needed an apartment in a building that would take three large dogs.
The Harvard Club on West 44th Street is a holdout on what was once a block of clubs.
A windmill, a barn, a stagecoach tavern and a boathouse are among one-of-a-kind homes on the market.
In some new construction in Westchester and Putnam Counties, megamansions are being displaced by more eco-conscious houses.
The Bayshore Regional Sewerage Authority has been ordered to seek zoning clarification for a planned wind turbine that would be close to many homes.
Only the driver gets a parking space; a confrontation threatens a lease; insurance coverage for unofficial sublet.
Investing in student housing may not only help reduce room-and-board expenses, but also provide a revenue source, and in some cases a tax deduction.
Ori Gersht’s “History Repeating,” the Israeli-born artist’s first museum survey show, explores the idea of landscape as a witness to history.
When a restaurant diner whines about his meal; what to do when you want houseguests to pay for their food; and how to put down people who brag.
Some people have wondered if my dog is a wolf, but he is just a quivering, clumsy pet whose response to human troubles is always the same.
On a canoe trip near the Arctic Circle, capsizing in swift current, backpaddling to avoid a bear and seeing what the world looks like more than 100 miles from the nearest road.
Rob McClure, an actor with no Tony Award or major name recognition, nonetheless landed the title role in the musical “Chaplin” on Broadway.
Scenes from the 1977 U.S. Open.
Hanna Rosin on women’s success in college.
Three new middle-grade novels feature girls from very different backgrounds dealing with the challenges of school.
Young girls learn about the limits of their parents in two new books about the strains produced by the Iraq war.
Paperback books of particular interest.
Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
School, relationships, popularity. Navigating life’s uncertainties, the teenage girls in these novels are pushed to the brink.
Variations on Goldilocks, the Three Little Pigs and more.
In their new young adult novels, Joyce Carol Oates and James Preller examine the consequences of fatal events.
In this graphic novel an ambitious theater geek concentrates on friendship and creative fulfillment instead of boy craziness.
A story inspires an app, a short film and now a book.
Rebecca Stead’s hero contends with a bully and an eccentric new friend.
Three very different books illuminate the urge to narrate.
In the Middle East, a sheltered girl befriends a shape-shifter.
New picture books offer creative approaches to counting.
In David Levithan’s novel, a teenage romance is put to the test.
For the high-spirited Olivia and others, the pressure to conform can sometimes seem overwhelming.
New picture books about heading off to school.
Two novels allude to the feelings of alienation among middle-school boys.
Three picture books encourage children to become constructors of their worlds.
In this series opener, history is broken, and it’s up to three young time travelers to fix it.
“The Norton Anthology of English Literature” celebrates its 50th anniversary.
Andrew Motion’s sequel to Robert Louis Stevenson’s 19th-century adventure classic.
Molly Ringwald’s fiction debut centers on a couple in a troubled marriage.
For success, character trumps cognitive skills, Paul Tough says.
With these interactive apps, the great globe fits in small devices.
Bruce Bawer argues that the contemporary American university is a place of hypocrisy and fear.
After being home-schooled and marrying at a young age, Nathan Harden was deeply shocked by the sexual culture at Yale.
For most of these recipes, use 4 to 6 ears of corn, which should work out to between 3 and 4 cups of kernels, depending on the size of the ears.
Jake Gyllenhaal is making his New York stage debut with Roundabout Theater Company’s production of “If There Is I Haven’t Found It Yet.”
A dozen recipes for corn off the cob.
Marcus Lattimore, a junior running back for No. 9 South Carolina, is an example of how hard it is for a star running back to overcome mental struggles after a serious injury.
The author and illustrator, most recently, of “Olivia and the Fairy Princesses” says good children’s books don’t underestimate the reader. “Children will figure things out.”
In this small town, under the gilded dome of the Vermont State House, you’ll find mountains, music, maple syrup and more.
Home to about 8,000 people, Montpelier is one of America’s smallest state capitals.
Readers respond to a recent review of Doug Fine’s “Too High to Fail: Cannabis and the New Green Economic Revolution.”
Readers respond to a recent review of Jim Holt’s “Why Does the World Exist?”
Troops of monkeys running free in Florida.
It’s been a long time since punk carried a sense of danger, and longer still since it carried the beat of political change.
A lone rhesus macaque, running loose in the streets of the Republican convention host city, has become a wildly popular, if elusive, public figure.
The new heroes within the secular movement are coming from unlikely places — like the pulpit.
Chewing gum, coffee grounds and other common items could help you fight ailments while you’re away.
Will Friedrich von Hayek be the Tea Party’s Karl Marx?
Bob Spitz’s biography of Julia Child, “Dearie” — one of a flurry of books timed to the centennial of the beloved chef’s birth — hits the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 6.

The Economic View column last Sunday, about a proposal to make mortgage shopping easier for borrowers, misstated part of the name of the new agency undertaking a revision of some loan disclosure forms. It is the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, not the Consumer Finance Protection Bureau.
International AFGHAN VILLAGERS REVOLT
The evening festivities surrounding the four-day coaching events included drives through some of the estates; above, the crown of the Breakers.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''B.P.,'' Aug. 17: What? Players who earn millions of dollars do not like to practice what they are being paid to do? Using a stick to hit a round, hard object thrown at 90 miles per hour is probably the most difficult task in all of sports. If they don't like the 30 mile-per-hour lobs the manager throws, then get a pitching machine out there and crank up the speed.

The player representatives for every major league team were summoned to a conference call with the union's executive director, Michael Weiner, at 1 p.m. Eastern on Tuesday. The players did not know the subject but had no reason to suspect anything unusual. Weiner wasted no time in telling them the news: the day before, he had begun treatment for a brain tumor. "Stoic," said the Washington Nationals' Drew Storen, describing Weiner's demeanor. "That's what caught me off guard the most, because he didn't play the part of, like, 'Feel bad for me.' He didn't play the victim. His world's upside down, and you know what he said? 'It is what it is. Just because of this, don't be afraid to call me if you need me.'

About the Best Sellers: These lists are an expanded version of those appearing in the August 26, 2012 print edition of the Book Review, reflecting sales for the week ending August 11, 2012. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above it. A dagger (†) indicates that some retailers report receiving bulk orders. For an explanation of our methodology, visit http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers.

Every three years, since it began in 1968, the Preservation Society of Newport County invites the Coaching Club of America with international clubs, this year from England and the Netherlands, for a weekend of coaching through the area, with luncheons, cocktail parties, dinners and a grand ball at the Breakers, the 70-room home of the Cornelius Vanderbilts. It is now one of 10 properties owned by the society. The ball is in honor of the coaching clubs. The festivities begin with an informal cocktail party at the Breakers stable given by Vanderbilt descendants. The event fills the stables, which operate as a museum at other times, with the sounds and smells of coaching, and recaptures the spirit of the Gilded Age. Coaching was championed in America by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, and the museum is dedicated to his successes in the sport. On Saturday, the public was invited to a show of coaches, bottom. (More photos, Page 11.)
FORT GREENE CO-OP $625,000

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Jeter Chips Away at Hits Records as Rose Watches,'' Aug. 19: This article perpetuates the myth that Derek Jeter's offensive skills place him in the pantheon of greats. His career statistics are very good but not extraordinary. What distinguishes Jeter's career is his longevity and consistency, and the fact that he has spent his entire career batting at the top of a lineup made up of many All-Star-caliber hitters.

WILLIAMS--Robert George. Lieutenant Colonel, USAF, 94, of Redington Beach, Florida, died peacefully on August 20, 2012. World War II fighter pilot of 137 combat missions, Robert was the husband of the late Ada Williams. He was born on September 26, 1917 in Lisbon, Ohio. He graduated from St. Petersburg Junior College in 1938. In October 1940, he enlisted in the Royal Canadian Air Force and entered flight training school, receiving his commission as a Sergeant Pilot in October 1941. Robert was assigned to the #

Parents who want to stimulate their children's brain development often focus on things like early reading, flashcards and language tapes. But a growing body of research suggests that playing certain kinds of childhood games may be the best way to increase a child's ability to do well in school. Variations on games like Freeze Tag and Simon Says require relatively high levels of executive function, testing a child's ability to pay attention, remember rules and exhibit self-control -- qualities that also predict academic success. ''Play is one of the most cognitively stimulating things a child can do,'' says Megan McClelland, an early-childhood-development researcher at Oregon State University who has led much of the research.

SEOUL, South Korea -- The bizarre twists of fate and intrigue that have shadowed Kim Young-hwan, once one of South Korea's best-known student activists, read like the plot of a Bond movie. Tortured by his own government in the 1980s for supporting its archenemy, North Korea, Mr. Kim now lives under the protection of the South, which assigned him a full-time government bodyguard.

A picture caption in the Vows column last Sunday, about the marriage of Frida Clements and Tomo Nakayama, described incorrectly the location of the couple's wedding, in West Seattle. It is on Puget Sound, not near the ocean.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Augusta Wouldn't Bend for President,'' Aug. 22: From 1950 to 1952, I was a member of the CBS legal department. One time I was assigned the job of preparing the Masters television rights contract with Augusta National Golf Club. I had been warned that Clifford Roberts, the club chairman, was a difficult person, but that was an understatement. He treated me like a servant and told me exactly what was to be in the contract.

By finishing 12-1 last season, Boise State became the first team since 1900 to win 12 or more games in four consecutive seasons. The Broncos moved past Southern California and Oklahoma, each of which had three straight 12- win seasons -- the Trojans from 2003 to 2005 and the Sooners from 2002 to 2004. Boise State has also averaged a Football Bowl Subdivisionbest 41.9 points per game since the start of the 2000 season. Boise has more 50-point games over that span, 43, than it does games with fewer than 30 points, 29.

KENT--William, Sculptor and printmaker, 93, he died August 16. Self-taught, his monumental wood sculptures and slate monoprints were critically acclaimed in the 1960's. Never in any "school", he was an original to the end. An October memorial will be announced at williamkentfoundation.com.

ZUCKERMAN--James R.,88, on August 23 after a battle with pancreatic cancer. Husband of the late Louise Zuckerman, father of Judith Z. Schwartz, Faye Zuckerman and Laurence Zuckerman, and devoted grandfather of David, Jonathan, Kayla, Seth, Melanie, Zachary, Ellie and Jessica. He served in two wars, visited 50 countries and loved his work as an attorney. Service at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, Monday, August 27, at 1pm.

WHETHER it was Robert Mitchum in the film ''Thunder Road'' or Burt Reynolds in ''White Lightning,'' cars have played critical roles in films about moonshining. Joining that tradition is ''Lawless,'' with Shia LaBeouf, Gary Oldman, Guy Pearce and Tom Hardy, a movie set mostly in 1931 Virginia. Keeping the period cars in running order on the set was the job of Gary Duncan, the film's chief car specialist. Most of the vehicles were Ford trucks and cars, he said in an interview.

Because of an editing error, the Big Deal column last week, about lower prices and values at the top end of the Hamptons real estate market, described incorrectly the recent sale by the designer Tory Burch of a house she had bought for $22.5 million in 2009. Ms. Burch sold the house for $11 million; she did not make $11 million on the sale. The column also misstated the involvement of Harald Grant, a broker at Sotheby's International Realty, in the $28.5 million sale of a house on Meadow Lane in Southampton . Mr. Grant was the agent for the buyer -- not the seller, who was represented by Marcella O'Callaghan of the Corcoran Group.

THE Los Angeles sisters Alana, Este and Danielle Haim, of the girl group Haim, started their careers in a band with their parents. ''We did covers of K-Earth 101 songs, bands like the Eagles, Billy Joel and Santana,'' said Danielle, 23. It wasn't until years later -- Aug. 7, 2007, to be exact -- that Danielle and Alana, now 20, and Este, now 26, played their first show without their parents. After taking a break to finish high school (Alana, left), finish college (Este, right) and tour with Jenny Lewis and Julian Casablancas (Danielle, center), the girls of Haim are now releasing demos, and their summer anthem ''Forever'' landed them on tour with Mumford & Sons. Before summer ends, here are Haim's Top 10 songs for the season: 1. ''Hey Lover,'' by Blake Mills.

OHIO The last time the Bobcats won more games than any other Football Bowl Subdivision program in the state was 1962. That streak should end in 2012. Beyond the talent, experience and coaching, the Bobcats have a schedule that could not be more favorable. Ohio is simply a better team than every opponent on its schedule - and that includes Penn State, which hosts the Bobcats in the season opener. LOUISIANA TECH Come December, Louisiana Tech will be the answer to a trivia question: which team won the final Western Athletic Conference championship? But Louisiana Tech may be able to do more than that. If the Bulldogs can win nonconference games against Texas A&M, Houston, Illinois and Virginia, you can book this team for a berth in a Bowl Championship Series bowl.

James Franklin is not the first coach to win games at Vanderbilt. It only seemed that way when he led the Commodores to six victories and a bowl berth last fall. But Franklin could stand alone if he wins six or more games this season: Vanderbilt has never reached bowl games in consecutive years.

ROSENBLUTH--Myra Jean (Popper), died peacefully August 16 at the Lutheran Home of Southbury, CT. Beloved wife of Emanuel (deceased), mother of Eva Jean Henneberg (Stephen). Dearly loved by sisters Doris Weinstock (deceased) and Rhoda Ashley of Southbury, CT. Graduate of Hunter College. Accomplished pianist, scrabble player, par excellence and lover of dark chocolate. Will be lovingly missed by nieces Leslie (Gregory), Pamela (Rose), Jessica (Sammy), Wendy (Paul), Karen Pass, a nephew Randall, and friend Michael. Her dry sense of humor and witty birthday poems tickled us. A memorial remembrance to be held at a future date.

NEIMAN--Karen F.,passed away August 22 at home in Longmeadow, MA. She was born on October 24, 1960 in Rockaway, NJ to Richard and the late Rhoda Neiman. Survived by husband Jay, sons Glenn and Shayne, two brothers, Andrew (Hellaine) and Roger (Bonnie), brother-in-law Eric (Linda), father-in-law (Leonard Michelman), sister-in-law (Margot) and nephews and nieces Lane, Jamie, Eric, Rachel, Ryan, Adam, Jack and Jenny. Karen was a graduate of Boston University with a Masters from George Washington University. She was a Director of The Longmeadow Adult Center for the last 24 years as well as a member of the Massachusetts Council on Aging and a board member of the Western Massachusetts Association of Councils on Aging. Funeral Services August 26, Burial services private. Contributions in her honor may be made to Friends of Longmeadow Older Citizens Association, Inc. (FOLOCA), 231 Maple Street, Longmeadow, MA 01106.

''I GREW up in a family that was very experimental with fashion,'' says the 26-year-old New York designer Tanya Taylor. ''My dad would travel all over the world and bring back fabrics. He would wear skirts sometimes. My mom put me in very weird '80s outfits that involved matching pants and tops and scrunchies.'' By comparison, Ms. Taylor's professional fashion path has been somewhat straight and narrow: she studied finance at McGill University, took an introductory design course at Central Saint Martins in London and later attended Parsons, where things started to take off. ''I saw a posting for an internship at Elizabeth and James,'' she says. ''It didn't include anything but a fax number. I thought: Who faxes these days? It was so me.'' (Ms. Taylor went on to work there as a special collections women's designer for two years.)

WEIR--David Manson II, died peacefully on Sunday, August 19, in East Hampton of complications from prostate cancer. Born in 1944, David was the son of Ernest Tener Weir, founder of National Steel, and Mary Hayward Weir. David was a racing car driver, who came in fourth in the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1971, and maintained his passion for automobiles throughout his life. He later worked as an alcoholism and substance abuse counselor. East Hampton residents will remember his little yellow Morris Minor convertible, often seen around the village. David is survived by his wife Gretchen and his two children, Maisie and Gregory. A raconteur, a wit, a clothes horse, a loyal friend, a generous husband and father, and a true gentleman, David will be sadly missed by his family and many friends. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to East End Hospice or to Visiting Nurse Service of New York. Memorial service to be held in New York City at a future date.

AN iconic penthouse with sophisticated steamed-beech-dominated interiors by Charles Gwathmey and sweeping views of Central Park from its perch at the Verona, a landmark Upper East Side co-op designed by William E. Mowbray in 1908, sold under the radar for $21 million, the biggest sale of the week according to city records. The seller, Jonathan S. Sobel, had not intended to leave the apartment, which he bought in 2002 expressly for the masterly Gwathmey Siegel renovation done for the previous owners, Charles and Brenda Koppelman. But after receiving a letter from Roger Erickson, a Sotheby's International Realty broker with clients at the Verona who wanted a larger apartment there, he and his wife, Marcia Dunn, decided to sell. They set the price at $21 million. After Mr. Erickson's intended clients elected not to buy, he contacted another longtime client, Stephen J. Meringoff, the commercial real estate investor , who bought the apartment.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the Pebble Beach Motoring Classic, a 1,500-mile tour for vintage cars through three Western states, misidentified one of the vehicles. It was a 1931 Pierce-Arrow Model 42 Sport phaeton, not a 1930 Hispano-Suiza H6C Cabriolet.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Armstrong Ends Fight Against Doping Charges,'' Aug. 24: Lance Armstrong's choice to discontinue his defense against the United States Anti-Doping Agency's attacks is not one of concession. It is an act of defiance in the face of an agency solely following the rules it makes up as it goes along.

In Texas A&M's first season in the Southeastern Conference, it will play the four teams that have combined to win the last six national titles: Florida on Sept. 8, Louisiana State on Oct. 20, Auburn on Oct. 27 and Alabama on Nov. 10. Washington has the toughest first-half schedule. The Huskies play host to Portland State on Sept. 15 one week after a game at L.S.U. , then home against Stanford, at Oregon and against Southern California.

CHAZIN--Edward, peacefully on August 23rd after spending his final days with friends, family and loved ones by his side. A service will be held to honor his memory on Wednesday, August 29th, 3pm at The Riverside 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

LIEGNER--Leonard. Died peacefully August 16 at age 93. Received degree from New York University School of Medicine. Captain in the U.S.A.A.F. in World War II. Director of Radiation Oncology at St. Lukes Hospital , NY. until his retirement. Member of the Hospice Movement in England. Founder and board member of the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies, NY. Survived by Evelyn, his beloved wife of 71 years. Loving father of Laurel and Steve, Kenneth and Irene. Cherished grandfather of Alison and Peter, Joshua and Jacqueline, Jordon and Amy, and Adam. Loved great grandfather of Ryan, Ella, Isabela, Vivienne and Avery. A rugged character, a mind of a scientist, heart of a poet. A selfless man of strength and dignity. In addition to publishing scientific papers, he was proud of his paper on Humanizing the Physician based on his many years of treating cancer patients. Respected and admired by all who knew him. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Center of Modern Psychoanalytic Studies.

IN the 1950s, Katharine Hepburn wouldn't board a plane without her Smythson address book. In its pages, she logged meetings with friends like Laurence Olivier, Frank Sinatra and Vivien Leigh. On its cover were stamped her initials and three places she frequented (London, California and New York) initiating a way to personalize paper goods. That book is in Smythson's in-store museum at 4 West 57th Street. Now, in honor of her idea, Smythson has four-zipper currency cases embossed with Fashion Week's four biggest cities: New York, London, Milan and Paris. Available with the option of monogramming, too, these are an update on the company's original 1966 currency case and come in violet, olive and classic brown crocodile; $357, smythson.com . CHELSEA ZALOPANY

CAHILL--John J.,"Jack" of Boca Raton, FL formerly of Pound Ridge, NY and Bridgewater, NH. Died August 23 at Spring House, PA of heart failure, with his daughter by his side. Born 1924 in Brooklyn, NY. Graduate of Brooklyn Prep and Fordham University. Served in the U.S. Army 1945-1947. Married for 58 years to Mary Ellen Mossien, who passed away in 2008. Beloved father of Marianne (Douglas) Platt, loving grandfather of Allison and Jennifer. Services entrusted to Babione Funeral Home, Boca Raton FL.

WOLL--Marian M.,died at the age of 89. Daughter of Antonio and Dora (nee Capuzzi) Miliambro. She was born on April 20, 1923 in Chappaqua, where "Millie" starred on the high school basketball team. She had four siblings: Kathryn, Joseph, Louis and Rocco. Marian married John Clellon Holmes, the noted chronicler of the "Beat Generation," in 1944. She met her second husband, Yael Woll, an award-winning film director, while working as Executive Assistant for Hans Richter at the Institute of Film Techniques at the City College of New York. They married in 1955 and raised their three children in Bedford Village. She is survived by her brother, Rocco, and his wife, Nancy; her daughter, Deborah Woll, and her husband, Gary Brown; her daughter, Susan Woll; her son, David Woll, and his wife, Kristen, many loving nieces and nephews and three adoring grandsons, Joseph, David and Charlie. A gifted artist and opera lover, an avid gardener and culinary wizard, a voracious reader and animal lover. Mom she was an extraordinary woman; a real spitfire. Donations in Marian's memory can be made to the Ossining Volunteer Ambulance Corps.

TO fill the newly created position of adviser for competitive assessment and quality, Nissan North America has hired David Champion, formerly the senior director of Consumer Reports' auto test center and one of the nation's most prominent consumer affairs voices on automotive issues. The appointment takes effect on Sept. 10, Nissan noted in a media release on Wednesday. Mr. Champion, who worked at the consumer magazine's testing headquarters in East Haddam, Conn., will be based at Nissan's proving grounds in Stanfield, Ariz. Among other purposes, the site is being used to refine the NV200 van, which is scheduled to be phased into the New York taxi fleet starting late next year.

NORR--David. David Norr, of Scarsdale, NY, passed away August 19 at age 89. He intertwined careers as a financial analyst, investment adviser and certified public accountant. He was the only analyst to have served on the Accounting Principles Board. He was active on several SEC committees on reporting problems and appeared before a Senate subcommittee on stock options. He devoted much effort to improving disclosure for investors and was a frequent speaker and the author of several articles and pamphlets on financial matters. He fought for expensing unsuccessful wells in the oil industry, for expensing the cost of stock options and was early to advocate stock buybacks. An activist, he ridiculed meager stock holdings of outside directors prior to their being given generous stock options. While president of the New York Society of Security Analysts, he wrote a newsletter for the benefit of members. He graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Columbia, from which he also held an M.B.A. He served in the Army in WWII. He established eight scholarships in honor of family members at their respective universities. His father, Henry I. Norr, an immigrant boy from Russia, graduated Phi Beta Kappa from City College and was principal of Evander Childs High School in the Bronx. He is survived by his wife, Carol Norr, daughter Amy Norr, her husband Jeff Metz and grandchildren, Rachael, Jordin and Melanie Metz of Narberth, PA, and daughter Susan Norr and granddaughters Nicole and Julia Norr of Scarsdale, NY. Memorial donations may be made to Americans United for the Separation of Church and State, or the New York Public Library.

The cover article on Aug. 12 about the Baikal-Amur Mainline railroad (BAM) that traverses Siberian wilderness north of the Trans-Siberian Railway misstated the price for the hydrofoil service across Lake Baikal between Irkutsk and Severobaikalsk from June to August. It is 4,200 rubles, not 42,000.

McCLURE--Douglas Ketcham of Rye, NY, beloved husband of Ruth Lind McClure, died peacefully at home on August 19th. Known for his warmth and keen sense of humor, he loved all that surrounded him. In addition to his wife of 34 years, he is surived by his mother, Elizabeth Ketcham McClure, his sisters Marilyn Plumb Beck and Dawn McClure Morton, seven nephews and eight nieces. He was predeceased by his father, Carl H. McClure III and by his sister, Marcy McClure Parker. A memorial service is planned on Thursday, September 6th, 4pm at Rye Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Doug's memory to the Lung Cancer Research Foundation, 845 Third Avenue, 6th floor, New York, NY, 10022.

WEINBERGER--Ruth Zuckerman, MD, on August 3 at the age of 97, in Teaneck, NJ, where she had lived since 1949 and practiced dermatology until retiring in 1980. She grew up in Brooklyn and graduated from the NYU School of Medicine in 1940. She was active in civic affairs in Teaneck and an avid painter. Her art was featured in a number of solo and group exhibits. Predeceased by her husband, Harold; survived by sons Peter (Mary Beth) of Syosset, NY; Marc (Kate) of Petaluma, CA; and daughters Deborah (Charlie Hoyt) of Washington, DC, and Rachel (Ed McGann) of Summit, NJ; grandchildren Andrew and Grace McGann; three nieces. Memorial service Sunday, September 2, at 2pm at the Marriott Teaneck at Glenpointe, Teaneck, NJ.

The photo caption with an opinion essay last Sunday, about padlocks that have been left on Parisian bridges as a symbol of love, misidentified one of the bridges, in front of Notre Dame. It is the Pont de l'Archevêché -- not the Pont des Arts, where many padlocks have also been attached to the railings.

President Obama and Mitt Romney have 72 days of campaigning from Sunday until the election. The closing chapter of the race will be highlighted by a handful of marquee events that could change the dynamic of the contest. The political conventions will give way to a burst of campaigning in September, followed by the closely watched debates in October. While the election is not until Nov. 6, tens of millions of voters will not wait. Early voting begins in less than a month in Iowa, and four years ago, 88 percent of the electorate in the battleground state of Colorado cast their ballots before Election Day.

BLUM--Bernard G. To our devoted husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, you are always in our hearts and thoughts. We miss you - Your loving family

Eighty years ago, in a small shop in Marseille, Patrick Ricard's father concocted an anise-flavored aperitif that became a French favorite and the foundation of one the world's major distributors of wine and spirits. The drink, devised in 1932, was a nondistilled mixture of licorice, anise and star anise that its creator, Paul Picard, bottled under his own name as Ricard pastis. It became a daily tipple for millions of French, particularly working-class people in the south.
HAMMOND--Harry S.,Jr., 94, of Barboursville, VA, formerly of Garden City, Long Island, NY died on August 19, 2012.

WALKER--Christopher Angus Lightfoot. Born July 20, 1954. Son of the late Angus Lightfoot Walker and Amber Lightfoot Walker, died unexpectedly at his home in Manhattan on Sunday, August 19. In adversity Christopher was one of the bravest. He was also eternally optimistic and with a great sense of the humorous side of life. He leaves a space that can not be filled.

An article last Sunday on the state budget stated incorrectly that state lawmakers in 2011 deferred spending on Medicaid instead of making cuts to that program. While they did defer spending, it was in addition to cuts to the program and in provider rates.
WHY WE TRAVEL Share the best photos from your recent travels. Some will appear in our print edition, and in an online slide show. Above, a reader shared a picture taken in Myanmar .

SUSSMAN--Ruth Levine. Today, and every day, we miss you and love you. Jane, Becky, and David

An article on Aug. 12 about Wang Shu, the first Chinese architect to win the Pritzker Prize, misstated the time frame when China's vice prime minister, Li Keqiang, is likely to become his country's next prime minister. Mr. Li, who embraced Mr. Wang at the Pritzker award ceremony in May, is expected to assume the post in China's coming leadership changes, which will probably happen next spring, not this fall.

DUFFY--Joan Marie, nee Scully, 82, of South Setauket, NY, on August 23, 2012. She was the wife of Francis, her husband of 60 years; the mother of Mary Frances, Michael, Eileen (Nilson Traslavina), Thomas (Moira Bailey) and John (Trisha); the grandmother of Ryan, Timothy (Megan), Benjamin, Brian, Samantha, Liam, Margot (Maggie) and John Francis (Jack). She is pre-deceased by a daughter-in-law, Jane Duffy, nee Wardlow. Friends may call on Saturday, 7-9pm, and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9pm at Bryant Funeral Home, 411 Old Town Rd., East Setauket, LI. A funeral mass will take place Monday at the St. Gerard Majella in Port Jefferson Station, LI, with interment at St. John Cemetery in Middle Village, Queens. Before she and Francis moved to the Jefferson's Ferry retirement community in 2001, Joan was a 46-year-resident of Valley Stream, NY. Born October 16, 1929, in Astoria, Queens, she was the only child of William Scully and Julia Scully, nee Lynch. She attended William Cullen Bryant High School in Long Island City, where she and Francis first met. She entered the College of New Rochelle, in the Class of 1951. A visit to the Keene Valley, NY, home of her college roommate led to a lifelong love of the Adirondacks. She graduated cum laude from New Rochelle and subsequently earned a master's degree from Fordham University. Joan was an English teacher and dean during a 25-year career in New York City schools including: the Wayside Home for Girls, the Elmhurst Hospital Center, Far Rockaway High School, Abraham Lincoln High School and Francis Lewis High School. She also was an adjunct professor at St. John's University. A former member of the Valley Stream Historical Society, she also was editor of the society's newsletter. A generous and irrepressible woman, Joan loved travel, literature, art, opera and the company of her family whom she gathered for a July reunion to celebrate her 60th wedding anniversary. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to St. Gerard Majella Church, 200 Terryville Rd., Port Jefferson Station, New York, 11776. www.bryantfh.com

WHETHER or not it's in fashion, the baseball cap has been a mainstay of American outfitting since its arrival in the 1940s. But lately, it seems to be spending less time on the diamond and more time on the street, the beach and the New York social scene (a reaction to the baseball uniform's influence on the spring 2013 men's collections, maybe). Note taken: Baseball caps are all that. And they look especially fresh on women wearing relaxed dresses, skirts and sweatshirts. At the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic, the model Dree Hemingway tomboy-ed an all-white lace look with a Yankees hat. The singer Rihanna topped slouchy jeans with a brightly colored two-toned ball cap. And on vacation in Florida, the singer Gwen Stefani paired her printed skirt and bikini with a hat that could easily belong to her hubby, Gavin Rossdale. Inspired by the way these three women wore their caps, T picked a few that come from everywhere (the boyfriend's closet, Barneys) and look as ready for fashion's major league as any accessory out there. From top, Kenzo cap, $60, barneys.com ; Fair Ends Ghana Camp cap, $48, fairends.com ; Ebbets Field Flannels cap, $45, jcrew.com . CLAIRE KNEBL

Cruises that cater to foodies, like Food Network at Sea , are nothing new. Nor are those that feature reality television stars, like Cruising With the Stars . A mash-up of the two genres, Top Chef: The Cruise , will feature hosts of the reality competition show, Tom Colicchio and Gail Simmons, and former ''cheftestants'' along with 2,000 passengers. Tickets for the five-day cruise on Celebrity Constellation (above), departing from Miami in April 2013 and making stops in Key West , Fla., and Cozumel , Mexico , went on sale Aug. 16. Ellen Stone, Bravo's senior vice president of marketing, said the ''Top Chef''-sponsored cruise was inspired by the show's mobile tours, in which contestants travel across the United States after a season ends. ''Fans would come out in droves,'' Ms. Stone said, ''and with the cruise, they'll now have five days to get personal access to the stars.''

BARTOW--Mary Neuman, of Peapack, NJ, died at home on August 17, 2012. She was 97. A Memorial Service will be held on September 7th at 11am at St. John on the Mountain, Bernardsville, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to The Willowwood Foundation, PO Box 218, Gladstone, NJ 07934.

An article last Sunday about Svetlana Legetic, a Washington party organizer who plans to do business in New York, misspelled the surname of the editor of DC magazine, which has chronicled Ms. Legetic's career. She is Karen Sommer Shalett, not Shalet.

Forbes's list of the 15 top-earning book writers of 2011 conjures Hunter S. Thompson, who once wrote, ''When the going gets weird, the weird turn pro.'' That's because there's lots of very professional weird here: 9 of the 15 authors write fantasy, horror or science fiction. There are old favorites like Stephen King (No. 2 at $39 million) and J. K. Rowling (No. 11, $17 million) and newer flavors too, like the ''Hunger Games'' writer Suzanne Collins (No. 9, $20 million) and George R. R. Martin (No. 12, $15 million), whose ''Game of Thrones'' (left) has become an HBO mainstay. James Patterson topped the list at $94 million. And, yes, he too dabbles in the weird.
GOLTEN--Robert Joseph, 79, of Boulder, CO, died August 15, 2012. A Celebration of Bob's Life will be held September 8th, 2012 in Boulder, CO. For details, see www.caringbridge.org/visit/ bobgolten.

FROST--Carolyn Aldrich, passed away August 15 in Colorado Springs, Colorado. She was born on September 20, 1930 in Baltimore, Maryland to Dr. Robert Henry Aldrich of Baton Rouge, Louisiana and writer Rhoda Truax Aldrich of New York, New York. She was raised in Cambridge, Massachusetts where she attended and graduated from the Cambridge School of Weston. Lynn moved to Colorado in 1948 to attend Colorado College, where her aunt, Carol Truax, was the Executive Director of the Fine Arts Department. She graduated from Colorado College in 1952. In 1953 she married Hunter Swift Frost of Pleasantville, New York, and they lived in New York City until 1966. Lynn worked as a social worker at Woman's Hospital. In 1966 the family returned to Colorado where Lynn became Director of Social Work at the Emory John Brady Hospital and Hunter taught at Fountain Valley School. While living at Fountain Valley School, Lynn designed and made costumes for many of the school's theatrical productions. In 1982, Lynn and Hunter moved to Connecticut. Lynn became an active member of the Democratic Women of Westport and enjoyed time in New York visiting family and attending shows, opening, and parties. Lynn and Hunter traveled in the US and abroad and in 1989 they embarked on a three month trip around the world. She saw the world through a sharp eye for social justice and equality, and she approached life with a keen wit and a love for things fair and just. In 1992 Lynn and Hunter returned to Colorado Springs where they were active in the arts community. Hunter passed away in December, 2009, three months after celebrating their 56th wedding anniversary. Lynn will be remembered as a gracious and generous hostess, and as a devoted wife, mother, and grandmother. Lynn is survived by her three children: Daniel, his wife Kathy and their daughters Sarah and Elizabeth; William; and Juliana and her son Kaleb Beavers. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in Lynn's memory to: The Class of 1952 Endowment, Colorado College Development Office, 14 E. Cache La Poudre, Colorado Springs, CO 80903 or The Hunter and Lynn Frost Fund, Fountain Valley School, 6155 Fountain Valley School Road, Colorado Springs, CO 80911-2299.

VINES clamber over ruined mansions. A stagnant swimming pool blooms with algae. Inside an abandoned hospital, amid falling plaster and splintered banisters, a chink in the wall reveals a city skyline. This is not a movie set, though it might become one.

The Atlanta Braves understand the fleeting nature of the standings this time of year. They ended last August with an 80-55 record and an eight-and-a-half-game lead for a playoff spot, only to squander it by going 9-18 in September. A year later, they are embarking on another final sprint, with another wild-card lead but a sharper perspective. "It's a bad taste, and I don't know if you ever want to go through it," Fredi Gonzalez, the Braves' manager, said last week. "But at the end of the season, if we advance, we can look back and say it helped."

Because of an editing error, a picture credit on Aug. 12 with an article about an increase in the number of microbreweries in South Africa , a country known for its wines , misspelled the given name of the photographer who took pictures of some breweries and a brewer. He is Pieter Bauermeister, not Peter. The article also misstated the name of the Web site for Valley Brewery. It is facebook.com/valleybrewery .

ON Aug. 2 Gabby Douglas, the 4-foot-11-inch, 94-pound dynamo nicknamed the Flying Squirrel, vaulted her way into the lead in the women's individual all-around finals at the Olympic Games in London. She became the first black gymnast -- and only the fourth American -- to win a gold medal in that event. In ''OPRAH'S NEXT CHAPTER,'' Sunday at 8:30 p.m. on OWN, Oprah Winfrey interviews Ms. Douglas at her gym in West Des Moines, Iowa, where she moved from Virginia Beach at 14 to train with Liang Chow, who had coached Shawn Johnson to a gold. Ms. Winfrey also speaks with Ms. Douglas's mother, Natalie Hawkins, and with Missy and Travis Parton, the white couple who gave Ms. Douglas a new home. ''I have an advantage because I'm the underdog, and I'm black, and no one thinks I'd ever win,'' the effervescent Ms. Douglas told The New York Times after the national championships in June, when even Martha Karolyi, the women's national team coordinator, didn't think she had what it took to be an Olympian. ''Well, I'm going to inspire so many people. Everybody will be talking about, how did she come up so fast? But I'm ready to shine.''

In Gia Kourlas's column on the changes in the New York Dance and Performance Awards, also known as the Bessies, [''Classifications in the Science of an Art,'' Aug. 12], she takes issue with the subcommittees within the selection committee charged with looking at work in different areas of New York City's diverse dance landscape. Ms. Kourlas rather inexplicably concludes that ''there seems to be more attention focused on raising the profile of the Bessies than on artistic achievement.'' The committee was increased to 41 members from 15, so there are more eyes looking at more dance. The members work in subcommittees, so there can be more rigorous considerations of specific areas of dance. The result is that artistic achievement is more central. Clearly, raising the Bessies' profile ensures the artistic achievement recognized gets broader visibility.

Joel is survived by wife Mariana, two sons, five grandchildren and many friends. He was an avid sailor, skier, fisherman, and hunter - the ultimate outdoorsman.

1. Tom Brady's Tuck (2002) The Raiders lose a playoff game to the Patriots because the refs deem Brady's sack-and-fumble an incomplete pass -- a moment that embodies not only the Raiders' knack for misfortune but also their soul-crushing inability to handle it when it comes.

James Vlahos's article points out that ''both sides participating in the settlement transactions are winners,'' because the life-insurance industry's pricing models assume that the majority of policies lapse. There are sure to be few lapsed policies among those bought by outside investors. So either the insurance companies will lose money or, more likely, they will increase prices to maintain profitability. Concord, Mass.
HOLLAND--Brian, 67, died August 14th at his Maryland farm. He took an acronym normally reserved for a newspaper jumble puzzle - NASDAQ - and turned it into a household name.

THE other day I got hung up on a new sandbar, the words ''luxury-branded accommodations,'' a term that sadly does not apply to mortuaries (not yet) but rather to hotel rooms splashed with a peer company's status symbols. A classic twofer, but clearly intended for gullible people. The fashion industry began using collaborations maybe 10 years ago as a way of attracting attention and as a legitimate means of experimenting with new kinds of artistic expression. Marc Jacobs's work with the artists Richard Prince and Takashi Murakami is a standout example. Mugler used Lady Gaga to spruce up its daring image, though the excitement soon fizzled.

Canada , the country where the directors James Cameron, David Cronenberg and Paul Haggis were born, is tapping its creative and civic-minded public to promote tourism. The country's tourism commission last week began a contest in which would-be directors can upload videos or images showcasing their travel experiences to a Web site. In case Canadians are stumped about what to include, the Web site for the project, called 35 Million Directors, helpfully offers a list that includes sports, breakfast, sunrise and, perplexingly, feet. The idea, though, isn't to overthink it.
DEMIRJIAN--John. Seiji Newman and the entire Newman family extend heartfelt condolences to Alexis, his brother Greg and sister Andrea on the loss of their father.

My dad also brought home delicacies from a Jewish bakery -- Hagelsteins. I still enjoy a good slice of babka, and I want to thank David Sax for a beautifully written piece that reminds me how much of a role food, and rituals, play in our lives. And when I make a Howard Jack, I'll be thinking of this story. WENDY ROTHMAN, Ann Arbor, Mich.

NELSON--Jerry. The cast and crew of Sesame Street, and the Board of Trustees and staff of Sesame Workshop deeply mourn the loss of cast member and creator of dozens of Muppet characters, Jerry Nelson. A member of the Sesame Street family for more than 40 years, he will forever be in our hearts and remembered for the artistry in his puppetry, his music, and the laughter he brought to children worldwide through his portrayal of Count von Count, Herry Monster, Fat Blue and many other beloved characters. We will miss his extraordinary spirit and the joy he brought to our Street.

FUTTER--Kenneth Gunther, of Bell Island, Rowayton, CT and New York City died peacefully at his home on August 19th. Born December 23, 1924 in Berlin, Germany, son of the late Matthew and Erna Futter. Attended the Kalisky School, Berlin; DeWitt Clinton High School, New York and Antioch College, Ohio. Veteran of World War II and the Korean War. Respected management consultant and CPA for advertising, lumber and design businesses and, after retirement, revered SCORE volunteer. Beloved husband of Lyn Gaylord; devoted father to Catherine and Barbara, step-father to Jennifer and Timothy, brother Bernard and his family and cousin Hans. He will always be remembered for his dedication to equality for all. Donations can be made to the Visiting Nurse and Hospice of Fairfield County or Whittingham Cancer Center, Norwalk Hospital in Ken's name. Memorial service will be private.

ROLLINS--Edwin A.,attorney and public defender, died August 17, 2012 at the age of 81. Ed defended the indigent for many years as a criminal defense attorney for the Legal Aid Society and later in private practice. A lifelong fighter for labor justice, he was a leader of the successful 1973 Legal Aid Society strike. Ed was a graduate of Columbia Law School and a Korean War-era veteran of the U.S. Navy. Ed is survived by his daughter, Dr. Elizabeth Lorde-Rollins, his son, Jonathan Rollins, and his sister, Barbara Coons. The family will receive mourners at the George H. Weldon Funeral Home, 353 East 116th Street, New York, NY on Sunday, August 26, 2012 from 12 noon to 4pm, with a funeral service to follow the viewing. Interment will be Monday at Calverton National Cemetery.
CLINTON STUDIO CO-OP $255,000

Last Tuesday, in the seventh inning against Cincinnati at Citizens Bank Park, Cliff Lee of the Philadelphia Phillies walked Todd Frazier. It is the only walk Lee has issued in four starts this month, compared with 32 strikeouts. Alas, he has no victories in August. His 3.99 E.R.A. this month has something to do with it, but the results have continued a dreary trend. The Phillies have scored just 57 runs while Lee has been pitching this season, averaging 3.32 per nine innings for him. He has seven losses and two victories, the fewest wins for any pitcher with at least 20 starts this season.

[Sarah Hepola's Riff column on Cat Marnell] seems to get at a point I made a while back that the same habit of addiction that drives a person to return again and again to the drug of his or her choice may have found a parallel in the reward-and-shame cycle of writing about oneself. Whether people praise or condemn or just keep writing about you . . . there's still an itch being scratched there. Marnell wrote, ''Why does a person have to have resolved their drug issues in order to be allowed to write about them?'' which is a totally fair question. She doesn't have to have resolved anything to write whatever she wants to. But it changes how we read her story, and how we feel about doing so. posted on The Atlantic Wire

THE major institutions of classical music in New York are pretty much in snooze mode during the final week of August. But the Metropolitan Opera is again offering its SUMMER HD FESTIVAL: 10 free screenings of live HD broadcasts of Met productions selected from the last few seasons, shown at Lincoln Center Plaza on consecutive nights. Through Sept. 3; metopera.org . Sunday brings Mozart's ''Don Giovanni,'' with the charismatic baritone Mariusz Kwiecien as Giovanni, at 7:30 p.m. The imaginative 2008 production by Phelim McDermott and Julian Crouch of Philip Glass's ''Satyagraha'' (Tuesday, 7:45 p.m.) got to the core of the work. This broadcast, taken from last season's revival, offers the tenor Richard Croft as Gandhi.

TUCKED amid New Haven's gritty downtown not far from the well-groomed Yale campus lies the Ninth Square, a district of old red-brick buildings whose storefronts sat mostly vacant for decades. But that has changed in recent years. The opening last year of a sprawling organic food store, Elm City Market ( elmcitymarket.coop ), announced the area's rebirth, with an assist from an urban-renewal city initiative that has converted empty spaces into artsy businesses called Project Storefronts . A wave of new art galleries, trendy boutiques and Brooklyn-style lofts stuffed with architects and social media types has followed. ''We have so many like-minded people with a do-something attitude that want to collaborate in a shared space,'' said Ben Berkowitz, a founding member of MakeHaven (266 State Street; makehaven.org ), a collaborative workshop. The same might be said of the Ninth Square at large. LIONEL BEEHNER

An article last Sunday on the French actor and director Guillaume Canet misidentified the setting for his new film, ''Little White Lies.'' The movie's band of close-knit friends vacations in Cap Ferret, France, which is on the Atlantic coast -- not Cap Ferrat, which is on the Riviera.

HORTON--Joseph R. (Joey) Died peacefully at home in New York City on August 19th, 2012. He was 62 years old. He is predeceased by his father, Sidney Horton, and survived by his spouse, William Zeolla, his mother, Phylis Caplan Horton, his sister Joan Horton, and his two nephews, Nick and Max Iattoni. Joey is a graduate of The Parsons School of Interior Design and was an exceptionally talented interior designer. Together with his partner William, they ran their company, "Joey Horton Interiors." THE Streetscapes column on Aug. 19, about the early 20th-century reconstruction of Park Avenue in Midtown, reported on the block-deep co-op then built at 277 Park Avenue, among other things. Following is a selection of reader comments from nytimes.com :

An article in some editions on Aug. 12 about Transportation Alternatives, the bicycle and pedestrian advocacy group, referred incorrectly to a campaign of painting roadways with body outlines where pedestrians had been killed by cars. While the collective of advocates behind the campaign, in the 1990s, included some former members of Transportation Alternatives, the collective acted independently of that advocacy group.

I watched Super Bowl XLVI in February by myself, the same way I watch most televised N.F.L. games. Sad? Hardly. Solo watching is a habit I adopted in high school. Although my friends and family were not overtly obnoxious, I often found them disruptive. When I was in middle school, my father entered the room with seconds left in a tight Cowboys-Eagles game. Having invested hours in watching this game, I was bothered that he was once again joining just in time for the conclusion. This, to me, was like showing up at the end of a long dinner and interrupting everyone's conversation to ask for dessert.

I was 7 years old, and it was 1955. My mother had just gone to Old Man Winter's Thrift Shop in Buf alo and returned with a Pierre Balmain suit (!) that she got for $8 to wear on Easter. The following Sunday, after spending six days deciding how to accessorize, I donned the suit, the straw cloche, white gloves, lipstick (no rouge!) and her size 6 low heels. Then I hit the street, parading up and down Weston Avenue, where many Italian families lived and who were either howling or trying to lift their jaws from the floor or just blink, but who oddly seemed to accept me exactly for who I was. Is there less tolerance nowadays? It would seem to me that this is so. These parents are doing everything they can, in such a touching and loving way, to make their children happy with who they are. STEVEN GOURNAY, New York, posted on nytimes.com

SCHACHTER--Rozalie. The American Friends of the Jerusalem College of Technology mourn the passing of their beloved and dedicated board member Dr. Rozalie Schachter. A leader in the technology industry, Rozalie was president of Herley Microwave and a dear friend of the students and alumni of JCT. Our condolences to her beloved husband, Rabbi Dr. Joseph Schachter, her parents, children and grandchildren. Louis Libin, President

GORMAN--Virginia Dwyer, died in Manhattan on August 20th at age 92. Virginia Dwyer was an actress best know for her work on daytime television, primarily for the role of Mary Matthews on "Another World". Ms. Dwyer was born in Omaha, NE, on December 19, 1919. She was married to television producer James Fleming and later to television director Walter Gorman. She is survived by her daughter, Susan Fleming Moran; her grandson, Conor Moran; her sister, Jenny Lou Brink; four nephews and three nieces. A memorial service is planned for October 13th in Tyringham, MA.

ZAUDER--Howard L.,M.D., Ph.D., of Scottsdale, AZ died on August 17, 2012 at the age of 88. He was Emeritus Professor of Anesthesiology and Pharmacology and Former Chairman of the Department of Anesthesiology, SUNY Health Science Center, Syracuse, NY. Dr. Zauder was President of the American Society of Anesthesiologists in 1987, and also served as President of the Society of Academic Anesthesiology Chairmen and Chairman of the Board of Governors of the American College of Anesthesiologists. He is survived by his wife, Linda Stehling, M.D. of Scottsdale, AZ, and daughter Gail Zauder of New York City. He was preceded in death by his son Adam Zauder. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice of the Valley, 1510 E. Flower Street, Phoenix, AZ 85014.

8 P.M. (Sundance) DOMINO (2005) The Sundance Channel pays tribute to the director Tony Scott, who died last Sunday, with his biopic about Domino Harvey (played by Keira Knightley, above), the privileged daughter of a jet-setting mother and the British actor Laurence Harvey who became a bounty hunter in South Central Los Angeles. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called this action adventure, whose ensemble cast features Mickey Rourke, Christopher Walken, Delroy Lindo, Jacqueline Bisset, Dabney Coleman and Mo'Nique, ''a lollapalooza of delectable cheap thrills.'' What makes it ''the ultimate Tony Scott movie -- or as a friend put it, 'It's all the Tony Scott you could possibly want in a Tony Scott movie!' -- is its uncharacteristically sharp screenplay,'' she said of its script by Richard Kelly. ''Mr. Scott has worked with talented writers before, but this is the first time he has shot a film written by a screenwriter who both cops to the great enjoyment that can be had from the modern action movie -- perhaps best illustrated here by the sight of Ms. Knightley unloading two machine guns at once -- and blows the action-movie tropes to smithereens.'' 9 A.M. (IFC) LETTERS FROM IWO JIMA (2006) Using illustrated letters by Lt. Gen. Tadamichi Kuribayashi to his wife and child, the director Clint Eastwood and the screenwriter Iris Yamashita chronicle, from the Japanese perspective, a crucial battle in World War II , in which an estimated 20,000 Japanese infantrymen fought, and only 1,083 survived. Ken Watanabe plays Kuribayashi in a performance ''all the more heartbreaking for his crisp, unsentimental dignity,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times.

WHEN the Republican Party meets in Tampa, Fla., this week, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey will deliver the keynote address. He promises "hard truths." Twenty years ago, the Democrat-turned-Republican Phil Gramm had that job. Warning to Governor Christie: no one remembers anything Mr. Gramm said. What we do remember from the 1992 convention in Houston is the jeremiad delivered by Patrick J. Buchanan, the former speechwriter for Richard M. Nixon who won nearly a quarter of Republican primary votes that year. With his invocation of a "cultural war" for the "soul of America," Mr. Buchanan brought down the house. His fulminations against abortion, homosexuality and other hot-button "cultural" issues exceeded tolerable political rhetoric and likely hurt President George Bush in the general election. But Mr. Buchanan nonetheless set the tone for the Clinton years, and "culture war" became shorthand for the battle between Red and Blue in the 1990s.

It's gratifying when what seems old becomes new again. That's the promise extended Oct. 12 at Carnegie Hall with ''Some Enchanted Evening: The Music of Rodgers and Hammerstein,'' by the New York Pops and the guests Aaron Lazar, Kelli O'Hara and Paulo Szot. Let the music of Richard Rodgers (above left) and Oscar Hammerstein II (right) -- ''Oklahoma!,'' ''South Pacific,'' ''Carousel'' -- dull the fall chill ( carnegiehall.org ).

THE novelist Ian Fleming was not pleased when he learned that his greatest creation, James Bond, was played by Sean Connery in ''Dr. No,'' the first in the film series. ''I'm looking for Cmdr. James Bond,'' he said, ''not an overgrown stuntman.'' Moviegoers disagreed, and Fleming later came to his senses. Now, in honor of the franchise's 50th anniversary, the complete Connery Bonds (including ''Never Say Never Again,'' from 1983), will be screened in IFC's aptly named program JAMES BOND NO. 1: SEAN CONNERY'S 007, starting Friday (with an all-day, seven-film Bond-a-thon next Sunday.) Opinions vary as to the others who have portrayed the pride of Her Majesty's Secret Service (and I, for one, will defend Pierce Brosnan). But we can all agree that Mr. Connery rules. Perhaps it's his devilish good looks. Or the subtle Scottish burr. Or his leading ladies. (Honor Blackman, your Pussy Galore will always be Bond Girl No. 1.) Or his urbane insouciance. Or his cruel cool when Bond sends Auric Goldfinger through an airplane window in ''Goldfinger.'' Let us raise a martini to his 007 -- and you know how he takes it. 323 Avenue of the Americas, at Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 924-7771, ifccenter.com .

MAHAFFEY--Constance Cassidy Constance Cassidy Mahaffey, of Fort Worth, TX, died peacefully Saturday afternoon, August 11, 2012, during her 74th year. Per her wishes, services will be held privately by family and friends. Memorials: In lieu of flowers, consideration of contributions to NPR (National Public Radio), in her memory, is suggested. Born in Paris, France, on January 23, 1938, Constance was the daughter of Henry Clarence and Marthea Stucklen Cassidy. At age 13, the family returned to the United States where she attended Friends Seminary in New York City. Constance attended Pembroke College in Brown University before receiving a BA in English literature from Roosevelt University. She received an MA, also in English literature, from the University of Illinois. Constance taught at the University of Kentucky. After retiring in 2000 from the University of Texas at Austin where she taught and worked in various departments, including linguistics, international studies and astronomy, she moved to Fort Worth to be closer to her family. Survivors: In addition to her daughter, Andrea Mahaffey Brim and her husband, Rick, Constance is survived by her grandchildren, Eric of Dallas, Travis of Houston and Lauren and Ryan of Fort Worth; cousins including, Susan Goodfellow and her husband, Bill of Salt Lake City, Utah; and many good friends including Keatha Falls and Daesene Willman of Austin and dear friend of 57 years, Kathrin Perutz of New York City.

Willa Ward, who lent her pure, note-bending voice to the Ward Singers, one of the most famous and influential groups of what is considered the golden age of gospel singing, died in Philadelphia on Aug. 12. She was 91. Her daughter Rita Scarlet confirmed her death.

Sacramento State shocked Oregon State, 29-28, last September. It was James Madison over Virginia Tech in 2010. Richmond beat Duke in 2009. Playing a Football Championship Subdivision opponent comes at a cost for Football Bowl Subdivision teams. A win is expected, but a loss as a doubledigit favorite overshadows anything a team might achieve over the course of the season -- see the Hokies in 2010. What F.B.S. teams should be wary of an underrated F.C.S. opponent? Kent State (Towson, Thursday); Maryland (William & Mary, Saturday); Colorado State (North Dakota State, Sept. 8); Minnesota (New Hampshire, Sept. 8).

Anthony Davis has had a spectacular year. After leading Kentucky to the N.C.A.A. championship in April, Davis, a 6-foot-10 power forward, was chosen in June by the New Orleans Hornets as the first pick of the N.B.A. draft. This month, Davis helped the United States men's basketball team win the gold medal at the London Olympics. Davis, 19, was named the Associated Press men's college basketball player of the year after averaging 14.2 points, 10.4 rebounds and 4.6 blocked shots for the Wildcats.

EISENBERG--Renee Abramson, 84, of Whippany, N.J.,died August 24. She is survived by her husband Mervin; daughter Robin and partner Bean Meles; son Richard and daughter-in-law Liz and grandsons Aaron and Will. She was a devoted wife, mother and grandmother and a sweet, smart, wonderful woman who will be greatly missed. Funeral Sunday, August 26 at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman in Livingston, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to Ruth Estrin Goldberg Memorial for Cancer Research (P.O. Box 194, Springfield, NJ, 07081), Alzheimer's Association or the charity of your choice.
GURNEY--Alan Peter, died peacefully on 22nd July 2012 in Woodbridge, Essex, United Kingdom. Much loved husband of Carol, stepfather to Charlie and Matthew.

PECHEUR--Richard A.,of Sea Cliff, NY on August 23rd, 2012 age 67. Employee of the NYSE for 36 years. Loving husband, father, brother and grandfather. Visitation at the Funeral Home of Dodge-Thomas Glen Cove, Saturday 7-9pm; Sunday 3-5pm. Service at Dodge-Thomas Funeral Home, Sunday 5pm. Interment Private. Donations may be made to the Marty Lyons Foundation. www.DodgeThomas.com

KATZ--Howard. 4/18/22 - 8/26/03. Never have nine short years been so long. We know that you are still with us trying to guide our hands to do better for all. But we can only see and hear you in our minds, and although we are grateful, it is not enough. Gilda and The Boys

TALVE--Jack, age 85, of Plainview, NY died peacefully on August 24, 2012. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Molly, by three children, Shelley Haber of Jericho, Kenny Talve of Huntington Station, and Larry Talve of Muttontown, NY, a son-in-law Dennis Haber and a daughter-in-law Lauren Talve. He leaves six grandchildren. Jason Haber, his wife Cory Erin Haber, Cory Haber, Lindsay Talve, Ashley Talve, Zachary Talve and Kara Talve, a great-granddaughter Makayla Haber, his brother Mark Talve of North Hills and sister Clarisse Talve of Brooklyn. He proudly served in the Marines during World War II. After the war, he along with his two brothers, Isadore and Mark formed Franklin Stainless Corp., which supplied customers throughout the world with stainless steel. His passions in life consisted of music, collecting art and travel. He loved life and loved his country. His country loved him back. In honor of his 85th birthday he received a flag that was flown over the United States Capitol. He will be missed forevermore. Nothing was more important to him than family. This loving man set the example for living life the way it was meant to be lived.

STAHL--Dr. Bernard, DDS, 91, died peacefully on August 25th during a brief hospital stay in Peabody, MA. Born March 11, 1921 in Washington, DC, the older son of Jacob and Augusta Stahl. He leaves behind his loving, devoted wife of 64 years, Hortense (nee Leiner) and daughter Shelley Stahl (Marblehead, MA), son Larry Stahl (Irvine, CA) and son and daughter-in-law Michael and Wendy Stahl (Montclair, NJ). He also leaves behind Shelley's children Alyssa and Emma Charney and Michael and Wendy's children Jason and Rebecca Stahl. He is also survived by his brother Seymour of Boynton Beach, FL. An avid sailor, Bernie and Horty spent many years cruising along the eastern seaboard and the Bahamas. He also took an avid interest in music, drawing and photography. He shared his talents generously, passing along his interests and skills to his children and grandchildren.

In the fall of 2007, I attended my first yoga class. For more than four years - ever since graduation had dumped me into adulthood - I'd been leveled by anxiety. My days were plagued with worry. Was I living correctly? What if I died? What if, like in that Twilight Zone episode, the rest of the world died and I lived? Innocuous things I said to people haunted me hours later- Was that dumb? Mean? Wildly inappropriate?-until I'd squirm with shame. Unable to sleep at night, I gobbled Tylenol PM, rationalizing that it was over-the-counter, as if "over-the-counter" meant "nutritious. I'd heard that yoga was relaxing. So one Saturday morning, in the spirit of relaxation, I spent 90 minutes contorting my body inside a 100-degree Bikram yoga studio. "For your first class," the teacher said before we began, "the goal is just to stay in the room."

HOW'S this for a sweet nothing? ''I could squeeze a bullet between those lips.'' And don't even ask about the erotic possibilities of a grenade. PHILIP RIDLEY, one of the most linguistically vivid and disturbing dramatists on the planet, reoutfits the language of love from his own special arsenal in ''Tender Napalm,'' which is receiving its American premiere at 59E59 Theaters. When it opened in London last year, this, uh, explosive anatomy of an affair had critics sounding as breathless as the play's two characters, a man and woman shipwrecked (literally) by passion. Pinter, Albee, Coward, Strindberg and Shakespeare were all summoned to describe a work in which dialogue came in shades of purple. Obviously the multifarious Mr. Ridley -- who is also an artist, filmmaker and (gulp) children's book author -- isn't easy to pigeonhole. But the man who gave us such resplendently titled dramas as ''The Pitchfork Disney'' and the deeply divisive ''Mercury Fur'' can always be relied upon to rattle, roil and possibly revolt his audiences. Paul Takacs directs Blake Ellis and Amelia Workman as a couple for whom sex is anything but safe. Opens Wednesday, through Sept. 9, 59 East 59th Street, Manhattan, (212) 279-4200, 59e59.org .

THESE early mornings in late August already taste of the coming autumn, so perhaps it's only right to point out that this is the last chance to see some plants of summer that will vanish very soon. ''ELLSWORTH KELLY PLANT DRAWINGS,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, closes Sept. 3, and it's an oasis of austere pleasures worth escaping to one more time. Mr. Kelly, who is 89, is revered for his abstract paintings and sculptures, but he has called his plant drawings ''a kind of bridge to a way of seeing that was the basis of the very first abstract paintings.'' The exhibition features 80 works, the earliest dating to 1948, and is the first major museum show dedicated exclusively to his drawings of plants, flowers and leaves. Whether using watercolor, graphite or ink, Mr. Kelly pares his plants to their elegant and essential lines -- sometimes straining toward a kind of plain abstraction -- but in the end they are all plant, all Kelly. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org .

To the Sports Editor: Re ''All Business on the First Date,'' Aug. 11: Campbell Robertson and Sarah Lyall wrote that in the equestrian portion of the modern pentathlon, riders cannot do much about horses that are ''simply bad,'' meaning they do not comply with the rider's directions after a 20-minute introduction.

Remy Charlip, a dancer, choreographer and founding member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company who dazzled avant-garde audiences for decades before finding an even larger audience writing and illustrating children's books with titles like ''Dress Up and Let's Have a Party'' and ''Fortunately,'' died on Tuesday in San Francisco. He was 83. His death was announced by June Ekman, a dance teacher at Sarah Lawrence College, where Mr. Charlip was a founder of the children's theater program. No cause was given, though Mr. Charlip had never fully recovered from a stroke in 2005.

''Money market funds effectively are operating without a net.'' Mary L. Schapiro, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Attempts to make sweeping changes to money market mutual funds, by having them hold cash reserves and let their share prices fluctuate, have been derailed.

Nearly a quarter of the 124 programs in the Football Bowl Subdivision will have changed their conference affiliation from 2011-'13. The reality of conference realignment is that every league is affected, and it will take at least a year or two for most of us to remember that universities like Temple, Nevada and Missouri play in the Big East, Mountain West and Southeastern Conference. A look at the 2012-13 changes. Atlantic Coast Conference

Matt Barkley, U.S.C., QB (2011: 308 of 446 for 3,528 yards, 39 touchdowns, 7 interceptions) Like Stanford's Andrew Luck last year, Barkley enters the season as the favorite to win the Heisman Trophy. What can Barkley learn from Luck's unsuccessful Heisman campaign? That taking care of business is only one part of the race. Like Luck, Barkley needs to produce while keeping an eye out for a fast-rising underdog - like Baylor's Robert Griffin III, who went from a borderline contender last August to the Heisman winner in December.
