The Spanish filmmaker David Victori was the grand prize winner of the first Your Film Festival , an online competition sponsored by YouTube, Scott Free Productions and Emirates airlines, for his short film "The Guilt," about a man out for revenge after his wife's murder. The announcement was made at the Venice Film Festival on Sunday after his film was selected from a pool of 10 finalists by a jury that included the director Ridley Scott and the actor Michael Fassbender. According to a news release the global competition received 15,000 submissions, which were narrowed down to 50 semifinalists by Mr. Scott's production company. YouTube viewers then voted to select the final 10 films. Mr. Victori will receive $500,000 for his next project for YouTube, and Mr. Scott and Mr. Fassbender will act as executive producers.

In Victor LaValle's third novel, "The Devil in Silver," a man called Pepper is taken to a psychiatric hospital in Queens by three cops who don't want to be bothered with putting him in jail for assault. He's told he will be there for 72 hours of observation, but the days stretch to months. Mr. LaValle is known for an approach that mixes various literary influences and tones, from humor to horror. While Pepper struggles to get decent treatment from an indifferent staff, he also forges alliances - some shakier than others - with his fellow patients and marshals them to fight a beast that has the withered body of an old man and the large head of a bison. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. LaValle discussed "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," the art of making a monster, van Gogh's kinship with his characters and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation: Q.

For companies like Amazon, Google and Microsoft that sell cloud computing services, the most drastic changes may be in places most of us do not see. Already, places without clean water, decent sanitation or steady electricity are using supercomputers. Cheki is a used-car classifieds business that serves about a million people a month, mostly in Kenya and Nigeria. Most of the one million people using the site are looking at it with Android -based smartphones that cost about $70, according to Thomas Shaw, the company's information technology manager. Imagine things in a few years, when Huawei, which makes most of the devices, gets those phone prices even lower.

ABRAMS--John Bryden. Roy and Evelyn Abrams, bereaved brother and sister-in-law to Jed Abrams, wish to express their profound sense of loss and sorrow over Jed's untimely passing. As those who knew him well were aware, Jed's core self consisted of an infinite tenderness and vulnerability. Often most honestly expressed with the nieces and nephews he adored, as well as the animals he rescued and kept over the years, it was a pure spring of lovingness we feel privileged to have known and traumatized to have lost. Our prayers for your soul, brother, we will always love you.

4:56 p.m. | Updated " The Royal Romance of Charles and Diana " was a forgettable made-for-TV movie broadcast by CBS in 1982. But it has re-emerged 30 years later at the center of an esoteric but messily contentious dispute about screenwriting credits involving faculty members at New York University's prestigious Tisch School of the Arts .

Watching golf on television, you may have noticed that golf shoes are shrinking. The minimalist movement is most obviously exemplified by the casual, street-style shoes some professionals have begun wearing in competition. The shoes have small plastic studs for traction but no spikes. A golfer can put them on in the morning at home, hop in the car, drive to the golf course, play 18 holes and still be wearing them in a restaurant afterward.

VANN--Guy Keith, 56, died peacefully in his home on September 1, 2012. Born in New York City where he resided his entire life, Guy graduated Brooklyn Law School and became a pioneering litigator and innovator in the field of indoor air quality litigation. He was a passionate advocate who independently tackled the most difficult cases often against formidable opponents. His wit, humor and sharp intellect will be sorely missed by all who knew him. He is the son of Barbara Blumenthal and the late Sydney Vann and is predeceased by his beloved stepfather, Arthur Blumenthal. Services will be held on Tuesday, September 4, 2012 at 6:30pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York, NY. Donations can be made to ASPCA in memory of Guy Keith Vann at www.aspca.org.

Greg Norman's name still comes up an awful lot even though he has played in only three PGA Tour events in the last five years. Adam Scott, as he was almost winning the British Open this summer, talked at length about the way Norman inspired him to take up golf and pursue it as his principal sport. As it turns out, Norman, speaking from experience, helped Scott when things did not end so well at Royal Lytham & St. Annes in July.

Dear Diary: It is 1950, and I'm 12 years old. I'm at the Stadium to see a game with my father. There's a rain delay, but when they finally start rolling up the tarp, my father lets me go down to the Yankees' dugout to try to get some autographs. A short while later I'm on my way back, a huge grin on my face.

8 P.M. (CNN) OBAMA REVEALED: THE MAN, THE PRESIDENT In this 90-minute documentary Jessica Yellin, the chief White House correspondent for CNN, speaks with President Obama about his time in office, the challenges he has faced and his ambitions for a second term. She also examines the pros and cons of the president's cool demeanor and what happened when his lofty goals met the realities of Washington politics. Among those interviewed are Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton; Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago, a former White House chief of staff; Austan Goolsbee and Christina D. Romer, former heads of the Council of Economic Advisers; Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio; and David E. Sanger, the chief Washington correspondent for The New York Times. In ''Barack Obama: Making History,'' at 10 on MSNBC, Chris Matthews examines the historical context of the president's election and presidency, and looks at what he has accomplished during his first term as well as what he hopes to achieve going forward. Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., the campaign adviser David Axelrod and Caroline Kennedy weigh in. 9 A.M. (Nickelodeon) SPONGEBOB SQUAREPANTS An all-day marathon leads up to two new episodes, starting at 7:30 p.m. In ''Squid Baby,'' Squidward reverts to infancy after hitting his head, and in ''The Good Krabby Name,'' SpongeBob and Patrick develop an advertising blitz to get everyone in Bikini Bottom to eat at the Krusty Krab.

ABRAMS--John Bryden. Jan and Stefan Abrams are devastated to announce the death of their beloved son, John (Jed) Bryden Abrams, who lost his will to live on August 30, 2012. He will be deeply missed by his brother Roy, sister Cleo, sister-in law, Evelyn, brother-in-law Brian and his adoring nieces and nephews, Eric, Isla, Lila, Kiki, and Owen, as well as his uncles Mark and Richard, aunt Nancy, his partner Amanda Mills and much extended family and friends. With his handsome good looks and engaging personality, Jed represented all that was beautiful, tender, unpredictable and sometimes perplexing. He enthusiastically pursued the unorthodox with his martial arts talents, yet had an incredible business savvy for the financial markets. He will be missed by all who had the privilege of spending time with his unique persona and personality. A graveside service will be held in Topeka, Kansas and a memorial service will be announced in New York. It is our hope that donations in his memory be sent to the Brain and Behavior Research Foundation, 60 Cutter Mill Road, Suite 404, Great Neck, New York 11201.

Dear Diary: The wealthy, pretty people are all at the beach, leaving the rest of us in an ordinary city with manageable streets. Soon they'll be back, with vacation-reading book reviews and complaints about how that place has really gone off, filling the roads with goldenrod cabs, and we will know, truer than falling leaves, that summer is over.

MARK--Frieda, born January 5, 1906 died peacefully in her sleep on September 1. Beloved and devoted wife of the late Meyer Mark. Beloved mother of Morris [Susan], grandmother of Matthew [Cindy] and Tara [Ken], great-grandmother of Alexa, Amanda, Andrew, Jane, and Maxine. A true family hero. We all love you.

KEIN--Verna. Died August 29 at the age of 57 from renal amyloidosis. Daughter of Adele and Fritz Kein. An extraordinarily kind and loving daughter, mother, sister, friend, physical therapist and healer. Survived by her daughter Rebecca and sisters Anita and Belinda.

This month, the British newspaper The Guardian ran an interactive map of American drone strikes, pinpointing the locations in Pakistan where missiles from the unmanned aerial vehicles struck suspected terrorists. The map, which was based on data from the Bureau of Investigative Journalism in Britain, was available through The Guardian's app for the iPhone , as well as its Web site. A graduate student at New York University, Josh Begley, recently took the same data on drone strikes from the same source that The Guardian used and put it into an iPhone app of his own creation that featured an interactive map. While The Guardian's map was part of a much broader newspaper app featuring all manner of articles, the app by Mr. Begley, called Drones Plus, was dedicated exclusively to the drone strikes.

A Renaissance drawing from a prized British collection is being sold at Sotheby's in London on Dec. 5, the auction house is expected to announce on Tuesday. Raphael's "Head of an Apostle,'' dating from around 1519, was created as a study for a figure in one of the artist's greatest late paintings, "Transfiguration,'' that belongs to the Vatican Museum in Rome. The drawing, which was executed in black chalk, is from Chatsworth, the Derbyshire home of the Duke of Devonshire (who also happens to be deputy chairman of Sotheby's board of directors.) Estimated to sell for $15.8 million to $23.8 million, it has belonged to the Duke's family since William Cavendish, the 2nd Duke of Devonshire, acquired it sometime in either in the late 17th or early 18th centuries.

LUCKER--Jay K. February 23, 1930 - September 2, 2012. Survived by his daughters Amy and Nancy, son-in-law Joshua, grandson Benjamin, and sister Gloria. Predeceased by his wife Marjorie Stern, whom he met while they both attended Brooklyn College. Jay was a leader in the library world, having last served as Director of Libraries at MIT, before his retirement in 1995. Prior to MIT, he was at the Princeton University Libraries after starting his career at the New York Public Library on 42nd Street. He received his MLS from Columbia University in 1952. Throughout his career he was active as a library building and planning consultant, continuing to work up to the present. He was widely loved and admired, and will be greatly missed.

The scandal over global interest rates has state officials like Janet Cowell of North Carolina working intensely behind the scenes to build a case for suing the nation's largest banks. Ms. Cowell, the state's elected treasurer, and several of her staff members have spent the summer combing through the state's investments trying to determine how much the state may have lost because of suspected manipulation of the London interbank offered rate , or Libor, which is used as a benchmark for trillions of dollars of financial contracts around the world.

VENICE - The middle weekend of the Venice Film Festival saw the premieres of the two most eagerly awaited films in the official competition. Both, as it happens, are unorthodox love stories - as well as tales of spiritual crises - by American auteurs with perfectionist reputations and loyal followings. "The Master," Paul Thomas Anderson's maximalist drama about the complicated bonds between a charismatic cult leader and a tormented World War II veteran, screened on Saturday morning to a largely receptive press audience; early reviews have been mostly very positive. (Some examples are here and here .)

KRESSEL--Bertha H. The Yeshiva Family is deeply grieved by the passing of Bertha H. Kressel, a virtual Eshet Chayil - a Jewish Woman of Valor - who was educated at the Yeshiva of Crown Heights and Yeshiva University's Brooklyn High School for Girls and Brooklyn College. She was the beloved wife of Dr. Henry Kressel, a graduate of Yeshiva College, who is the first university alumnus to serve as the Chairman of Yeshiva University's Board of Trustees. Together the Kressels are Benefactors of Yeshiva University, and established a Chair in Economics and Research Fellowships for outstanding undergraduate students. They are the proud parents of Aron (and Lois) Kressel, M.D., of New York City and Kim (and Zev) Efrat, of Efrat, Israel, grandparents of seven and great-grandparents of two. Bertha was a deeply cherished aunt, and friend to many because of her humility, acts of chessed (compassion and loving kindness) and her love of Jewish and general culture, virtues reflected in the lives of her progeny. Heartfelt condolences are extended on behalf of the entire university to Dr. Henry Kressel, their children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren and the entire extended family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor

Children who use glucocorticoid inhalers to prevent asthma attacks may be shorter as adults, researchers said on Monday. Previous studies have shown that the drugs slow growth rate, but most experts believe that growth returns to normal after the first few years of therapy. But the new study , published in The New England Journal of Medicine, found that the growth deficiency persists into adulthood.

Now that the White House has revealed its recipe for Honey Brown Ale, brewed by cooks in the White House kitchen using honey from its own hives (along with releasing a nifty video of the beer-making process), I thought it would be worth assessing the recipe and methods, and conjecturing on how the beer would taste. This required a beer-making professional, so I called on Garrett Oliver, brewmaster at the Brooklyn Brewery and editor of the encyclopedic "Oxford Companion to Beer. " Like most professional brewers, Mr. Oliver began as a home brewer, and so is intimately aware of the challenges and limitations of making beer in bathrooms and kitchens, even one as exalted as the White House. "Brewing at home is very much like cooking at home - it doesn't bear much resemblance to professional brewing, but it can be done simply or very rigorously, and the results can be excellent,'' he told me, adding that the Brewers Association , a craft-brewing trade group, estimates that a million Americans make beer at home. (After word of the White House's brewing experiment spread, many of them joined in urging President Obama's aides to divulge the recipe.) "The version of brewing they're doing at the White House might be called 'second-level beginner.' "
International SON OF CHINESE OFFICIAL

If newspaper articles had routinely carried reporters' bylines 100 years ago, there would be no question now about who got one of the biggest scoops of the early 20th century, the April 18, 1912, interview with the surviving telegraph operator from the Titanic. It was published the morning after survivors of the disaster arrived in New York aboard the Carpathia, the ship that had rescued them in the Atlantic Ocean. The account, a high point of The New York Times's coverage of one of the defining events of the years before World War I, was important enough to rate a byline - unusual in those days.

KRIEGSMAN--Alan M.,84, died peacefully at home in Chevy Chase, MD, on August 31. Kriegsman was Critic Emeritus of the Washington Post, where he wrote about the arts from 1966-1996. He was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for dance criticism in 1976. Beloved husband of Sali Ann Kriegsman; cherished brother of Carl Kriegsman of Bayshore, LI, and dear uncle of Carl, Jr., Michael, Paul, and David; treasured brother-in-law of Sy Ribakove of Congers, NY and the late Richard Ribakove, and dear uncle of Joshua Ribakove; devoted son of the late May and Harry Kriegsman. Funeral at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York City, Wednesday, September 5 at 11:15am. Private burial. A memorial celebration is being planned. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in Mike's memory to the ACLU Foundation (125 Broad Street, New York, NY 10004) or JSSA Hospice (6123 Montrose Road, Rockville, MD 20852).

Neti pots -- those odd teapotlike vessels used to wash out the nasal passage -- have won legions of fans who rely on them for relief from allergies , congestion and colds . But now, after two cases of a deadly brain infection were linked to neti pots, government health officials have issued new warnings about using them safely.

Byard Lancaster , an alto saxophonist who took part in the great wave of free jazz inspired by John Coltrane and then diversified far into other music and cultures -- living in Nigeria, France and Chicago, playing blues, reggae and Afrobeat -- but kept returning to Philadelphia, his hometown, died on Aug. 23 at a hospice in Wyndmoor, Pa. He was 70. The cause was cancer, said his sister, Mary Ann Lancaster Tyler.

Connie Anderson didn't know what was bothering her 17-year-old son, a Baltimore-area high school senior with Asperger's syndrome, a form of autism. He was usually a diligent student, but his grades began to plummet. "He was starting to go downhill fast," Ms. Anderson said. "His grades were crashing, and he wasn't able to focus."

HAUSKNECHT--Murray, on September 1, 2012. Survived by his wife, Ellen, son David and his wife Sue, daughter Gina and her husband Matthew, and beloved granddaughters Elana and Jesse.

SCHIFF--Anne, died in Manhattan on August 29 at the age of 97. She was the beloved wife of Stanley Schiff who predeceased her. She graduated from Washington Irving High School and then from NYU in 1935. She was a devoted wife and mother. She had a long active life and enjoyed playing tennis and bridge into her nineties. She is survived by her two daughters Posey Bacopoulos and Helen Schiff (Richard Congress) who will always remember her love and devotion.

Jeffrey A. Michael, a finance professor in Stockton, Calif., took a hard look at his city's bankruptcy this summer and thought he saw a smoking gun: a dubious bond deal that bankers had pushed on Stockton just as the local economy was starting to tank in the spring of 2007, he said. Stockton sold the bonds, about $125 million worth, to obtain cash to close a shortfall in its pension plans for current and retired city workers. The strategy backfired, which is part of the reason the city is now in Chapter 9 bankruptcy. Stockton is trying to walk away from the so-called pension obligation bonds and to renegotiate other debts.

A map on Sunday with the continuation of an article about the hurricane-battered Plaquemines Parish on the southeastern tip of Louisiana located Venice incorrectly. The town is on the west bank of the parish, not on the east bank.

8 P.M. (Sundance) CASSANDRA'S DREAM (2008) Colin Farrell and Ewan McGregor, from left above, portray South London brothers with big dreams. Their dedication to each other and the idea of family is put to the test when each exceeds his grasp -- one by sleeping beyond his station, the other by losing large at cards -- and together they turn to their wealthy uncle (Tom Wilkinson) for help. He agrees, if they'll murder someone for him in exchange. '' 'Cassandra's Dream,' Woody Allen's latest excursion to the dark side of human nature, is good enough that you may wonder why he doesn't just stop making comedies once and for all,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Still, ''like all filmmakers, Mr. Allen steals from himself like a magpie, which wouldn't be grounds for criticism if he were a more dedicated and careful thief,'' she said. ''Like many of his later films, though, 'Cassandra's Dream' feels too lightly polished and often rushed, as if he had directed it with a stopwatch. That's too bad, because while Mr. Allen may feel as if he's running out of time, he has scarcely run out of ideas.'' 3 P.M. (NBC) THE STEVE HARVEY SHOW Mr. Harvey, the comedian, gets his own talk show.

Cherished grandfather of Bari and Jared. Devoted uncle and cousin. Unending dedication to his clients for 61 years. He will be missed by many.

A medicine commonly used for seizures and nerve pain may help treat chronic cough, a new study has found. Australian researchers conducted a small, randomized study of gabapentin, an anticonvulsant used to treat epileptic seizures, restless leg syndrome and pain caused by shingles . Gabapentin is available by prescription under various brand names.

The picture of Robson was taken by Barton Silverman of The New York Times, not by Gary Hershorn of Reuters.

SCHWARTZ--Dori Poole, 85. Dori's body died today. Her spirit is imprinted on all who knew her, her laughter and vitality, and is a treasured residue that lives on. Her passion for rooftop gardening, extended to people and animals, specializing in strays and odd-balls. We all grew a little better and enjoyed life in her presence. Wife to Jerry, mother to Erica and grandmother to Liam. Tributes should be sent to: "Meals on Wheels", reflecting her con-cern for those in need.

Christie's may have been able to get nearly $10 million for a 1962 painting of Andy Warhol's "Four Campbell's Soup Cans'' back in November, but now everyday shoppers can buy their own piece of the Pop artist for just 75 cents. On Sunday Target started selling a special edition of 1.2 million Warhol-themed tomato soup cans . Issued to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the first showing of Warhol's paintings of the celebrated soup can, the labels come in four brilliant color combinations, like blue with orange or teal with hot pink, to mimic the artist's style. They also have famous Warhol quotes on them like "In the future, everybody will be world-famous for 15 minutes,'' and a picture of the artist on the back.

SOCHYNSKY--Anastasia. Died on September 2, at the age of 90. Daughter of Motria and Fedir Koroliv, who headed the Urainian National Republic trade commission in Switzerland in 1919. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Rostyslaw Sochynsky. Mother of Yaroslav and Lada Sochynsky and Ilona Shyprykevich. Grandmother of Anna and Michael Sochynsky. An accomplished silversmith, Anastasia was devoted to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden where she sat on the Executive Committee of the Auxiliary. The BBG presented her with The Merit Award in 1999. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her generosity, connoisseurship and strong will.

As President Obama kicks off his convention week in Charlotte, N.C., his campaign has a new ad that doubles down on his charges that Mitt Romney 's economic policies would harm the middle class. "The middle class is carrying a heavy load in America," the commercial says as images of a forlorn-looking mother and a worker in a hard hat appear on the screen. "But Mitt Romney doesn't see it." A picture of Mr. Romney flashing a wide grin is shown, along with a picture of a stately brick mansion.

THE FACTS According to the Environmental Protection Agency, the levels of air pollutants inside homes can far exceed the levels outside , thanks to household cleaning products, central heating and cooling systems, and other indoor sources. But scientists have found that certain plants can scrub your home of airborne chemicals, albeit gradually.

MENLO PARK, Calif. -- New York, London and Hong Kong are common addresses for blue-chip multinationals. Now Silicon Valley is, too. From downtown San Francisco to Palo Alto, companies like American Express and Ford are opening offices and investing millions of dollars in local start-ups. This year, American Express opened a venture capital office in Facebook's old headquarters in downtown Palo Alto. Less than three miles away, General Motors ' research lab houses full-time investment professionals, recent transplants from Detroit.

It is David Ebersman's fault. There is just no way around it. Mr. Ebersman is Facebook 's well-liked, boyish-looking 41-year-old chief financial officer. ABRAMS--John Bryden. Roy and Evelyn Abrams, bereaved brother and sister-in-law to Jed Abrams, wish to express their profound sense of loss and sorrow over Jed's untimely passing. As those who knew him well were aware, Jed's core self consisted of an infinite tenderness and vulnerability. Often most honestly expressed with the nieces and nephews he adored, as well as the animals he rescued and kept over the years, it was a pure spring of lovingness we feel privileged to have known and traumatized to have lost. Our prayers for your soul, brother, we will always love you.

CARPENTER--Ruth C. A Memorial Service celebrating the life of the remarkable Ruth Carpenter will be held on September 8, 2012 at 1 p.m., at the Church of All Souls at 80th Street and Lexington Avenue.

STURM--Colonel Earl Claude, An American Leader Colonel Earl Claude Sturm, a very highly decorated Retired U.S. Army Infantry Officer, passed away on August 28, 2012. He was 88 and died in the hospital following surgery. Col. and Mrs. Sturm resided in Dacula, Georgia. Col. Sturm was born on July 22, 1924 in Burbank, Oklahoma to Earl and Odessa Schofield Sturm. He graduated from Oklaunion High School in 1941. Upon graduation he matriculated to Oklahoma A&M University. Col. Sturm was inducted into the U.S. Army as an enlisted man in 1942. He received his commission in 1944. During WWII he served as the commander of a rifle company and temporarily as the battalion commander of the 3rd Battalion, 253rd Infantry Regiment, 63rd Infantry Division. He commanded his units during the European Campaign and was in command of his units during the Battle of the Bulge and the penetration of the Siegfried Line. Upon the conclusion of WWII, Col. Sturm left active duty and returned to college where he earned his degree from Oklahoma A&M. While in college he met his life long sweetheart and wife, Edith Ellen Lackey of Wewoka, Oklahoma. They were married on February 2, 1947. Col. and Mrs. Sturm were married for 65 years. Upon the invasion of South Korea by North Korea, Col. Sturm was recalled to active duty, and once again commanded a unit in combat; Company E, 23rd Infantry Regiment, 2nd Infantry Division, designated as a Ranger unit. Col. Sturm's company led the initial assault and capture of Heart Break Ridge. After turning over the ridge to another company, they subsequently rescued that unit's troops after they valiantly held the ridge. While Col. Sturm's troops sustained a high casualty loss on the initial assault, they rescued the survivors with no further casualties. Thereafter, Col. Sturm assumed command of the area. Following three tours of duty in the Korean War, Col. Sturm occupied positions of increasing responsibility and once again commanded a Battalion in combat during the Vietnam era. Col. Sturm retired in 1971. Upon his retirement from active duty in 1971, Col. and Mrs. Sturm moved to Cape Coral, Florida. Shortly after his arrival in Cape Coral, Col. Sturm developed a successful youth tennis organization, a unique aspect of which was the pairing of young tennis players with retirees. Estimates vary greatly, but it is believed over the next 25 years almost 200,000 children participated in the program. In 1990, Col. Sturm received the USTA Service Bowl Award for his efforts to help children, and the Eve Kraft USTA Community Service Award for his significant contributions to the development of youth tennis programs. In addition to tennis, Col. Sturm loved to play golf and spend time with his three children, his eight grandchildren and his sixteen great-grandchildren. In 2010, the U.S, Army inducted Col. Sturm into the Order of Saint Maurice. He was the 843rd recipient of this prestigious award in U.S. history. Col. Sturm was inducted into the order due to his service to our country, his service to his fellow soldiers and his unquestioned integrity. Col. Sturm is survived by his wife, Edith Lackey Sturm, his brother Wilbert Jack "Red" Sturm of Cut Bank, Montana, his sister Edith Virginia Sturm Greer of Fairbanks, Alaska, his daughter Marybeth Sturm Arnold and her husband Phillip Bruce Arnold of Sand Springs, Oklahoma, his daughter Barbara Edith Sturm Mayer and her husband Timothy David Mayer of Athens, Georgia, and his son Glenn Wesley Sturm of Atlanta, Georgia. Col Sturm is also survived by his eight grandchildren and his sixteen great-grandchildren. Col. Sturm is a member of Hamilton Mill United Methodist Church, Dacula, Georgia. Interment will be held at Ft. Benning National Cemetery (Main Post) on Tuesday, September 4, 2012 at 10:00am. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to: NIF/Col. Sturm Fund, National Infantry Foundation, Col. Sturm Memorial Fund, 1775 Legacy Way, Suite 220, Columbus, GA 31903.

KELMAN--Sylvia KELMAN, Sylvia, 91, died peacefully on September 1. Wife of Kurt, mother of Steve, Mark, and Ellen and seven grandchildren, she will be remembered for many things her intelligence, devotion to family and community, energy, and her Jewish cooking. Child of immigrants, she attended Hunter and worked for the War Department. After raising children and participating in political and social volunteer activities, she became a lawyer. Her children and grandchildren try to carry on her ideals. Funeral Wednesday, September 5, 9:30am Riverside North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck. Donations in Sylvia's memory may be made to Kol HaNeshama in Jerusalem, a reform synagogue representing her ideals of Israel as a light unto the nations: Kol HaNeshama, 85 Fourth Avenue, #

CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- Mother Nature is apparently bipartisan in her wrath. Just a week after upending the carefully planned schedule at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla., with a hurricane, she appears to have set her sights on the gathering of Democrats here, where President Obama is set to accept the nomination in an open-air stadium on Thursday -- with no umbrellas allowed.

The playwrights David Lindsay-Abaire and Naomi Wallace have been named the 2012 recipients of the Horton Foote Prize , a biennial award named for the playwright and screenwriter who died in 2009 at 92 . Mr. Lindsay-Abaire's "Good People" was chosen as the outstanding new American play, and "The Liquid Plain" by Ms. Wallace received the award for promising new American play. Each winner will receive $15,000 and a photograph of Mr. Foote. Set in South Boston, "Good People" centers around Margie, a woman who reexamines her life after reuniting with an old boyfriend. The show opened on Broadway last year in a production by the Manhattan Theater Club. Mr. Lindsay-Abaire received a Tony Award nomination for best play; the actress Frances McDormand won a Tony for playing Margie.

GEARNS--Mary Jane Mary Jane Gearns, 81, of Garden City, NY and Manhattan died at home on August 31, 2012. Born and raised in Sterling, IL, the youngest of six children of Leo and Verna Wahl, she received a B.A. from St. Mary's College and M.A. from the University of Notre Dame, becoming the first female layperson to receive a Notre Dame degree. Mary Jane taught English at Duquesne University until her marriage to William Gearns, with whom she had two children, Jack and Mary Gail. Mary Jane was a devoted mother, faithful friend, and amazing and loving grandmother with boundless energy and enthusiasm for life. She traveled with family and friends all over the world and delighted in taking each of her grandchildren on their own annual trips (no parents or siblings allowed!) to destinations of their choosing, including Kenya, Australia, New Zealand, the Galapagos Islands, and many other exciting destinations. Mary Jane served for more than 20 years as a Director of Wahl Clipper Corporation, the world's largest manufacturer of electric hair clippers, founded by her father in 1919. Mary Jane was a generous supporter of many charities, including Covenant House, where she volunteered for many years, and The Sharing Foundation, which cares for severely disadvantaged and orphaned children in Cambodia. The family is deeply indebted to her extraordinary caregivers, who kept her smiling and comfortable throughout her illness: Ann, Kathy, Marylynne, Maureen, and Kathleen. Mary Jane is survived by her children Jack (Carolyn) and Mary Gail (David Russo); grandchildren Christopher and Colleen Gearns, and Sarah and Matthew Russo; brother, Msgr. Raymond Wahl; and many nieces and nephews. Contributions in Mary Jane's memory may be made to The Sharing Foundation, Concord, MA (www.sharingfoundation.org) or Catholic Relief Services (www.crs.org). The family will receive visitors at Fairchild Sons, 1201 Franklin Ave., Garden City on September 7 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Joseph's Church in Garden City on September 8 at 9:30am.

GAUGHRAN--Edward, died August 30, 2012 after a brief illness, preceded by years of beating the odds. He was 85 years old. Beloved husband of Phyllis, father of Lisa and Laurie, grandfather of Althea, Adelaide and Silas, father-in-law of Brooks and Nick. Cherished uncle to his nieces and nephews. Trusted friend. Preceded by dear brother Bern. Attended Brooklyn Tech (1943), University of New Mexico (1949), NYU Ph.D. Clinical Psychology (1960). Former teaching and training faculty NYU and Westchester psychoanalytic institutes. Veteran US Navy and lifetime opponent of war. Eddy was a man of deep thought and big heart. A gifted psychoanalyst, committed Democrat, honest and gentle human being. He was unflinchingly himself, and in so being was greatly loved. Gathering of remembrance at the family home, Sunday, September 9, noon. Donations Barack Obama Campaign.

Venus Williams's latest United States Open ended Monday, and it seemed fair to wonder afterward how many more major tournaments she had left. Williams and her sister, Serena, fell to Maria Kirilenko and Nadia Petrova, a pair of Russians seeded fourth in women's doubles, 6-1, 6-4. The third-round match, moved from Arthur Ashe Stadium to Louis Armstrong because of weather, was more lopsided than expected.

Biggadike--E. Ralph, E. Ralph Biggadike, passed away peacefully August 17, 2012 with his wife Maylin and children Ella, Andrew, and Oliver by his side. A faculty member at Columbia Business School, Ralph taught catalytic organizational leadership and work team effectiveness in his award-winning courses. As faculty director of the General Management Leadership Program, Ralph reached thousands of students worldwide. Previously, Ralph served as VP of strategic management and group president for worldwide drug delivery systems at Becton Dickinson and was the Paul M. Hammaker Professor of Business Administration at the Darden School, University of Virginia. Ralph earned an MBA from the University of Virginia and a DBA from Harvard, where his thesis on corporate new ventures won the Richard D. Irwin Prize for Best Doctoral Dissertation. Early in his career, Ralph worked in advertising, marketing, and sales for British-American Industries, where he travelled the world, living in Malaysia and settling in the US. Born in 1937 in the UK and educated at the Wellingborough School, Ralph lived his life as a perpetual student. He was an actor as a young man and the dramatic arts inspired his teaching and how he engaged the world. He studied how people work together to elicit creativity, innovation, and leadership in life and in business. Ralph loved golf and especially links golf courses. He was a member of the Ridgewood Country Club and Royal Dornoch Golf Club in the highlands of Scotland, where a memorial bench was placed in his honor. Donations may be made in his name to the New Jersey State Golf Association Caddie Scholarship Foundation that provides financial support to caddies pursuing higher education at 1700 Galloping Hill Rd., Kenilworth, NJ 07033. A memorial service will be held at St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church on Fairmount Rd., Ridgewood, NJ on Saturday, September 8, at 2pm.

DAVID--Hal. To our beloved Eunice and family. Our whole family mourns the loss of our very dear friend, Hal David. He was an outstanding human being who was loved and respected by all who knew him. With Love, Bonnie & Bernie Hodes

Can people become better, more efficient runners on their own, merely by running? That question, seemingly so innocuous, is remarkably divisive at the moment, with running experts on one side suggesting that runners should be taught a specific, idealized running form, while opponents counter that the best way to run is whatever way feels right to you.

CHARLOTTE, N.C. - Politicians, delegates, lobbyists, journalists and protesters were gathering on Monday in Charlotte for the Democratic National Convention , which begins on Tuesday. They will find an Old South gold rush town that grew up to be a New South banking center with tall, shiny buildings, artsy statues and a few quirks -- from a statue believed to be modeled after Alan Greenspan 's face to the "Disco Chicken." Here's what visitors need to know to understand "the Q.C." (We'll explain what that is in a minute.)

COLLISON--Margaret Wei, of New York, New York, passed away on August 16th, 2012 at the age of 84. She was a devoted and beloved mother, grandmother, sister, aunt and friend. She is survived by her daughter, Serena Collison Williams, son-in-law Thomas A. Williams Jr., two grandsons, J. Hunter Williams and Charles Norwood Williams, brother Ted Wei and his wife Mary, sister Pauline Tsu and her husband John, and sister-in-law Stella Wei. Born May 16, 1928 in Shanghai, China to John and Margaret Wei, and attended the McTyeire School for girls and the Shanghai-American School. She immigrated to Hong Kong in 1947 during the Communist Revolution, and then to the United States after her marriage to William Norwood Collison in 1951. After retiring from Citigroup, she dedicated herself to volunteering at the Hospital for Special Surgery where she served over 5000 hours over 16 years, was Chair of the Library and was recognized with the Germaine B. Wilson Award for outstanding volunteer service to HSS. Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, September 8th at 2pm at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Contributions in Margaret's memory may be made to St. James Church or the Hospital for Special Surgery.

There has been no shortage of finger-pointing since the collapse of the law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, with most of the animus directed toward the firm's managing partner and its broader leadership. Now, an aggrieved former partner has taken aim at an unlikely target: Citibank .

An article on Saturday about Republican lawmakers and candidates who are distancing themselves from Representative Paul D. Ryan's budget plan misstated the age at which recipients would be affected by his Medicare proposal. It is for people currently under 55, not 55 or younger.

An employee with the New York City parks department was fatally stabbed on Tuesday near a recreation center in Queens after a fight with a fellow worker, the authorities said. The attack occurred in a lot behind the Al Oerter Recreation Center , on Fowler Avenue, in Flushing, about 3:15 p.m., the police said. The victim, Ezra Black, 31, of East 38th Street in Brooklyn, was stabbed in the chest, the police said.

Moore and her husband Nicholas J. Moore; and by his grandchildren Garret S. Batten, Herbert W. Moore, and Gardner M. Moore.

11:09 p.m. | Updated ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. - Alex Rodriguez could barely contain his glee Monday morning as he bounced through the visitors' clubhouse hugging some teammates, laughing with others, and even pounding one reporter on both shoulders with his fists.
Randall Irmis , curator of paleontology at the Natural History Museum of Utah and an assistant professor at the University of Utah , is investigating the rise of dinosaurs in southeastern Utah.

George L. Gunther, an iconoclastic Republican state senator from Connecticut who spent 40 years in office, making him the state's longest-serving member of the General Assembly, died on Sunday in Branford, Conn. He was 92 and lived in Stratford. The cause was cancer, his daughter Karla Gunther Mazzey said.

Induced abortions may raise the risk for very preterm birth in subsequent pregnancies, a new study reports. Researchers reviewed the records of 300,858 first-time mothers who had single babies in Finland from 1996 to 2008, comparing the data with a registry of induced abortions from 1983 to 2008. The analysis appeared online Wednesday in the journal Human Reproduction .

A change in fast-food restaurant ambience can affect the amount of food consumed by customers, an unusual study has found. Researchers decorated a section of a Hardee's restaurant in Champaign, Ill., with indirect lighting, soft music, white tablecloths, even candles on the tables. The room was soundproofed, isolated from the loud music and bright lights of the adjoining standard interior. Only one thing remained the same: the menu.

For two decades, Patricia DiGiusto struggled with severe asthma . Powerful medications and frequent use of her inhaler could not prevent repeated trips to the emergency room. On one particularly bad night, Ms. DiGiusto watched from her hospital bed as doctors and nurses prepared to insert plastic tubing down her windpipe to help her breathe. Gasping for air, she was certain she would not survive.

Six years ago, Todd McGee was a lean, athletic 34-year-old working in construction and living with his wife and toddler daughter on Martha's Vineyard, where he spent summer weekends surfing. A stroke changed his life forever. Today, with one arm useless and difficulty speaking, Mr. McGee, now 40, cannot work. He devotes most of his time to keeping as healthy as possible. Though he is able to drive and care for his daughter, now 7, everything takes longer, and he has trouble concentrating even on routine activities that others take in stride, like grocery shopping.

GERVAIS, Ore. -- This tiny farm-country community is having a back-to-school sale, on the schools themselves. Interested in a well maintained, one-owner elementary with playground and orchard view? Or a 1990s charmer, now used for teaching second through fifth grades but convenient to shopping and the Interstate? Like school districts all over the nation, Gervais, with about 1,100 students in a town of 2,300 people, has been deeply stressed by years of financial retrenchment. Music and art classes were eliminated last year. Teaching positions have been reduced through attrition and layoffs loom in years ahead, with state aid showing few signs of a robust comeback.

OTTAWA -- A speech by Pauline Marois, whose separatist Parti Québécois claimed a victory in a provincial election on Tuesday, was abruptly cut short when a man fired shots near an entrance to the hall where she was speaking, leaving one man dead and another in critical condition. Montreal police officials said that the shootings took place near a back door of the meeting hall. As Ms. Marois was stating her ''firm conviction that Quebec needs to become a sovereign country,'' she was pulled off the stage by two plainclothes officers.

MOSCOW -- Ramil Safarov stepped uncertainly off the plane in his native Azerbaijan last Friday, returning home after spending eight years in a Hungarian prison for a gruesome murder. But it took only a few minutes for the celebrations to begin. There was a pardon, a new apartment, eight years of back pay, a promotion to the rank of major and the status of a national hero. Mr. Safarov, 35, was already famous because of his crime. Eight years ago, carrying an ax, he crept into a dormitory room in Hungary where an Armenian serviceman, a fellow student in a NATO-sponsored English class, slept, and nearly decapitated him.

An article on Aug. 8 about Brazil's successful effort to raise its profile in Africa through an array of aid projects and loans described imprecisely the location of Angola, which has reached a new security agreement to train its military personnel in Brazil. Angola is on the west coast of southern Africa; it is not a West African nation.

PROWLER--Joan Zoob, born April 30, 1927 died peacefully in her sleep on August 26th. Although born in Brooklyn Joan grew up in Greenwood, SC and attended the University of South Carolina. After graduation she returned to New York and raised a family in Malverne while earning her Masters in Library Science from C.W. Post. She later served as Director of the Uniondale Public Library until her retirement. Throughout her life Joan treated those she met with a southern geniality and a New York sensibility. She was the loving and beloved wife of Robert Prowler, who died six weeks ago, and is survived by sons Gilbert (Mindy) and David (Simone), sister Lenore (Gerald) Harrison and grandchildren Brienna, Alyssa, and Joseph. Services will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 North Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, at 11am, Sunday, September 9th.

Biggadike--E. Ralph, E. Ralph Biggadike, passed away peacefully August 17, 2012 with his wife Maylin and children Ella, Andrew, and Oliver by his side. A faculty member at Columbia Business School, Ralph taught catalytic organizational leadership and work team effectiveness in his award-winning courses. As faculty director of the General Management Leadership Program, Ralph reached thousands of students worldwide. Previously, Ralph served as VP of strategic management and group president for worldwide drug delivery systems at Becton Dickinson and was the Paul M. Hammaker Professor of Business Administration at the Darden School, University of Virginia. Ralph earned an MBA from the University of Virginia and a DBA from Harvard, where his thesis on corporate new ventures won the Richard D. Irwin Prize for Best Doctoral Dissertation. Early in his career, Ralph worked in advertising, marketing, and sales for British-American Industries, where he travelled the world, living in Malaysia and settling in the US. Born in 1937 in the UK and educated at the Wellingborough School, Ralph lived his life as a perpetual student. He was an actor as a young man and the dramatic arts inspired his teaching and how he engaged the world. He studied how people work together to elicit creativity, innovation, and leadership in life and in business. Ralph loved golf and especially links golf courses. He was a member of the Ridgewood Country Club and Royal Dornoch Golf Club in the highlands of Scotland, where a memorial bench was placed in his honor. Donations may be made in his name to the New Jersey State Golf Association Caddie Scholarship Foundation that provides financial support to caddies pursuing higher education at 1700 Galloping Hill Rd., Kenilworth, NJ 07033. A memorial service will be held at St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church on Fairmount Rd., Ridgewood, NJ on Saturday, September 8, at 2pm.

The stage adaptation of "Flashdance," based on the 1983 movie about a female welder-dancer, will begin performances on Broadway in Aug. 2013, the show's producers announced on Tuesday. A theater, dates and casting are still to be announced. A Broadway run of "Flashdance" has been in the works for several years. Following a 2010 London production, a group of veteran theater producers announced last year that the show would come to Broadway in the fall of 2012. In May, however, the producer Marc Routh said the show would be pushed to spring 2013 , citing a lack of available Broadway theaters this fall, and to give time for more work to be done on the show.

8:00 p.m. | Updated Hackers released a file that they said contained a million identification numbers for Apple mobile devices, claiming that they had obtained it by hacking into the computer of an F.B.I. agent. The F.B.I. said it had no evidence that this was true. The hacking group, known as AntiSec - a subset of the loose hacking collective known as Anonymous - posted copies of the file on Sunday and claimed to have a total of 12 million numbers for iPhone , iPad and iPod Touch devices, along with some phone numbers and other personal data on their owners. They said their goal in releasing a slice of the data was to prove that the F.B.I. used device information to track people.

LUCKER--Jay K. February 23, 1930 - September 2, 2012. Survived by his daughters Amy and Nancy, son-in-law Joshua, grandson Benjamin, and sister Gloria. Predeceased by his wife Marjorie Stern, whom he met while they both attended Brooklyn College. Jay was a leader in the library world, having last served as Director of Libraries at MIT, before his retirement in 1995. Prior to MIT, he was at the Princeton University Libraries after starting his career at the New York Public Library on 42nd Street. He received his MLS from Columbia University in 1952. Throughout his career he was active as a library building and planning consultant, continuing to work up to the present. He was widely loved and admired, and will be greatly missed.

A person briefed on the matter said the deal was worth about $370 million, more than double it sale price in 2007. BEN PROTESS

Target Margin Theater , the alternative New York theater company known for its frisky interpretations of plays ranging from Shakespeare to Brecht, is turning its attention to Yiddish theater. The company has announced a two-season exploration of Yiddish theater called Beyond the Pale, which begins with a festival of plays, readings, a scholarly panel and a concert of Yiddish music, to be held Oct. 17 through Nov. 3 at The Brick in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The festival, all in English, will present four fully staged plays including "God, Man, and Devil," the circa 1900 play by Jacob Gordin, an influential Yiddish dramatist. In March, Target Margin will present a reworked drama from the Yiddish canon at the Abrons Art Center at the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Other productions, workshops and concerts are also planned. "As I have learned about Yiddish theater in the last couple of years I've come to appreciate the range and sophistication of Yiddish theater and I want people to realize what is out there," David Herskovits, artistic director of Target Margin said Tuesday. "The festival is the kickoff for big productions, little productions, readings and short presentations." A dozen Yiddish theaters thrived in New York City in the early 20th century.

DUHL--Doris, (nee Becker), age 88. Born in the Bronx, raised her family in Malverne, taught in Valley Stream, retired to Florida. Pre-deceased by her husband, Arthur. Survived by her children, Joanne and Steven, and her grandchildren: Joshua, Caitlin, Samuel, and Aryanna.

ZIELONY--Stanley (Shalom). The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express great sorrow at the loss of Stanley (Shalom) Zielony. A resident of Garden City, NY, he was a legendary supporter of the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology. Mr. Zielony worked to strengthen Israel by building its scientific and technological strength. In 2003, he received a Technion Honorary Doctorate in profound gratitude for his outstanding support, which transformed the face of the Technion campus, improved student life, and helped spur academic progress. His gifts included facilities in the Maydan Center for Advanced Materials Studies; the Distinguished Women in Science Lecture Series; and the Technion Symphony Orchestra and Choir. Together with the late Henry Taub, he initiated the Leaders in Science and Technology program, which has helped bring many outstanding new faculty members to the Technion. His generosity also led to a renewed Student Union Building; unprecedented Graduate Student Village housing; the Shalom Zielony Plaza; and extensive renovations to the Ullman Teaching Center. We extend our sympathies to his daughter Tamara, and the entire Zielony family. American Technion Society Joel S. Rothman, President Joan Seidel, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

Fans with tickets from Tuesday's night session that was suspended because of rain have several options for rain checks under the United States Open cancellation policy. They can exchange tickets from Tuesday night for the same session at next year's United States Open or for the day sessions on Thursday or Friday. Tuesday's tickets can also be exchanged for a separate ticketed day session at Louis Armstrong on Wednesday. Matches on Wednesday afternoon at Armstrong include the quarterfinal between Italy's Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci, the conclusion of the fourth-round match between Novak Djokovic and Stanislas Wawrinka and the quarterfinal doubles match between Mike and Bob Bryan and Julien Benneteau and Nicolas Mahut.

SAN FRANCISCO -- ''Stay focused and keep shipping'' may be the motto Facebook has sought to follow since its flubbed public offering three months ago. But on Tuesday, the company seemed focused mostly on how to stabilize its hemorrhaging stock. It announced what amounted to a repurchase of several million shares; said its largest shareholder and chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg , would not sell his shares or options for at least another year; and moved up when some employees could start selling their shares.

CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- It may have been a bit early for goofy-Hollywood-guest night, and the guest was about five decades too young. But Kal Penn reported for duty on Tuesday, armed with a pitch for young voters. ''I am honored to accept your nomination for president of the United States,'' said Mr. Penn, an actor who worked in the White House and is a surrogate for the president when he is not playing a charming slacker in the ''Harold & Kumar'' movies.

Edward Villella, the ousted patriarch of the Miami City Ballet, is making an early exit from the stage. Under the hawklike gaze of lawyers, the company and Mr. Villella said on Tuesday that he would leave as artistic director immediately instead of next April. Mr. Villella, 75, a magnetic star of New York City Ballet under George Balanchine, said he had cleaned out his office over the weekend and would return to New York next week with his wife to house hunt.
ABRAMS--John Bryden. To Jan, Stefan, Cleo, Brian, Roy, Evelyn and entire family, we send our love and deep sympathy on the loss of your sweet and loving son Jed. The Sosnow Family.

Kurt Maetzig, a pioneering East German director whose socialist films scrutinized anti-Semitism, explored corporate complicity in the rise of fascism and helped compel Germans to come to terms with their Nazi past, died on Aug. 8 at his home in Germany. He was 101. German news organizations, quoting a family member, said he had died in the village of Wildkuhl in the former East German state of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, where he had lived for many years.

Elovich--Fanny (Berglass), passed away on September 2, 2012 shortly before her 101st birthday. She was born on September 11, 1911 in New York City to Samuel and Sarah Berglass. She graduated from Washington Irving High School where she excelled in public speaking and later attended Baruch College. In 1933 she married Solomon Elovich who died in 1997. For over twenty years she was an administrator in the New York City Health Department until her retirement in 1973. Fanny is survived by her children Larry Elovich and Eleanor Glanstein, their spouses Helen Elovich and Joel Glanstein, her sister Ellen Permut, five grandchildren Lisa Elovich, Lauree Vasta, David Glanstein, Stacey Epstein, and Lynn Eisenberg, and ten great grandchildren. Fanny was an inspiration to all who knew her and she will be greatly missed. Services will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 115 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY at 10:00am on Thursday, September 6, 2012.

DAVID--Hal. To our beloved Eunice and family. Our whole family mourns the loss of our very dear friend, Hal David. He was an outstanding human being who was loved and respected by all who knew him. With Love, Bonnie & Bernie Hodes

SLEVIN--Harvey, on September 3rd at age 96. Beloved husband of Naomi, loving father of Jeff (Debbie), Barry (Lynne), Ken (Jane), cherished grandfather of Bailie, Matt (Dara), Ted (Marlo), Sam, Jeremy, Mickey and Julie. Funeral service on Thursday, September 6th, 1pm, Plaza Funeral Chapel 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91st St. Burial at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

The Rolling Stones will release two new original songs when they put out a greatest hits record in November, Mojo magazine reported on Tuesday. The two songs - entitled "Gloom and Doom" and "One Last Shot" - were recorded in Paris last month and will appear on a three-CD set of the band's hits, "GRRR!," which is set to be released on Nov. 13. The songs will be the first new material the Stones have generated since the recording sessions for their 2005 album "A Bigger Bang," Billboard reported. The band has several projects in the works to mark their 50th anniversary. (Their first show was at Marquee Club in London in July 1962.) Besides "GRRR!," the Stones will also release in mid-November "Crossfire Hurricane," a documentary movie about their early years.

When the DC universe of superheroes was reintroduced last year one of the commitments from the company was diversity. Cyborg, a black hero, was promoted to the Justice League; Bunker, a new Teen Titan, is Mexican and gay; and female or minority-group characters were the headliners in many series. DC is continuing that push with the introduction of Simon Baz, an Arab-American from Michigan, who finds himself wearing a Green Lantern power ring. His story unfolds in issue No. 0 of "Green Lantern," which is part of a monthlong zero-issue event from DC Comics, that promises to shed light on the new back stories of its heroes. "Green Lantern" is written by Geoff Johns, who drew upon his own Lebanese ancestry and Michigan roots for the character. "This is such a personal story," Mr. Johns told The Associated Press.

The hedge fund industry has been rushing headlong to open Bermuda-based reinsurers. Reinsurance, already something of a murky business, may become even more complicated as a result. And while the hedge funds are likely to profit, the question is: Who's watching to make sure this doesn't lead to another financial calamity?

GEARNS--Mary Jane Mary Jane Gearns, 81, of Garden City, NY and Manhattan died at home on August 31, 2012. Born and raised in Sterling, IL, the youngest of six children of Leo and Verna Wahl, she received a B.A. from St. Mary's College and M.A. from the University of Notre Dame, becoming the first female layperson to receive a Notre Dame degree. Mary Jane taught English at Duquesne University until her marriage to William Gearns, with whom she had two children, Jack and Mary Gail. Mary Jane was a devoted mother, faithful friend, and amazing and loving grandmother with boundless energy and enthusiasm for life. She traveled with family and friends all over the world and delighted in taking each of her grandchildren on their own annual trips (no parents or siblings allowed!) to destinations of their choosing, including Kenya, Australia, New Zealand, the Galapagos Islands, and many other exciting destinations. Mary Jane served for more than 20 years as a Director of Wahl Clipper Corporation, the world's largest manufacturer of electric hair clippers, founded by her father in 1919. Mary Jane was a generous supporter of many charities, including Covenant House, where she volunteered for many years, and The Sharing Foundation, which cares for severely disadvantaged and orphaned children in Cambodia. The family is deeply indebted to her extraordinary caregivers, who kept her smiling and comfortable throughout her illness: Ann, Kathy, Marylynne, Maureen, and Kathleen. Mary Jane is survived by her children Jack (Carolyn) and Mary Gail (David Russo); grandchildren Christopher and Colleen Gearns, and Sarah and Matthew Russo; brother, Msgr. Raymond Wahl; and many nieces and nephews. Contributions in Mary Jane's memory may be made to The Sharing Foundation, Concord, MA (www.sharingfoundation.org) or Catholic Relief Services (www.crs.org). The family will receive visitors at Fairchild Sons, 1201 Franklin Ave., Garden City on September 7 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Joseph's Church in Garden City on September 8 at 9:30am.

Long the retail stepsister of upper Fifth Avenue, the stretch of the avenue south of 49th Street and north of 42nd Street seems finally to be coming into its own with the opening of several flagship stores by retailers from around the world. The list includes Joe Fresh and Aritzia, two Canadian fashion retailers; Ted Baker London; Tommy Bahama; and an expanded Lacoste. H&M, the Swedish fast-fashion retailer, also announced last month that it planned to open its largest store in the world, a 57,000-square-foot outlet at 48th Street and Fifth Avenue, next fall.

The DealBook column on Tuesday, about the role that David Ebersman, Facebook's chief financial officer, played in the company's initial public offering, misstated the price range for that offering. It was $28 to $35, not $29 to $34. The column also misstated Mr. Ebersman's age. He is 42, not 41.

KALISH--Arthur. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death of our former partner, current Of Counsel, friend and colleague, Arthur Kalish. We express our deepest sympathies to all members of the family.

CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- Former President Bill Clinton tried to rebut Republican arguments against the re-election of President Obama in a major speech at the Democratic National Convention Wednesday night, saying Mr. Obama has taken steps to turn around an economy left in shambles by Republicans. ''In Tampa, the Republican argument against the president's re-election was pretty simple: We left him a total mess, he hasn't finished cleaning it up yet, so fire him and put us back in,'' Mr. Clinton said.

FARBER--Elsie R. Pre-deceased by her husband Irving. Survived by her children Jon, Adam and Jill. Daughters-in-law Michaela and Jean. Son-in-law Philip. Grandchildren Matthew, Kate, Steve and Wesley. She kept on keeping on and we will miss her. Donations in her memory can be sent to Meals on Wheels, either in NYC or locally.

KALISH--Arthur. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System are greatly saddened by the death of Trustee Arthur Kalish, beloved husband of the late Janet Wiener Kalish. A long-time benefactor of LIJ Medical Center, Arthur was committed to LIJ's growth and development. His outstanding generosity over the years enabled LIJ to become a medical institution of the highest caliber, offering quality medical care to improve the health of the community. A valued member of the board of trustees, Arthur was the former chair of the board's audit committee. His dedication, passion and service made him a true partner who helped shape North Shore-LIJ's growth and advance patient care. We extend our heartfelt condolences to daughter Pamela and her husband Paul Chader, son Philip Kalish and his wife Nancy, and grandchildren Stephen, David and Michael Chader. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 6. Contributions may be made to the North Shore-LIJ Health System Foundation, 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021. Richard Goldstein, Chairman Michael Dowling, Pres. & CEO North Shore-LIJ Health System

An art review on Friday about ''Robert Adams: The Place We Live, a Retrospective Selection of Photographs'' at the Yale University Art Gallery, misidentified the subject of the photograph ''Sally, Weld County, Colorado.'' Sally is a dog, not a cat. The review also referred incompletely to an introductory statement by Mr. Adams about the series ''Our Parents, Our Children.'' It is in the exhibition's catalog and in an online feature; it is not in the exhibition itself.

Virgil Goode, the presidential nominee for the conservative Constitution Party, qualified for Virginia's ballot on Tuesday, complicating Mitt Romney's chances of winning the swing state. Polls show a tightly contested race there between Mr. Romney and President Obama. The Virginia State Board of Elections announced on Tuesday that Mr. Goode's name would appear third on the ballot, after the Republican and Democratic presidential nominees.

ABRAMS--Jed. The East Hampton Tennis Club morns the passing and great loss of Jed Abrams. Our deepest sympathies, thoughts and prayers are with Jan and Stefan and their family. Joe Eisler, President East Hampton Tennis Club

In tennis terms, Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci might be called frenemies. They are buddies off the court and doubles partners on the court, and on Tuesday, they teamed up to win their quarterfinals match in straight sets. But come Wednesday, they will also play each other in the quarterfinals of the singles tournament. The about face for the Italian pair is jarring, but one they are taking in stride.

Fuse, the music-themed cable channel that mixes videos and documentaries with offbeat fare like the comedy game show "Funny or Die's Billy on the Street," is increasing its commitment to music journalism. On Tuesday it said that it was creating a dedicated news division and introducing a daily news show whose hosts may be familiar to viewers of its sometime rival MTV. The show, called "Fuse News," will be broadcast live, Monday through Friday, from the channel's studio on Seventh Avenue in Manhattan (near the home of Fuse's corporate parent, the Madison Square Garden Company).
COHEN--Sidney J. 9/5/25 - 11/24/10 You will be loved and missed forever.

LOS ANGELES -- Environmentalists in this greenest of places call the California Environmental Quality Act the state's most powerful environmental protection, a model for the nation credited with preserving lush wetlands and keeping condominiums off the slopes of the Sierra Nevada. But the landmark law passed in 1970 has also been increasingly abused, opening the door to lawsuits -- sometimes brought by business competitors or for reasons unrelated to the environment -- that, regardless of their merit, can delay even green development projects for years or sometimes kill them completely.

FOKINE--Gloria, (nee Negreira). Cuban born Gloria Fokine died Monday, September 3, 2012 after a long illness. As a ballerina, teacher and archivist of ballet history, she will be remembered by her students, colleagues and friends. Donations in her memory can be made to The Alzheimer's Association. A memorial will be held at a future date.
GORMAN--Cliff. Oct. 13, 1936 --Sept. 5, 2002 TO YOU MY LOVE I GIVE MY HEART. GAYLE

Mitt Romney and the Republican National Committee raised about $100 million in August, a person briefed on the total said on Tuesday. It was the Republicans' third nine-figure month in a row, putting Mr. Romney on pace to be one of the most successful Republican fund-raisers in history. Most of the money, raised in a series of joint party fund-raisers, will flow to the national committee and other party committees participating in the effort, which can accept far larger checks from individuals than Mr. Romney's campaign can.

A music review on Friday about a performance by the band Zs at 285 Kent in Brooklyn, using information from a representative of the band's record label, misidentified the long song it played. It is ''Xe,'' not ''Grain.''

HUNT--Peter Sanford, (78), of Alexandria, VA died peacefully at home on September 2, 2012 surrounded by his family. He lives on in the hearts of his loving wife of 49 years, Joan, his children, Tori, Doug, and Margie, and his six grandchildren. An avid sailor and committed environmentalist, he worked to make awareness of Low Energy Nuclear Reaction (Cold Fusion) - the safe power source of his grandchildren's future.

JAFFE--Bernard, Jr. (Buster) born August 26, 1930 died peacefully in his sleep at age 82 in Boca Raton, Florida. Ben is survived by his beloved children Brenda and Anthony, his half sister Betty Newman and his two grandchildren Georgia and Nicholas Jaffe. For those of us who knew Buster well, knew his lust for life was intoxicating. Handsome, witty, charming and generous he lived his life like it was not a dress rehearsal and took great pleasure in his adventures. Getting into college at Cornell and deciding to leave the first week to transfer and graduate from Syracuse exemplified his spontaneity to a tee. After serving in the Korean War as a Second Lieutenant in the Air Force, the debonair young man started his long career on Wall Street working for Loeb Rhoades and ending at Smith Barney. Residing both in New York City and Palm Beach, Ben treasured his friends and family, traveling and his long standing relationship with all his favorite restaurants and bars. He lived by the motto, "The best is yet to come." He would want us to remember that and have no regrets. A man who danced to his own drum, his spirit and passion for life will continue to live through his friends and family. We love you Dad.

McCORMACK--Bernard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Bernard McCormack associated with The New York Times from June 1, 1975 until retiring on May 31, 1996.

6:30 P.M. (SNY) JETS NATION: CURTIS MARTIN HALL OF FAME SPECIAL This hourlong program follows Curtis Martin, a former running back for the New York Jets and the New England Patriots, during the week leading up to his induction last month into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio. ''I began to look at football as my basic training or my sacrifice that I had to make to do what I really wanted to do, which was reach people,'' Mr. Martin says, admitting that he ''didn't want to play football, didn't like playing football, had to train my mind to enjoy it while I was in the N.F.L.'' Highlights include glimpses of the parade route on the morning of Mr. Martin's enshrinement as well as a discussion of his relationship with the coach Bill Parcells (above right, with Mr. Martin). 10:30 A.M. (HBO) JANE EYRE (2011) Mia Wasikowska portrays Charlotte Brontë's beleaguered governess, in desperate flight from her employer and soul mate, Edward Rochester (Michael Fassbender), in this adaptation of the 1847 novel, set at Thorndike Hall on the wild and misty moors of England. Jamie Bell is St. John Rivers, the young clergyman who helps to nurse Jane back to health; Judi Dench, the gossipy housekeeper; Sally Hawkins, the nasty aunt; and Imogen Poots, the pretty rich girl who almost derails Jane's chances in love. ''Reader, I liked it,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''This 'Jane Eyre,' energetically directed by Cary Joji Fukunaga ('Sin Nombre') from a smart, trim script by Moira Buffini ('Tamara Drewe'), is a splendid example of how to tackle the daunting duty of turning a beloved work of classic literature into a movie. Neither a radical updating nor a stiff exercise in middlebrow cultural respectability, Mr. Fukunaga's film tells its venerable tale with lively vigor and an astute sense of emotional detail.''

CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- On Wednesday night, one former Democratic president, Bill Clinton, will appear before the convention here in a live prime-time speech, an event that is being billed as second in importance only to President Obama's speech itself. But there is another living Democratic president: Jimmy Carter. And he was given a role with a decidedly lower profile in this convention.

KLEGER--David S.,age 72, died peacefully at home on September 1, 2012. Born in Cleveland, Ohio to Fannie and Joseph Kleger, David was the devoted and beloved husband of Eve for 43 years; adored father of Alison, Mark, and Laura and father-in-law of Scott, Dorsey, and Justin; loving grandfather of Garrett, Cordelia, Max, Brayley, Jackson, and an expected grandson; dedicated brother of Barbara; cherished family friend of Susan, Jenny, Iam, and Logan; and dear friend and mentor to many. His earnest enthusiasm for life, his love for family and friends, and his kind generosity will be sorely missed. David received a BS from Cornell University School of Engineering and an MBA from Harvard University. He had been the founder and President of Kellogg Properties Inc. of NYC since 1977. David also served on several school and non-profit boards to support his commitment to expanding education and social services. A memorial service will be held at Frank Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue on September 10, at 5pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in his name to either The Kleger Family Cornell Tradition Scholarship, attn: June Losurdo, Cornell University, 259 Carpenter Hall, Ithaca, NY 14853 or The Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services at 135 W. 50 St, NYC 10020.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- More than 100,000 Syrians fled their country last month, a sharp acceleration of the exodus prompted by 18 months of conflict, the United Nations said Tuesday, adding renewed urgency to the mission of a new peace envoy given dim prospects for success. The refugee flood coincided with a marked increase in the carnage in Syria , as President Bashar al-Assad 's government unleashed its air force against towns and neighborhoods across the country where his opponents have found support. The resulting surge of displaced people, mainly in the last two weeks of August, accounted for more than 40 percent of the 234,000 refugees who have registered for United Nations support since the fighting began.

To anyone who has ever complained about a closet-size New York City galley kitchen, consider the 60-square-foot space at Battersby, the restaurant of the moment on Smith Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Joe Ogrodnek and Walker Stern, the chefs and owners, turn out up to 200 covers a busy night from this tiny kitchen. At Alain Ducasse at Essex House, where the two worked together, ''the garde-manger station alone was almost the size of this entire restaurant,'' Mr. Ogrodnek said. ''It was luxurious. But, it turns out you really don't need much space to do what you want to do.'' Here, see how three chefs navigate their cozy professional home. SOPHIE BRICKMAN

CASSANO--Alfred J.,65, passed away September 4. Wake September 6 and 7, 2pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm, at James Romanelli, 8901 Rockaway Boulevard, Ozone Park.
