President Obama’s acceptance speech on Thursday was the cautious declaration of a chastened husband who has been to couples counseling.
Rescue teams searched the waters off a southern Italian islet for survivors of a boat that ran into trouble a day earlier while crossing from Africa.
Rimsha Masih has been detained in a high-security prison since mid-August, when Muslim neighbors accused her of burning a textbook used to teach the Koran to children.
A series of earthquakes in southwest China shook two rural provinces populated by some of the country’s poorest people, damaging 20,000 homes, an official said.
No player has tormented the Mets more than Chipper Jones, who is playing his last season and has some surprisingly warm feelings for New York and for Mets fans.
The pop stars were among a handful of winners on Thursday night at the MTV Video Music Awards, which handed out just six awards in two hours.

7:30 P.M. (HBO) EXTREMELY LOUD & INCREDIBLY CLOSE (2011) Oskar Schell (Thomas Horn), an 11-year-old New Yorker whose father (Tom Hanks) died in the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center, traverses the five boroughs in search of the owner of a key in an envelope scrawled with a single word -- ''Black'' -- that he believes will unlock the answer to what happened on ''the worst day.'' Sandra Bullock, above with Mr. Horn, plays Oskar's grieving mother, who seems oblivious to his travels; Viola Davis and Jeffrey Wright are the first of the 472 Blacks whose names Oskar has culled from city phone books; and Max von Sydow is the mysterious man who becomes Oskar's sidekick. ''The performances, including from the reliably appealing Mr. Hanks and Ms. Bullock, are smoothed of any roughness, which can be chalked up to the fact that most of the story is seen through Oskar's eyes,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''Mr. Horn, who was 13 when the movie was made, is an attractively real-looking boy, with an impish smile and a natural-feeling directness, and he holds his own just fine, even against a scene-stealer like Mr. von Sydow.'' But, she added: ''It's an impossible role in an impossible movie that has no reason for being other than as another pop-culture palliative for a trauma it can't bear to face. In truth, 'Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close' isn't about Sept. 11. It's about the impulse to drain that day of its specificity and turn it into yet another wellspring of generic emotions: sadness, loneliness, happiness.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY This newsmagazine kicks off its 16th season with a report by Kim Lawton from the Democratic National Convention about the issues liberal religious leaders face, and how President Obama's stance on gay marriage has affected his support among some religious groups. Also, Bob Faw interviews Ron Hansen, an author and Roman Catholic deacon.

The artist Shepard Fairey, whose 2008 poster of Barack Obama became an optimistic symbol of the last presidential campaign before spawning a bitter copyright battle with criminal overtones, was sentenced in federal court in Manhattan on Friday to two years of probation and fined $25,000 for tampering with evidence in the case. Government prosecutors had argued that Mr. Fairey should serve time for his actions and he faced up to six months in prison. In February he pleaded guilty to a criminal contempt charge after admitting that he had destroyed documents and fabricated others to try to conceal the fact that he had used a particular Associated Press photograph of Mr. Obama as the source of his well-known "Hope" campaign poster.

An article this weekend on Page 102 about the American intellectual Gene Sharp refers incorrectly to his work on a master's degree. He received his master's at Ohio State University in 1951; he was not working on his master's thesis in New York in 1953. And because of an editing error, the article also misstates, at one point, part of the name of nonprofit organization he founded. As the article correctly notes elsewhere, it is the Albert Einstein Institution, not Alfred Einstein Institution.

The About New York column on Friday about stolen motorcycles recovered by the police, then stolen again, misstated, in some copies, the number of suspects charged as part of the original ring that was broken up. It was 33, not 31.

BROOKLINE, Mass. - Days after Joseph P. Kennedy III stood in front of the Democratic National Convention to offer a tribute to his great-uncle, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, he found himself on a smaller platform just outside Boston, shaking hands with commuters at a public transit station here on the first day of his general election campaign in the Fourth Congressional District of Massachusetts. Mr. Kennedy, 31, handily won his primary election Thursday, taking 90 percent of the vote in a contest with two relatively unknown rivals, Rachel Brown and Herb Robinson, and once again keeping the Kennedy name prominent in Massachusetts politics.

Every fall, Columbia Law School admits a couple hundred students to its prestigious master's program. This year's crop includes a civil rights activist from Armenia, a terrorism-finance expert from Bangladesh and a Croatian lawyer with a win over Roger Federer. Had things worked out differently, Mario Ancic, the Croatian lawyer, would have spent the past two weeks grinding it out on the hardcourts at the United States Open. Instead, he has been holed up in the Columbia law library, poring over his contracts casebook.

SCHERR--Lawrence, MD, 83 of New York, passed away on September 6, after a noble fight. Born in Brooklyn, NY on November 6, 1928 to Harry and Sophie Schwartz, Dr. Scherr graduated from Brooklyn technical high school and Cornell University, and proudly served in the United States Navy in active combat in Korea as an officer in the United States Navy Amphibious Force. Dr. Scherr received his MD from Cornell university medical college in 1957. from 1967 to 2001, he was David J. Greene Chairman, Department of Medicine, North Shore University Hospital and Professor of Medicine, Cornell University Medical College and New York University School of Medicine. He was Professor Emeritus of Medicine, Weill Medical College of Cornell University. Dr. Scherr was Chairman of the New York State Board for Medicine and Chairman of the New York State Council on Graduate Medical Education. He served with President Clinton's white house review group on health care reform as well as numerous other committees nationally. Dr. Scherr is survived by his beloved and devoted wife Peggy of 58 years; daughter Cynthia Rosen (Alan) and son Robert; grandchildren Sabrina; Benjamin; Natalie; and Sophie. Funeral services will be held Sunday, September 9th at 2:00pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the North Shore-LIJ Health System Foundation.

SIEGEL--Clara, died September 6, 2012 at the age of 102 and one day, peacefully in her sleep at her home in Manhattan. Born on the Lower East Side, she lived The American Dream. Motherless at 16, she worked her way through Beth Israel Hospital School of Nursing. Happily married to Sam Siegel for 59 years until 1993, she lived 71 years in Manhattan and 31 years in Brooklyn. Beloved matriarch of her family and mother of Roberta Valins (Martin), William (Colette) and Richard (Beverly). She leaves nine devoted grandchildren and 23 great-grandchildren literally from coast to coast and in between. Services at Gutterman's, Woodbury, Sunday at noon. Shiva at Roberta Valins' home, Sunday - Tuesday.

A film review on Friday about ''Keep the Lights On'' misspelled, in some editions, the surname of the actor who plays Erik. As the listing of credits and a picture caption with the review correctly noted, he is Thure Lindhardt, not Lindhart.

An article in some editions on Thursday about an impasse between the Hunts Point Produce Market and the city, part of the negotiations in keeping the cooperative in the Bronx, misidentified the location in the Bronx where FreshDirect, another business that had threatened to leave New York for New Jersey, was promised it could build. It is the Harlem Rail Yards, adjacent to the Mott Haven and Port Morris neighborhoods -- not ''at Hunts Point.'' (The site is west of Hunts Point.)

SHELTON--Peter Laros. Peter will be forever missed and remembered as a loving Father, devoted Husband, Partner, Mentor and a key Driver of the Creative Force that is Shelton, Mindel & Associates. Peter did everything you couldn't see because his humble nature kept him behind the scenes. Peter was a visionary architect who invented the seemingly inevitable. He had a creative mind that always strived for perfection. Whenever we look at anything, are posed with a problem or asked for a solution we quietly reflect ... what would Peter think? He was extremely private and chose to keep his courageous and dignified battle with cancer just that. Peter and partner, Lee Mindel received the Cooper Hewitt Smithsonian National Design award from the First Lady, Michelle Obama, at the White House. The night before the event, he expressed to Lee, that although he had a hard time believing in religion he would never lose his faith in the value of the creative. We at SMA are deeply saddened by our loss but embrace moving forward with his inspiration and how he taught us all to challenge and resolve. We console and send our love to his devoted wife Laura Bennett Shelton and his beloved six children Cleo Bennett, Peik, Truman, Pierson, Larson and Finn Shelton. There will be a tribute held in his honor at the Seagram Building, Four Seasons Restaurant located at 99 East 52nd Street on Tuesday, September 11th 2012 between the hours of 4pm and 6pm. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to: The RK Laros Foundation, Elizabeth Mowrer, Executive Director, 4513 Virginia Drive, Bethlehem, PA 18017. 610-867-8452.

Prepaid cards can be a better deal than checking accounts for some people, but the cards need more consumer safeguards, a new report from the Pew Charitable Trusts finds. Along with the report, " Loaded with Uncertainty ," Pew introduced an online tool to help consumers determine which option is best for them.

An article on Friday about a tentative deal by Japan to buy three uninhabited islands that are part of a chain at the center of a heated territorial dispute with China misstated, in some editions, the year the United States, which seized the islands in World War II , returned them, along with Okinawa, to the Japanese. It was 1972, not 1971.

"The Saints are going to win it all, baby," Pat Bode, the proprietor of Mugz's Bar in the New Orleans suburb of Metairie, her excited eyes wide with unwavering certainty, proclaimed to me on a recent evening. "I got a lot of faith in that." A veteran of nine marriages who celebrated her 79th birthday last month with a raucous theme party at her bar, Miss Pat, as Mugz's regulars like the former Saints defensive lineman Derland Moore have affectionately come to know Bode, shifts effortlessly between serving as her bar's resident den mother and its own version of Joan Rivers. She occasionally shares unspeakably filthy jokes with patrons as they dine on the complimentary food she lovingly prepares for them in her living quarters, which are situated in the back of the bar she opened 40 years ago - partly with money she earned during her years working as a dancer in Bourbon Street gentlemen's clubs.

Mrs Thaw was known for her brilliant dinners for world renowned figures of the charitable, cultural and political spheres. She will be greatly missed. Lawrence Lovett, Founding Chairman Gary Parr, Chairman Mrs. Donald K. Miller, Vice Chairman Pierre Durand, President

Cate Blanchett will bid farewell to her role as co-artistic director of Sydney Theater Company by starring with Isabelle Huppert in a new production of "The Maids" as part of the company's 2013 season, it was announced on Thursday. The Jean Genet play, about a pair of house servants with murderous designs on their employer, will be directed by Benedict Andrews , who previously directed Ms. Blanchett in "Gross und Klein (Big and Small)" and "The War of the Roses" for Sydney Theater Company. Its new translation is by Mr. Andrews and Andrew Upton, Ms. Blanchett's husband and co-artistic director. At the start of the year Ms. Blanchett and Mr. Upton said they would step down from their posts at Sydney Theater Company, after presenting several internationally acclaimed productions including "A Streetcar Named Desire" (which starred Ms. Blanchett as Blanche DuBois) and "Uncle Vanya" (which featured her as Yelena). But last month the theater company said it had appointed Mr. Upton to stay on alone in a new term that begins next year. Other productions that were announced as part of the company's 2013 season include revivals of "Waiting for Godot" starring Hugo Weaving and Richard Roxburgh (who both appeared in "Uncle Vanya") and directed by Tamas Ascher (who also directed "Vanya"); and "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead" starring Tim Minchin, the musician and comedian, and Toby Schmitz. The season will begin in January with a stage adaptation of Kate Grenville's novel "The Secret River."

Epiphanny Prince scored 30 points to lead the Chicago Sky to a 92-83 win over the Liberty in Newark. Chicago moved a half game past the Liberty for the fourth and final playoff spot in the East. Cappie Pondexter scored 24 points on 7-for-19 shooting to lead the Liberty (11-17). (AP)

It's not quite "Mad Men Missouri," but a little drama is playing out in a dispute between a beleaguered Senate candidate and a television ad department in the state. The candidate is Representative Todd Akin , a Republican who is on the defensive for remarks he made in his campaign against Senator Claire McCaskill, a Democrat. The television station is KOMU-8, an NBC affiliate in Colombia, Mo., that reported that it had pulled Mr. Akin's ads midway through its intended run because of an unpaid bill.

STACKS--John F.,veteran Time magazine journalist and author, passed away September 4 in New York City of complications from prostate cancer. He leaves his wife Carol, a son Ben and his wife Kim, a stepdaughter, Dr. Nicole Ruane and her husband Andrew Powell, and three grandchildren, Hannah, Kate and Frank. After graduation from Yale in 1964, he reported for the Washington Evening Star before joining Time in its Washington bureau. He took a brief leave of absence in 1968 to work as Sen. George McGovern's press secretary before returning to Time, where he oversaw the magazine's coverage of Watergate, served as National Political Correspondent during the 1980 presidential campaign and served as bureau chief in both Boston and New York. He later worked in a variety of editorial management positions, including Chief of Correspondents and Deputy Managing Editor. He is the author of five books, including Scotty, a biography of James B. Reston, and most recently Albest, a compilation of recollections of Time correspondents during the past four decades. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Prostate Cancer Research Fund #

LONDON - Glencore, the world's largest commodities trader, saved its megamerger with Xstrata from collapse on Friday by sweetening its offer for the large multinational mining company. But the deal still remains in limbo after Xstrata raised concerns about the revised proposal. Under the new terms, Glencore is offering 3.05 of its shares for every Xstrata share, valuing the combined company at $90 billion. The commodities trader had initially agreed to exchange 2.8 shares.

SLIDE SHOW Nate Silver writes in Sunday's magazine about changes in weather forecasting. The Dutch photographer Erik Hijweege, using the professional pseudonym Kevin Erskine, has photographed storms across the country. nytimes.com/magazine

Lovers of Proust, get out your headphones: Naxos AudioBooks, a British division of the classical music label, has recorded all seven volumes of "Remembrance of Things Past" on CD - 120 discs, which will take 153 hours to get through. The last one comes out on Oct. 29. Nicolas Soames, the publisher, said in an interview that the new version replaces an earlier, abridged edition - just 36 CDs - that the company recorded between 1996 and 2000. He believes the 120-disc edition (also available for download), which will cost £380 (about $600), to be the longest audiobook in existence.

An article this weekend on Page 52 about new knits of the season, modeled by the actor Nico Tortorella, misidentifies his role in ''Scream 4.'' He plays a suspect (and eventual victim); he is not the killer.

A disgraced former Intel executive whose testimony helped convict the hedge fund billionaire Raj Rajaratnam of insider trading crimes deserves a lenient sentence because of his cooperation with the government, federal prosecutors said on Friday. In a letter to Judge Barbara Jones, the United States attorney's office in Manhattan praised the cooperation of Rajiv Goel, the former Intel executive.

Pitchfork, the usually irreverent music blog, has apologized for publishing a videotaped interview with the Chicago rapper Chief Keef that was filmed at a shooting range and features images of the young hip-hop star firing a gun. "This concept was rushed and never should have happened," Pitchfork's editor, Mark Richardson, said in an online statement . He called the episode, one of the site's "Selector" interviews with rappers, "insensitive and irresponsible." The decision to delete the video, which was recorded several months ago at a shooting range in New York City, from Pitchfork's archive comes after some less-than-sensitive comments appeared on Chief Keef's Twitter account about the death of another young Chicago rapper named Lil JoJo.

In the belief that it ought to appear as if someone cared about the city's second-most-prominent 9/11 memorial - Fritz Koenig's "Sphere for Plaza Fountain" sculpture from the original World Trade Center - a guerrilla cleaning crew took matters into its own gloved hands on Thursday. The volunteer maintenance workers arrived with water buckets and plenty of rags. As golden evening light filled Battery Park, where the 'Sphere' has stood since 2002, they bathed and gently swabbed the sculpture's base. A parks enforcement patrol car drove by a couple of times, stopping once for several minutes. But no one stepped out.

Memorial Service: Sunday, September 9, 2012 at 2:30pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 West 76th Street New York, NY 10023.

Trulia, the real estate search site, said it could raise nearly $100 million in an initial public offering. In a regulatory filing on Friday, the San Francisco-based Trulia said it planned to price its offering of six million shares at $14 to $16 a share. Trulia will sell five million shares, while the company's stockholders will sell the rest. At the top end of the range, the stock offering would yield $96 million.

Clint Eastwood said the idea for the most controversial convention speech in a generation came to him in the green room off stage, just after he greeted Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan, the country's most influential Roman Catholic bishop. "There was a stool there, and some fella kept asking me if I wanted to sit down," Mr. Eastwood said. "When I saw the stool sitting there, it gave me the idea. I'll just put the stool out there, and I'll talk to Mr. Obama and ask him why he didn't keep all of the promises he made to everybody."

DIETSHE--Robert Allen, born 1927, died on September 6. Father of Karen Dietshe and Maximilian Dietshe, grandfather of Grace Dietshe and Lillian Roberts and father-in-law of Wendie Winslow and Kenneth Roberts. Known as Bob, he was raised in Tenafly, New Jersey, served in the Army Air Corps, and attended Columbia University. Throughout his career, Bob worked for the Sun Oil Company as a public relations executive, and lived in Westtown, Pennsylvania. For the past 20 years, he has been retired and living in Simonsville, Vermont, in a house he had designed. Memorial services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations to are suggested to the: Springfield Humane Society 401 Skitchewaug Trail, Springfield, Vermont, 05156. 802-885-3997.

Have you fallen behind on your student loan payments? The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau this summer introduced an online tool to help you evaluate your options. The " Student Loan Debt Collection Assistant " asks a series of questions to help you determine what steps to take if you've missed payments or think you may in the future. It starts by asking if you have federal loans - like a Perkins or Stafford loan - or private loans. (If you aren't sure, the site has a link to the National Student Loan Data System , where you can find the answer). Federal loans generally have more protections for borrowers who fall behind on payments.

MILLER--Marcia Judith. On September 6th, at home, surrounded by her grateful family. A stunning painter, daily master of the NY Times crossword, lover of all things New York. Adoring and adored mother of Sasha and Zachary, wonderful aunt to Rebecca and Florence, an inspired grandmother to Annabel and Callie, the sharpest, wittiest and most loyal of sisters to Gerry, ever-generous sister-in-law to Penelope and mother-in-law to Kevin, incomparable and loyal friend to Patty, Sally, Barbara, Karen and a host of equally incomparable and loyal friends, wife, soul-mate, inspiration and continual wonder to Jeff, life-long host and provider of great pasta dishes to legions of travelers who found a warm home, as we all did, on 79th Street. A talent for art, family and friends, that was Marcia. Visit marciamillernewyork.com and see what we mean. Always to be missed and remembered, with Chaim and both Idas, by Zachary Green, Sasha Goldman and Jeff Stock. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel this Sunday, September 9th at 11:15am. Guests will be received afterwards and on Monday at Marcia and Jeff's apartment. Charitable donations, in lieu of flowers, to either the Chaim & Ida Miller Award, Cornell University School of Industrial & Labor Relations, or Partners in Literacy.

DENKER--Warren Zev, 70, beloved husband, father and friend, passed away with his family by his side on Tuesday, September 4, 2012, after a courageous battle with cancer. Zev was born on April 28, 1942 in Brooklyn, NY to the late Morty and Evelyn Denker and grew up in Forest Hills, NY. In 1973 Zev married the love of his life, Carole, and they relocated to Suffern, NY to raise their family. Zev enjoyed opera, was a voracious reader and cherished sharing time with friends and family. Passionate about his work, he spent his entire career of over thirty years working for ABC Television, where he was Director of Affiliate Relations. Due to his integrity and charismatic personality, he developed numerous lifelong friendships. Zev was a gregarious people person, who was loved by all. He will forever be remembered for his intelligence, warmth, humor and generosity. Zev is survived by his loving wife Carole; son Michael (Pinar); daughter Heather (Jason); and brothers, Bruce and Stephen. Contributions in Zev's memory may be made to Temple Beth El c/o The Rabbi's Discretionary Fund, Spring Valley, NY or The American Cancer Society.

Henry Herx, who over three decades wrote thousands of movie reviews for Roman Catholic publications, assessing the moral complexities raised on screen through the prism of church tenets, died on Aug. 15 at his home in Ramsey, N.J. He was 79. The cause was complications of liver cancer, said his son, Joseph.

Here's one for the list of tools you can probably live without: An app for iPhones and iPads that helps compute what the tooth fairy should leave for your child. Now, just in case there any children who are avid Bucks readers, I'm not saying that the tooth fairy doesn't exist -- just that he or she may confer with parents to determine the amount of money that is left under your pillow. The amount may vary, based on where you live, and by family (or fairy) tradition.

The smartphones going into the world's next two billion pairs of hands may not belong to either Google or Apple, but to Mozilla. The Mozilla Foundation, which oversees open source software projects like the Firefox Web browser, expects to release a mobile operating system for smartphones early next year. Its target market is Latin America, then the rest of the developing world, where smartphones from Apple and Google are still too expensive for most people.

QUEBEC CITY _ The founder, chairman and chief executive of Garda World Security, an armored car and security company based in Montreal, joined forces with a private equity fund to make a $1.1 billion offer to take the company private on Friday. In league with the chief executive, Stéphan Crétier, is Apax Partners, the London-based private equity. The consortium's $12-a-share offer includes the assumption of $625 million in debt.

Penumbra Theater in St. Paul, Minn.,which describes itself as the country's largest African-American theater, has announced that it is suspending programming this season until it can resolve a severe budget crunch. The theater, founded in 1976 and long a home for artists like Danny Glover and August Wilson, has laid off six of its 16 full-time employees and cut $800,000 from its $2.7 million budget. It is now tapping board members, donors, and artists across the country to help raise $340,000 by the end of the year so it can close the shortfall and produce "Spunk," George C. Wolfe's adaptation of stories by Zora Neale Hurston next March, its lone offering for the season. (The theater typically puts on between three and five shows.)

The e-book fiction best-seller list last Sunday, using incorrect figures from a data source, erroneously included one book and omitted another. ''Regency Christmas Wishes,'' by Sandra Heath and others, which appeared at No. 16, should not have been on the list; ''Because You Are Mine, Part III,'' by Beth Kery, should have been listed at No. 19. The rankings of three other books were consequently listed incorrectly: ''The Light Between Oceans,'' by M. L. Stedman, should have been No. 16, not No. 17; ''Wrong Bed, Right Guy,'' by Katee Robert, No. 17, not No. 18; and ''I, Michael Bennett,'' by James Patterson and Michael Ledwidge, No. 18, not No. 19. The corrected list is available at nytimes.com/books .

FELDER--Gertrude (Levenson), age 93, of Rockville Centre, NY passed away peacefully at her home on September 6th. Beautiful, multitalented and courageous to the end, she thrived and inspired as wife, mother and teacher. Born in New York City. on June 6, 1919 to the late Regina and Charles Levenson, she attended Wadleigh High School and graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Hunter College. In 1941, she married her soul mate, Kenneth Felder. He adored his "Git" and together they formed a bond of love that lasted 66 years until his death in 2007. Gertrude was predeceased by her adoring and adored brothers Bernard and Seymour Levenson. She was the beloved and proud mother of Toby Schwefel and her husband Michael, and Carolyn Felder and her long time companion Louis Salamone. She was the cherished Grandma of Charles Scott and his wife Ashlee, Jeffrey and David Schwefel, a good friend to her sister-in-law Anita and loved and respected by many nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. Gertrude was a gifted poet, real estate manager, teacher, charity fundraiser and an accomplished athlete. She served as an inspiration and role model for all those who knew her. She did it all with elegance and grace. She will surely be missed. Funeral Services are at 12:00 Noon on Sunday, September 9th at Gutterman's Chapel, Rockville Centre, NY.

SALYER--Marjorie Carlin "Jill" June 5, 1918 to August 30, 2012. Marjorie "Jill" Salyer Smith, passed away peacefully in her home in Coronado, California on August 30, 2012 at the age of 94. Jill was blessed with a long and vibrant life. Her warm and sparkling smile won her many friends the world over. She was born in Brooklyn, New York on June 5, 1918 to her loving parents, Jeannette and Walter Carlin. They lived a joyous life dedicated to family, Church and community and they travelled widely. Marjorie attended Berkeley Prep in Brooklyn K-12. Marjorie made her debut in New York City in 1936 and then went on to Georgian Court College in Lakewood, New Jersey in the class of 1941 where she studied journalism. Marjorie gained the nickname "Jill" while dating a dashing young Princeton man named Jack who was starring in a Princeton Triangle production of "Jack and Jill." The name stuck and all but her oldest childhood friends and relatives in Brooklyn called her Jill from then on. Marjorie was elected Dartmouth Winter Carnival Queen in 1940. What a beauty, inside and out. Jill loved our great country, she was highly principeled and very patriotic. Throughout the war she volunteered as a driver with the Red Cross picking up service men and women from ships returning home and taking them to the hospital. Jill met her future husband in Spring Lake New Jersey the night that President Truman announced the bombing of Hiroshima. Robert F. Smith, a Pearl harbor survivor, was then a Commander in the Navy, in Command of the Lighter than Air Force at Lakehurst Naval Air Station. He was a dashingly handsome gentleman and it was love at first sight for both of them. They married in New York in 1948 and moved to Chicago where they began their family. Robert "Bob" was President of Indiana Steel Corporation and Jill was a very active corporate wife. She excelled at hosting guests from around the world and serving on community boards while working as a volunteer at the Art Institute. Marjorie "Jill" was elected to the Board of Directors of Lafayette National Bank in Brooklyn in 1957 and served faithfully and for many years. They moved the family to Long Beach, Indiana where they built an outstanding home on the beach largely designed by Jill. She served on the Parent Committee of Notre Dame School, her children's school. She was den mother to her daughter's and son's Scout troops. Jill loved flowers and Chaired the Annual Flower Show as well as the School's Annual Summer Fundraiser. Bob and Jill designed and built a second home at Eldorado Country Club in Indian Wells California where the family spent the winters. They were founding members of Sacred Heart Church in Palm Desert. Jill was active in the Auxiliary of the Eisenhower Medical Center and the Ladies Golf Committee at Eldorado. She remained a member of Eldorado until 2011. In 1965 Bob made a career change from manufacturing to banking. He became Senior Vice President of Wells Fargo Bank in charge of the International and the National Divisions. The family moved to San Francisco. Jill was called upon to organize many Bank events. She was honored to have served on the Board of the San Francisco Ballet and the DeYoung Museum and the Women's Auxiliary of Children's Hospital. She was a member of the Franciscan Club, Menlo Country Club and the San Francisco Golf Club, quite a feat for a woman then. In the early 70s they purchased a condominium in Honolulu, Hawaii where, together with family and friends they enjoyed many happy times. Later, as the children grew and airfares climbed they sold the Hawaii property and bought a beautiful Condominium in Coronado, California where they celebrated many of Jill's birthdays and many 4th of July celebrations. She was gracious, loving and generous to all who knew her. After her husband passed away in 1998 Jill married Dr. John Salyer of Palm Desert California in 2001. They split their time between Indian Wells and Coronado. Dr. Salyer passed away in 2008. Marjorie (Jill) is survived by her daughter, Roberta Smith, her grandson, Maximilian Riley, granddaughter, Joanna Riley Weidenmiller and her son, Jeffrey Smith, his son Alex and daughter Carlin. She was deeply loved and will be sorely missed. Funeral Mass in celebration of her life will be held at 2pm on Thursday, September 20 at the Naval Amphibious Base Chapel in Coronado. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, www.stjude.org, or Vitas, Innovative Hospice Care of San Diego, www.vitas.com.

SCHERR--Lawrence, M.D. We are deeply saddened by the passing of Lawrence Scherr, M.D. a national leader in Medicine, a mentor to all of us and a true complete physician. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his family, colleagues and all of his patients who he has touched so deeply throughout his preeminent career. David J. Cooper, M.D. CEO, ProHEALTH

THAW--Elizabeth Copley. All of us at the American Associates of the Royal Academy Trust are greatly saddened by the death of our good friend Lee Thaw. She will be greatly missed by all. C. Hugh Hildesley, Chairman Kathleen B. Hearst, President

This week's Bonus Feature is just that: a bonus excerpt from Paul Elie's ''Reinventing Bach,'' in which he surveys the American cultural landscape around one night that Gould was recording the ''Goldberg'' Variations in New York City: That was Wednesday, June 8, 1955. The night before, Dwight Eisenhower appeared on color TV (the first U.S. president to do so). In a laboratory in Philadelphia, Dr. Thomas Stoltz Harvey was sectioning the brain of Albert Einstein, which he had removed while performing an autopsy on the scientist after his death in Princeton in April. Saul Bellow, on Riverside Drive in New York, was mourning his father: ''Not that I was ever prompt at anything,'' he told Leslie Fiedler, ''but life is particularly difficult in all departments just now.'' Flannery O'Connor had just returned to Georgia from New York, where she had seen ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' on Broadway and appeared on television to watch a playhouse acting-out of ''The Life You Save May Be Your Own.'' After years of struggle, Alberto Giacometti saw his work presented in three retrospectives at once: in West Germany, in London and at the Guggenheim Museum on Fifth Avenue. And an editor at the Viking Press was considering a novel by Jack Kerouac: ''So here are these characters -- in search of their identity -- and the way they must do it -- is by driving all over the U.S. -- and the way they are really doing it is by 'feeling' life down to its very roots.''

While the German director Max Ophuls's 1940s sojourn in Hollywood was not a happy one, it still produced some of his finest work. His two 1949 films, ''Caught,'' a portrait of a psychotic millionaire (based on Howard Hughes and chillingly incarnated by Robert Ryan) and ''The Reckless Moment,'' a tough noir examination of the emotional restrictions of the middle class, still await a DVD release in the United States. Fortunately, Ophuls's 1948 ''Letter From an Unknown Woman'' is receiving a DVD and Blu-ray release by Olive Films. This romantic melodrama points forward to the opulent and ironic period style Ophuls would perfect after his return to France in ''The Earrings of Madame de ....'' and his film maudit ''Lola Montès.'' ''Letter From an Unknown Woman'' feels less worldly than those pictures, and while the tragic twist of its source, a short story by the great Viennese writer Stefan Zweig, is still present, the obsessional quality has become somewhat masochistic.

Like so many trappings of midcentury manliness, brow line eyeglasses - the kind favored by Malcolm X - have landed in the hipster bargain bin. Leave it to Tom Ford to rescue them with this exquisite version made of gold-plated metal and water buffalo horn, the way they used to be in the 1960s. (The horn component even comes with a certificate of authenticity, along with a special cleansing cream.) The only thing that's not midcentury about these limited-edition frames is the $2,950 price tag.

" Kurt Vonnegut: Letters " (Delacorte, $35). The great writer's life unspools in these frank missives. In 1945, he writes his parents of being a German P.O.W.: "One boy starved to death and the SS troops shot two for stealing food." He jabs Norman Mailer: "I am cuter than you are." In the last letter, dated 2007, he declines a speaking gig: "I resemble nothing so much as an iguana, hate travel, and have nothing to say." " The John Lennon Letters " (Little, Brown, $30). Much of Lennon's correspondence is published here for the first time. Beatlemaniacs will no doubt home in on his sometimes violent exchanges with Paul McCartney in the 1970s, but equally interesting are the more quotidian entries, like grocery lists, homemade Christmas cards and curiously loopy responses to fan mail.

''I think you're the cause of all this!'' That line, spoken right into the camera -- and so, to us -- in Alfred Hitchcock's film ''The Birds,'' is the most direct example of Hitchcock's penchant for making the audience share moral culpability for what's on screen. We cower in horror from the bird attacks (as do Tippi Hedren and younger victims, above) and yet, having signed on for the mayhem, we are the cause, just as the woman says. There are striking moments like that throughout the 14 films in Universal's Blu-ray set ''Alfred Hitchcock: The Masterpiece Collection,'' and in Hitchcock Blu-rays released by Warner Brothers: Janet Leigh's dead eye staring accusingly at us in ''Psycho''; Grace Kelly, being strangled in the ''Dial M for Murder'' and reaching behind her for a weapon and pointing her finger directly into the camera (seen in 3-D, as it is on the new Blu-ray, the accusing digit reaches out of the screen. Sometimes the immoral simply resemble us. There's Farley Granger blithely telling Robert Walker he'd like someone to murder his wife in ''Strangers on a Train,'' and James Stewart in ''Rear Window,'' so intent on solving a murder by peeping from his apartment window (as we are peeping at the screen) that he almost allows the deaths of two other innocents. It's the refusal of such passivity that makes Doris Day a heroine in the superb (and still relatively unsung) ''Man Who Knew Too Much.'' Unable to be just a spectator, she screams during a performance at the Royal Albert Hall, saving a man from an assassination. But no one is entirely innocent in Hitchcock's world, and those screams ensure the would-be assassin's own death. These Blu-ray debuts were unavailable for preview. The Universal set is a version of a 2005 DVD box that gave rise to some criticism of the transfers and color of a few titles, especially ''Vertigo'' (which was originally shot in the VistaVision process). Technical questions aside, these films remain among the movies' hardest-edged investigations of moral responsibility, and among the most entertaining. True guilty pleasures. (''Alfred Hitchcock: The Masterpiece Collection,'' Sept. 25, Blu-ray $299.98; ''Strangers on a Train,'' Oct. 9, Blu-ray $19.98; ''Dial M for Murder,'' Oct. 9, 3-D Blu-ray $35.99) CHARLES TAYLOR

MODELL--Arthur B. With the most profound sadness, we mourn the passing of our beloved Uncle Artie. The love, respect and admiration we had for our incredible uncle can not be expressed adequately in these few short sentences. He was a beacon of strength and love for our family. Our mom and dad, his sister Pansy Modell Bloom and his brother-in-law Bernard Bloom, who predeceased him, showed us the mutual love and concern siblings can have for one another. We will miss you Uncle Artie. May your name be a blessing! Peggy and David Gershon and Family, Robin and David Gelles and Family, Heidi and Kenneth Glass and Family

MARVIN--Ira, age 83, died on Saturday, September 1st at UCLA Medical Center in Westwood, CA. He is survived by his beloved wife, Joan DeMarrais Marvin; brother, Woody Satz; children, Carey Marvin, Greg Marvin, Laura Marvin Smith, and David Marvin; as well as nine grandchildren; Spencer Ward-Marvin, Lois Ward-Marvin, Sophie Marvin, Johannah Marvin, Katelyn Smith, Tyler Smith, Matthew Marvin, Nicholas Marvin, and Lucas Marvin. Ira resided in New York and vacationed on Fire Island for many years before moving to the Los Angeles area. He was an avid fisherman. Ira had a long and successful career as a cinematographer and film producer with many productions to his credit including "Terms of Endearment," "Splash," "Ironclads," "The Jacksons an American Dream," and "Geronimo" among many others and also served as Vice President of the Directors Guild of America. There will be a service in Marina Del Rey, CA and a service in the Spring in Ocean Beach, Fire Island, NY.

Rhetoric, simply put, is the study of how language works to persuade. So any writer seeking to make a case, or hold a reader's attention -- which is more or less any writer not in the service of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea -- has something to learn from it. If the classical orators have modern counterparts in the realm of the written word, pre-eminent among those counterparts are the authors of opinion pieces. Here is persuasion overt, persuasion front and center. The techniques that served Cicero will just as effectively serve modern writers of opinion.

SCREENWRITERS have only lately emerged as respected players in filmmaking, after decades of abuse. Trust the Anthology Film Archives to champion them, with its FROM THE PEN OF ... series. The third installment, through Sept. 18, highlights novelists who have written scripts, including Truman Capote (''The Innocents,'' 1961); Donald Westlake (''Cops and Robbers,'' 1973, and ''The Stepfather,'' 1987); and Joan Didion and John Gregory Dunne (''The Panic in Needle Park,'' 1971). Few novelists have inspired directors like Elmore Leonard, whose works (''3:10 to Yuma,'' ''Out of Sight,'' ''Get Shorty'') have been adapted countless times. Mr. Leonard himself is a seasoned screenwriter, and Anthology offers his western ''Joe Kidd'' (1972), with Clint Eastwood, and ''Mr. Majestyk'' (1974), a modern-day Charles Bronson vehicle displaying Mr. Leonard's flair for plotting, pungent dialogue and petty-criminal portraiture. Mr. Bronson is a Vietnam veteran and ex-convict who just wants to hire some migrant workers and raise watermelons, but the mob and the law keep hampering him. With help from a strong Mexican woman (Linda Cristal), his pickup truck and his shotgun he finds a way. ''Mr. Majestyk,'' Tuesday at 7 p.m. and Saturday at 4:45 p.m; 32-34 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village; (212) 505-5181, anthologyfilmarchives.org .

Fifty years ago this Wednesday, Tom Cheney of the Washington Senators struck out 21 Baltimore Orioles over 16 innings. It remains a record for strikeouts in a game, and no pitcher has thrown more innings in any game since. When Cheney set the record, his daughter Terri Cook was a toddler. His career was over within four years, when he was 31, and he went on to become a part owner of a propane gas company in Georgia. He died in 2001.

THAW--Elizabeth Copley. Venetian Heritage mourns the loss of its founding member Mrs. Lawrence Copley Thaw who also was a board member of the International Rescue Committee. Her loyalty to us and love of Venice were exemplary. Mrs Thaw was an important figure in international society and a perennial member of the best dressed lists. Mrs Thaw was known for her brilliant dinners for world renowned figures of the charitable, cultural and political spheres. She will be greatly missed. Lawrence Lovett, Founding Chairman Gary Parr, Chairman Mrs. Donald K. Miller, Vice Chairman Pierre Durand, President

What to expect when you're expecting? Just hope it's nothing like what transpires in ''Rosemary's Baby,'' Roman Polanski's 1968 adaptation of Ira Levin's horror novel, in which Mia Farrow plays a young wife who becomes impregnated by Satan. The Prince of Darkness has help in the form of the sinister but delightful John Cassavetes, as Ms. Farrow's crocodile-smile husband, an ambitious but flailing actor. He sells his wife's womb to the big red guy in exchange for a juicy part in a hit play. The picture is alternately chilling and bitterly funny, but Mr. Polanski's deft touch means you can't always distinguish which is which. Rosemary is presented as such a guileless naïf that you alternate between wanting to protect her and wishing she'd wise up, but in the end, as Ms. Farrow plays her, it's hard not to sympathize with her. With her pixie haircut, waifish body and enormous eyes, she's a Keane painting come to life.
SOHO DUPLEX LOFT CO-OP $1,650,000

DEMIRJIAN--M. John M. John Demirjian of Quogue, NY died on August 22 at Peconic Bay Medical Center in Riverhead, NY. He was 79. He was born in Evanston, Illinois on May 24, 1933. His parents, Puzant and Nevare (nee Kalustian) Demirjian, were immigrants whose families had escaped the Armenian genocide during WWI. Mr. Demirjian graduated from Wheaton College in Wheaton, IL in 1955 with a B.S. in Zoology. That same year he was drafted into the Armed Services but received a 4-F exemption due to a head injury he had suffered playing high school football, which also accounted for the stunning white streak in his hair. In 1957, following a brief stint in the study of medicine, Mr. Demirjian shifted his professional focus to Wall Street. and joined the investment bank of L.F. Rothschild & Co, Inc. He loved the work and, rising rapidly through the ranks, was named manager of municipal bond trading in 1960. By 1972, he was a general partner, and in 1975 became the director of international operations, establishing important relationships with many European, Middle Eastern, and Japanese financial organizations and agencies, including the Vatican, the Saudi Arabian Monetary Authority, the Monarchy of Liechtenstein, and numerous central banks. He was named an administrative partner at Rothschild in 1985. In 1989 he joined Bishop Rosen & Co. where he served as a financial adviser until his retirement in 2005. Mr. Demirjian was an avid golfer and a member of The National Golf Links in Southampton and the Quogue Field Club. He was also a long-time member of the New York Athletic Club. An active member of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan for many years, he served there as a trustee and elder. Upon the retirement of the Reverend David Read in 1991, Mr. Demirjian established a scholarship fund in Dr. Read's name, which awards $10,000 each year to an outstanding seminary student. In his retirement, he continued to analyze the financial markets in the context of world events, poring over six newspapers every day. He was always elegantly dressed, usually with a cigar in hand. A warm, gregarious bear of a man, he was much beloved by family and friends alike. He is survived by his second wife, Nancy Mullan-Demirjian; and three children, Andrea, Gregory, and Alexis. A funeral service was held on Saturday, August 25, at the Church of the Atonement in Quogue. The family suggests that memorial donations be sent to a charity of the donor's choice .

The Scottish designer Jonathan Saunders loves splashing color and prints across his women's wear, but for his men's collection he toned it down. "With women, I think about how to configure prints on a female body," he says. "For men, my approach is about the combination of textures and patterns in a more architectural and functional way." He drew from the designs of Le Corbusier and Charlotte Perriand for the collection, which features waffle jacquard coats, sporty wool mélange suits and graphic printed shirts. The idea, Saunders says, was to create clothes that are casual and "not overly formal or sharp." Available at matchesfashion.com .

Jonny Lee Miller counts as a blessing that he knew early that he wanted to act. Performing in London school productions at 8, he had an agent by 9, parts on British TV in his teens and roles in movies like ''Hackers'' and '' Trainspotting '' in his 20s. Now near 40, Mr. Miller is playing a modern-day Sherlock Holmes in the CBS drama '' Elementary ,'' Thursdays at 10.

JAFFE--Bernard, Jr. (Buster) born August 26, 1930 died peacefully in his sleep at age 82 in Boca Raton, Florida. Ben is survived by his beloved children Brenda and Anthony, his half sister Betty Newman and his two grandchildren Georgia and Nicholas Jaffe. For those of us who knew Buster well, knew his lust for life was intoxicating. Handsome, witty, charming and generous he lived his life like it was not a dress rehearsal and took great pleasure in his adventures. Getting into college at Cornell and deciding to leave the first week to transfer and graduate from Syracuse exemplified his spontaneity to a tee. After serving in the Korean War as a Second Lieutenant in the Air Force, the debonair young man started his long career on Wall Street working for Loeb Rhoades and ending at Smith Barney. Residing both in New York City and Palm Beach, Ben treasured his friends and family, traveling and his long standing relationship with all his favorite restaurants and bars. He lived by the motto, "The best is yet to come." He would want us to remember that and have no regrets. A man who danced to his own drum, his spirit and passion for life will continue to live through his friends and family. We love you Dad. Memorial Service September 21, 10:30am at Riverside Chapels, West 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

LEVINE--Benjamin, DDS, died September 7, 2012 at age 90. Beloved husband of the late Renee Marcus Levine, devoted father of Randy, Barbara and Jonathan Levine, caring father-in-law of Frank Braly, Suzy Frisch and Jonathan Brandl, and proud grandfather of Jake Braly, Katie and Max Brandl, and Rachel, Zachary and Sarah Levine. He is lovingly remembered as a brilliant linguist, accomplished photographer, fabulous raconteur, and avid collector of African art and antiquities. We will miss your wonderful sense of humor and unconditional love. You will never be forgotten.

Jan. 4, 2012 San Miguel de Allende, Mexico My wife and I took a wintertime break from the North Fork of Long Island and headed to San Miguel de Allende, Mexico. The climate is terrific, but what really wowed us were the colors and textures of the city -- eye candy for photographers. I took this shot in Zona Centro, which retains an Old World character, with its cobblestone streets and narrow sidewalks. I loved the way that the lines and shadows seemed to point to the women making their way along Insurgentes, the street we were on. JAMES SLEZAK, Jamesport, N.Y.

THE new season looms, but the bustling Signature Theater Company is still finishing up last season, which included a tribute to the great South African playwright ATHOL FUGARD. As part of its first season in its new home on 42nd Street the company presented revivals of two Fugards -- ''Blood Knot'' and ''My Children! My Africa!'' -- and now it ends the Fugard season with the New York premiere of ''The Train Driver,'' which Mr. Fugard has said he thinks is his most important play. As with much of Mr. Fugard's recent writing the play depicts the troubled and despair-riddled landscape of post-apartheid South Africa. It's inspired by an actual event that took place more than a decade ago: A poor black woman from a squatter camp stepped, with her three children, into the path of a speeding commuter train. Mr. Fugard's play takes place after the event, as the driver of the train, played by Ritchie Coster, tries to come to terms with the horror of what took place and his inadvertent role in it. Opens Sunday, Romulus Linney Courtyard Theater at the Pershing Square Signature Center, 480 West 42nd Street, Clinton; (212) 244-7529, signaturetheatre.org .

CONSIDERING the all-star artists who regularly show at one Gagosian Gallery or another worldwide, it is interesting to see a name on this fall's roster that will not be familiar to American audiences. She is the German artist KARIN KNEFFEL, and when an exhibition of her paintings opens at Gagosian's Madison Avenue space on Wednesday, it will be one of the first times that New Yorkers will have the chance to see her delicate, multilayered canvases. Reminiscent of Gerhard Richter, with whom Ms. Kneffel studied, the paintings imaginatively combine perception and reality, or as the artist once explained, they ''create something to hang onto, which disappears the moment you try to grasp it.'' The exhibition, on view through Oct. 20, will include one painting, from a series of works, based on Haus Esters in Krefeld, Germany, the Bauhaus-style red-brick villa designed by Mies van der Rohe that has become a contemporary art museum. In this painting Ms. Kneffel has incorporated the interior furnishings that the Esters family had in the house, overlaid with semitransparent reflected images of a furniture arrangement consisting of lamps and chairs by Mies and the designer Lily Reich. 980 Madison Avenue, near 77th Street, (212) 744-2313, gagosian.com .

ON a recent weekend the fashion designers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez met for a company retreat at the Hamptons home of John Howard, an investor in their Proenza Schouler label. They made pizzas and hung out in a pair of treehouses Mr. Howard installed in his yard, one with a television set that drops down from the ceiling. ''He made us slushies,'' Mr. McCollough said.

Nico Tortorella, 24, is a model who became an actor only to be cast, in the CW series "A Beautiful Life," as a model. Here Tortorella reprises his role as a fashion plate, wearing some of the season's rich knits. (More than just layering devices, these sweaters have enough details - be it a fuzzy texture, a jacket's cut or an expressionist pattern - that there's no need to cover them up with outerwear.) Last year, Tortorella was one of the victims in Wes Craven's " Scream 4 ." Next year, he'll be in Kevin Bacon's serial-killer show, "The Following." Then he'll play a corrupt cop in the big-screen adaptation of Dean Koontz's " Odd Thomas ," starring Willem Dafoe. "Just to play opposite Dafoe, who for once is the good guy, and then I turn bad on him - it's awesome," he says.
In his east village studio, the artist jeremy everett puts on a solo show in fall's svelte new overcoats.

KNOWN for exceptional estate gems, the fine jeweler Stephen Russell has created a pair of mesmerizing, monochromatic earrings that put Old World glamour back in the moment. Modeled after an 18th-century pendeloque shape, they're made of almost 200 sapphires -- their setting upstaged by all that brilliant blue. And about that setting: Mr. Russell chose 18-karat blackened gold to augment the vintagelike quality. Stephen Russell 18-karat blackened gold and sapphire earrings, price on request; stephenrussell.com . EDWARD BARSAMIAN

MILLER--Marcia Judith. On September 6th, at home, surrounded by her grateful family. A stunning painter, daily master of the NY Times crossword, lover of all things New York. Adoring and adored mother of Sasha and Zachary, wonderful aunt to Rebecca and Florence, an inspired grandmother to Annabel and Callie, the sharpest, wittiest and most loyal of sisters to Gerry, ever-generous sister-in-law to Penelope and mother-in-law to Kevin, incomparable and loyal friend to Patty, Sally, Barbara, Karen and a host of equally incomparable and loyal friends, wife, soul-mate, inspiration and continual wonder to Jeff, life-long host and provider of great pasta dishes to legions of travelers who found a warm home, as we all did, on 79th Street. A talent for art, family and friends, that was Marcia. Visit marciamillernewyork.com and see what we mean. Always to be missed and remembered, with Chaim and both Idas, by Zachary Green, Sasha Goldman and Jeff Stock. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel this Sunday, September 9th at 11:15am. Guests will be received afterwards and on Monday at Marcia and Jeff's apartment. Charitable donations, in lieu of flowers, to either the Chaim & Ida Miller Award, Cornell University School of Industrial & Labor Relations, or Partners in Literacy.
DEARBORN, Mich. IT'S one thing to take a 41-year-old station wagon for a Sunday drive, quite another to put it on the road for a six-day, 1,400-mile family vacation.

I'm sitting at Starbucks, trying to finish my last term paper. I've chosen to write on marriage in Virginia Woolf's ''Mrs. Dalloway,'' despite the Orthodox Jewish Girl stereotypes buzzing in my head. (Religious girls, one-track minds.) The next table's conversation drifts over: ''I don't talk to her. 'Cause she's married now, you know?''

Among the houses that Philip Johnson designed in New Canaan, Conn., the suburban enclave that became a laboratory for postwar Modernist design, the Robert C. Wiley house , completed in 1953, remains one of his most elegant. It is a strikingly simple composition of two rectangular boxes: one, a glass and wood pavilion with a single, 15-foot-tall living, dining and kitchen space, is cantilevered over the other, a stone and concrete base that contains, among other things, four small bedrooms, bathrooms and a sitting room. The 3,000-square-foot house typifies Modernism's insistence on efficient use of space, but by the advent of the McMansion era, despite its architectural pedigree, it merely seemed quaintly, and unsalably, tiny. The house had been on the market for some time when an enlightened buyer - Frank Gallipoli, the president of Freepoint Commodities , an energy trading firm - bought it in 1994. "I wasn't looking for a Philip Johnson house," he recalled, but given the price of land in New Canaan, the building, along with the six acres on which it sits, offered good value. "It had the utility of a house," Gallipoli said, "but I was getting an art object." And art is a subject close to Gallipoli's heart: he owns an extensive collection that includes works by contemporary British artists like Damien Hirst, Tracey Emin, Gary Hume, Jenny Saville and Marc Quinn. Many of these pieces are too big to show in a domestic setting, so Gallipoli began to think about converting a barn on the property (it also served as a garage) into a private gallery. About 10 years ago, he asked Johnson himself to come up with a design, but the architect's idea for a series of domed structures was never built. Ultimately, Gallipoli commissioned Roger Ferris, of the Connecticut firm Roger Ferris + Partners , to design the barn, along with a pool house, a new garage and a substantial restoration of the existing house. (Ferris also did some work on Gallipoli's Manhattan house and designed a "surf shack" for him in the Hamptons, which includes a pink Corian aboveground lap pool.)

WHAT I BROUGHT HOME Have a favorite souvenir from a favorite vacation? We're asking for photographs of what people bring home, and for the stories behind them. One reader treasures size-8.5 blue silk shoes, above, brought back from Suzhou, China .

PBS viewers can cavort with the gods and ponder the convergence of 19th-century opera with 21st-century technology when the network broadcasts WAGNER'S COMPLETE RING CYCLE -- ''Das Rheingold,'' ''Die Walküre,'' ''Siegfried'' and ''Götterdämmerung'' -- for the first time in more than two decades. This much-debated production, directed by Robert Lepage (rumored price: $16 million and not a few disgruntled critics) and starring Bryn Terfel, Deborah Voigt and Stephanie Blythe, was unveiled in increments at the Metropolitan Opera starting in the 2010-11 season. ''Wagner's Dream'' (Monday at 9 p.m.), in which Susan Froemke tells the back story of Mr. Lepage's staging of the epic, ushers in this four-night event (Tuesday through Friday at 9; check local listings). This documentary also marvels at the 45-ton set, nicknamed ''the machine,'' of 24 rotating planks that twisted into staircases and walls and threatened to grind everything to a halt. Ms. Voigt, who fell off the contraption early in her run as Brünnhilde, likened navigating the demanding role while the ground moved beneath her feet to climbing Mount Everest. As is watching the spectacle: the operas total 16 hours, with Friday night's installment clocking in at 5.

THE Zimbabwe-born NORA CHIPAUMIRE, now working out of New York, has spent most of her (still relatively short) choreographic career exploring ideas about African identity -- and even more specifically, ideas about female African identity. Until now her pieces have been largely abstract, even if they have dealt with Zimbabwean history and her experience of it. But in ''Miriam,'' which opens on Wednesday in the Fishman Space of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's new Fisher Building, Ms. Chipaumire turns to the life of the South African singer MIRIAM MAKEBA, taking inspiration from her dramatic narrative -- first as an exiled, worldwide symbol of protest against the apartheid government, later as the beloved artist known as Mama Africa. The idea of Ms. Chipaumire taking on Makeba's complicated life and art is compelling. Ms. Chipaumire too is an artistic protester against the politics of her country (South Africa's neighbor) and is effectively in exile; she too is a performer of intense vitality and charisma. But Ms. Chipaumire's work suggests that she is unlikely to do anything overly literal in ''Miriam,'' which has an original score by Omar Sosa. 7:30 p.m. Wednesday through Saturday, 321 Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100, bam.org .

ANDY WARHOL once proclaimed that ''an artist is somebody who produces things that people don't need to have,'' a statement exemplified by his namesake foundation. The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts has, in recent years, allowed his work to be paired with retailers (Barneys) and limited-edition luxury goods, including accessories (Philip Treacy), wine (Dom Pérignon) and even skateboards (Alien Workshop). Noticeably missing from the portfolio, however, has been a beauty collaboration. Enter the Nars autumn/winter 2012 color collection. Combining Warhol's well-documented love of makeup with that of the brand's founder and creative director, François Nars, the 29-piece offering captures the spirit of Warhol -- and his muses, including Edie Sedgwick, Debbie Harry and Candy Darling -- through more than just the use of recognizable imagery. ''What I loved about (Warhol's) world was that he took elements from the past and made them his own,'' Mr. Nars said. This desire to project forward is evident in product development innovations, like printed eye-shadow palettes with every color filled through to the pan, as well as never-before-seen applications of Warhol's works (a ''Kiss''-wrapped soup can, for example) by the creative consultant Fabien Baron.

From good (''The Rainmaker'') to so-so (''The Firm,'' ''The Pelican Brief'') the film adaptations of John Grisham's legal thrillers have all been marked by good performances. The best, Joel Schumacher's terrific 1994 melodrama ''The Client,'' is bursting with them. The plot involves 11-year-old Mark Sway (Brad Renfro), who accidentally witnesses the suicide of a mob informant and in the process finds out, literally, where one of the bodies is buried. He becomes the target of hit men who want to silence him and career-climbing prosecutors who want to force him to spill his guts (even if it means the hoods will actually spill his guts). And he becomes the client of a struggling defense attorney, Reggie Love (Susan Sarandon, left with Mr. Renfro), who finds herself with the biggest case of her career. Everywhere you look in this picture someone is doing some snazzy bit of character acting: Tommy Lee Jones, as the Bible-thumping showboat of a prosecutor; Mary-Louise Parker, not allowing a sliver of condescension to creep into her portrayal of Mark's utterly defeated working-class mom; Ossie Davis as a judge, his voice thick and sweet and his gaze as inescapable as fate; J. T. Walsh as a disheveled prosecutor who senses this case could be his ticket into the big time. And that's not to mention John Diehl, Anthony LaPaglia, Anthony Edwards, Anthony Heald, William H. Macy, Will Patton, Micole Mercurio and the sunshiny Amy Hathaway.

Zadie Smith An accomplished novelist, Zadie Smith has also been praised for her essays, especially those in The New York Review of Books. In ''The House That Hova Built'' (Page 108), she meets Jay-Z on the eve of his latest feat: opening the new home of the Nets, the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, with eight sold-out shows. The difference between the flamboyance of the designers' runways and what women really wear can be quite amazing. As the New York spring collections unfolded this week, simple styles by two European designers, Azzedine Alaïa and the label Alexander McQueen, designed by Sarah Burton, popped up consistently on the avenues. Alaïa's princess dress, left and right, was designed with sophisticated knitting technology. From a molded bodice, the skirt is released into a graceful circle that moves with the body. At far left are black and beige sheaths from McQueen. The prototype, far left, top, which was shown on the Paris runway in the spring, had a lace-like black cage of leather over a beige knit sheath with a flanged hem. The commercial version, not seen at the press shows, represents practical reality: it is completely of knit fabric and has lost the flanged hem. The popularity of the dresses may indicate that women are moving away from separates. What they appear to want is a flattering look that they can zip themselves into in 30 seconds.

An article last Sunday about a family that had to move back in with the wife's parents misstated the direction of a trip along the Nile taken by the family. In traveling south from Luxor to Aswan, the family went up the Nile, not down.

THE violinist GIL MORGENSTERN has offered many thoughtfully conceived programs as part of his engaging Reflections series, which explores varied repertory in light of artistic, historic and social contexts. He celebrates the fifth anniversary of the series with an enticing lineup, beginning Wednesday and Thursday at the W.M.P. Concert Hall, a jewel-box salon decorated with Parisian chandeliers and gilded mirrors. Mr. Morgenstern will be joined by the pianist J. Y. Song for ''Stravinsky, the Violin Years 1930-1935.'' The program will include excerpts from the Violin Concerto in D, ''Firebird Suite,'' ''Duo Concertante'' and ''Suite Italienne.'' 7 p.m. Wednesday, 7:30 p.m. Thursday, 31 East 28th Street, Manhattan; (212) 582-7536, wmpconcerthall.com . The Miller Theater opens its fall season with a presentation by the admirable French early-music group LE POÈME HARMONIQUE. The ensemble will pair Monteverdi's haunting madrigals about love's torments with lighthearted, witty works by Francesco Manelli. The semistaged, candle-lighted production aims to evoke the streets and canals of 17th-century Venice during Carnival. 8 p.m. Wednesday and Friday, 2960 Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights; (212) 854-7799, millertheatre.com .

Running back Darren McFadden is finally healthy and, he hopes, ready to help lead the Oakland Raiders back into contention. Drafted fourth over all by the Raiders in 2008, McFadden has had shoulder, leg and foot injuries that limited him to 32 starts in four seasons. While taking better care of his health, he became interested in improving the nutrition of children. McFadden, 25, is a part owner of Playmaker Nutrition , a new company with a line of supplements that contain no corn syrup, gelatin or preservatives. His partners in the venture include the Colorado Rockies' Carlos Gonzalez, the Minnesota Timberwolves' Kevin Love and the skier Lindsey Vonn.

SILBIGER--Sharon, M.D. We mourn the passing of Dr. Sharon Silbiger, a consummate physician/educator. She led our Internal Medicine residency and student training programs with vigor, compassion, high standards, insight, and humor. Her unwavering commitment to equal care for every patient inspired us all. Sharon was a great citizen and proud faculty member of both the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, where she served as Professor and Associate Chair for undergraduate medical education in the Department of Medicine, and at Montefiore Medical Center, where she was a clinical service leader and Director of the Department's residency program. For 23 years, Sharon served as a role model for faculty, residents and students. She will be deeply missed. Steven Safyer, M.D. CEO and President, Montefiore Medical Center Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean, Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University Victor L. Schuster, M.D. Chair of Medicine, Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Montefiore Medical Center

An article last Sunday about France's experience with a law passed in April 2011 that bans niqabs , or full-face veils, misstated Belgium's position on the veils. A similar ban took effect in Belgium in July 2011, although it has been challenged in the courts; the Belgian government is not hoping to enact such a ban.

ARNSTEIN--Mary Benjamin, a pioneer in women's participation on public and private boards, an advocate for women's advancement and health issues, and a homemaker in Hamden, CT, died September 3, 2012, at age 85. She was the daughter of Helen Weil Benjamin and Robert Morris Benjamin of New York City. Born in New York City, Mrs. Arnstein attended Friends Seminary '44 and Vassar College '47. In 1947, she married Dr. Robert L. Arnstein of New York City. They moved to New Haven, CT in 1952 where she started her community service in 1955 as the Treasurer of the Vassar Club of New Haven. Over the years she contributed to 29 organizations and received eight awards in appreciation of her contributions. Mrs. Arnstein was the first recipient of Women's Health Research at Yale's Women of Vision Award; an inaugural founder of the Community Fund for Women & Girls; one of the first women to be honored with the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce Community Leadership Award; one of the first three special honorees of the YWCA of New Haven's Annual Women in Leadership Award; the first woman to be elected as trustee of the Connecticut Savings Bank; the first woman elected to the board of directors of the New Haven Water Company; and the second woman elected to the board of trustees at Yale-New Haven Hospital. Soon after Yale College began admitting women, Mrs. Arnstein served as Acting Special Assistant to Yale University President Kingman Brewster Jr. and was Chair of the University Committee on the Education of Women. In 1983, she was awarded the Yale Medal, the highest honor the Association of Yale Alumni bestows for outstanding individual service to the university. Mrs. Arnstein is survived by her children, Katharine Arnstein, of Brighton, MA, Douglas Arnstein, of San Francisco, CA, and Anne Arnstein, of Wallingford, CT. She was predeceased by her husband and her daughter Sarah Arnstein. She is also survived by her two grandchildren, Elena Arnstein of Astoria, NY and Jason of Los Angeles, CA. A celebration of her life and reception in her honor will be held on Thursday September 13, 2012 at 1pm at the New Haven Lawn Club, 193 Whitney Ave, New Haven, CT. In lieu of flowers, gifts in her memory may be made to The Community Foundation Fund for Women and Girls, 70 Audubon St., New Haven, CT 06510, Women's Health Research at Yale, P.O. Box 208091, New Haven, CT 06520 -8091, or the charity of your choice.

WEISSMAN--Jack L. 84, of Palm Beach, FL and New York City, NY passed away Wednesday, September 5 from complications of M.D.S., a blood disease, at Cornell-Weill Medical Center, New York City. Born in Philadelphia on August 12, 1928, to Anna and Robert Weissman, he grew up in his parents' family shoe store with his older brother Harold and went on to a career in the shoe industry. He rose from a Kitty Kelly Shoe store manager in Chicago, IL to Executive VP of Ideal Shoe, a division of J.M. Fields, a national chain. In 1970, he started his own company, Marketing Footwear Associates (M.F.A) in Cherry Hill, NJ with his nephew, Dick Weissman. He soon became known throughout the industry as "Mr. Snoopy." He was the originator of character licensing in footwear when he obtained the licensing rights for the Peanuts characters created by Charles Schulz. M.F.A. became an international business and also licensed "E.T," National Football League (N.F.L) footwear, Pac-Man slippers and Budweiser athletic footwear. In 1974, he started Butterfly Originals, a licensed children's accessory company with international distribution of more than 40 licenses of Snoopy/Peanuts, The Muppets and Pac-Man. Weissman was also a principal in a licensed school supply company, Plymouth Inc. Eventually, he sold his original M.F.A. business to Mercury International and went on to create Marketing Licensing Associates (M.L.A) with a partner, Robert Rowan. M.L.A. is an agency for licensors and licensees. The highlight of his long, happy career was in 1999 when he was elected to the Licensing Hall of Fame, the highest honor of the licensing industry. Jack loved life! He was known for his wonderful, abundant sense of humor, his gravelly voice and his signature bow ties. He was passionate about old movies, international travel, convertibles, the Phillies, golf, and food "I never met a food I didn't like." He was voted one of the "worst, most-avid golfers" in Golf Digest. One of the highlights of his personal life was the delight he took as "Santa Claus" in the annual Philadelphia Thanksgiving Day Parade, a role he played for almost two decades, growing his own beard for the part! All year round he was known as "Santa Jack." A lover of all things theatrical, he belonged for 25 years to the Players Club in Gramercy Park, New York City. Weissman was a life-long active member of Sigma Alpha Rho, a national Jewish high school fraternity dedicated to community service. In SAR as a young man, he proudly served as Supreme Exalted Ruler. He was a career-long active member of Two Ten Footwear Foundation, the charitable arm of the shoe industry. In Palm Beach, he served as President and Board Member of his condominium association and was an active member of the Citizens Association of Palm Beach. He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Joyce Mantyla. Two children survive him from his first marriage, a daughter, Rande Joiner (Bob Honig) of Potomac, MD, and a son, Lee Weissman (Laura) of Irvine, CA, a granddaughter, Sara Weissman, a nephew Dick Weissman (Joy) and a niece Marcy Rogovin (Charles) and cherished friends all over the world. A memorial service in celebration of Jack's life will be held Sunday, September 23 at the Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th Street at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Two Ten Footwear Foundation, 1466 Main Street, Waltham, MA 02451, attn: Jack L. Weissman Memorial Scholarship Fund.

KANTROWITZ--Nathan, 84, died peacefully of heart failure on August 27 at his retirement home in Chicago. He is survived by his wife, Joanne (nee, Spencer), his sons, Alex of Chicago and Ted of Montreal, cherished relatives and friends. He retired from the New York City Department of Planning as Director of Demographic Studies, 1982-1998. He was a tenured professor of sociology at Fordham and Kent State during 1967-1982, and research associate at Mobilization for Youth, 1963-68. Author of books and articles on race and ethnicity and on criminology. Contributions in his honor may be made to the hungry and homeless organizations of your choice.
Cuff links with more moxie than the standard silk knot.

With a finger to her lips, Brit Marling contemplates this image of her glowing hair and sensuous pose, and she seems pleased - if a bit surprised - by the inner bombshell she's unleashed. "As a girl you have this problem . . . the whole world is about the male gaze," she says later, after changing back into her own more demure skirt and blouse. "This shoot is kind of scandalous now that I'm thinking about it." In " Arbitrage ," out this month, Marling plays a daughter poised to take over the teetering financial empire run by her father (Richard Gere). She's his surrogate son, but consciously keeps her character pretty and feminine. "The girl who is firing you is in a little white YSL dress with six-inch Prada heels?" she says. "Like, really?"

Some years ago, Alfie the Wayward Macaque, as he was known, made the local news for months after his escape from the Pittsburgh Zoo. Newscasters would occasionally announce that Alfie had been seen in one part of town or another. He was out and about for months before finally being reeled in and returned to the zoo, where he was put in isolation until zoo officials could determine if he'd been exposed to anything. He didn't seem to be bothering anyone and became a sort of folk hero in the area. I think we were all a little saddened when his adventure ended. BARBARA STURNI LONG, Mercer, Pa., posted on nytimes.com

The App City column in some editions last Sunday, about sites that help adults find leisure and fitness classes, misspelled the given name of Em the Magician, who ran a magic class. He is Emran Riaz, not Emron.

Nothing has ever come easily for the Seattle Mariners. Even in their glory years, when they had Ken Griffey Jr., Randy Johnson and Alex Rodriguez in their primes, the Mariners could not win a pennant. When all three left and the Mariners won 116 regular-season games, they still lost in the American League playoffs. When Jack Zduriencik took over as the general manager for the 2009 season and the team won 85 games, it was a shimmering mirage. The Mariners were outscored by 52 runs that season, which was sandwiched between 61-101 seasons. This will be their third last-place finish in a row.
