Who says cap-toe shoes have to be all business? Not Sir Paul Smith. The designer has reimagined the John Lobb classic - along with the British boot maker's loafer and derby - in a series of waggish hues.

To Robert Sullivan, history is not so much a collection of dates and facts but actual places you can revisit - layers of geography that can be excavated one by one. Sullivan's seventh book, " My American Revolution " (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26), chronicles his quest through some of America's chaotic birthplaces, parts of New Jersey and New York where forgotten battles still haunt the landscape. His journey begins at the top of the Empire State Building, where Sullivan looks into the distance and sees greater New York as a "palimpsest of the Revolution, a painted-over canvas of ancient routes walked smooth. . . . " Much of Sullivan's historical sallying is done on foot, or, occasionally, by boat. He follows the routes marked on colonial maps, camps outside old taverns in freezing weather and often arouses the suspicion of local police by hiking along highways and through industrial wastes. There's something charmingly boyish about his adventures: "I began to work like a scout," he writes, calling his trips "reconnaissance missions." He walks the Continental Army's path from Princeton into the Watchung Mountains of northern New Jersey, a natural fortress where Washington hid from the British, and where Sullivan severely injures his back.

It's hard to say if ''Sunday Bloody Sunday'' (1971) is a movie about the idea of wanting too much or of not wanting enough. It is, maybe, a movie about the in-between state, the place where loneliness and desire intertwine fingers without daring to commit to anything more fulfilling, or more dangerous. Glenda Jackson, a thirtyish divorcee, and Peter Finch, a fortyish physician, share the same telephone answering service and, more significant, the same lover (Murray Head, right with Ms. Jackson). He hops from one bed to another with a half-smile and a sympathetic shrug, and while his two lovers don't know each other, each is aware of the other's existence. Neither wants to lose the affection of this raffish swain, an artist who makes clever but meaningless constructions from glass pipes, colored liquids and various mechanical bits and bobs. But jealousy is never a reasonable emotion, and it circles both characters like a wraith. Ms. Jackson and Finch, as lovers who are not in love with each other, give performances of tensile delicacy. The picture -- directed by John Schlesinger and written by the onetime New Yorker film critic Penelope Gilliatt -- is lacerating, unsettling in the way it picks at subterranean emotional turmoil, until in its final moments it becomes something close to wonderful. At one point Ms. Jackson's mother (Peggy Ashcroft) tells her daughter, and not unkindly: ''You keep throwing your hand in because you haven't got the whole thing. There is no whole thing.'' By the end of ''Sunday Bloody Sunday'' Ms. Jackson and Finch's characters have finally made peace with the imperfection of whatever it is we call love. Between them they've had the whole thing, but only in bits and pieces, and never all at once. (Criterion, Oct. 23, Blu-ray, $39.95) STEPHANIE ZACHAREK

SIEGEL--Clara, died September 6, 2012 at the age of 102 and one day, peacefully in her sleep at her home in Manhattan. Born on the Lower East Side, she lived The American Dream. Motherless at 16, she worked her way through Beth Israel Hospital School of Nursing. Happily married to Sam Siegel for 59 years until 1993, she lived 71 years in Manhattan and 31 years in Brooklyn. Beloved matriarch of her family and mother of Roberta Valins (Martin), William (Colette) and Richard (Beverly). She leaves nine devoted grandchildren and 23 great-grandchildren literally from coast to coast and in between. Services at Gutterman's, Woodbury, Sunday at noon. Shiva at Roberta Valins' home, Sunday - Tuesday.

EPSTEIN--Theodore, in memory of: passed on August 30, 2012. Born in Brooklyn November 26, 1914. Graduated Cornell University in 1937 where he was on the Boxing team. Served as a Captain in the Army Air Corps. Owned and operated Lido Cleaners on 1st Ave., in Sutton Place, NYC. Then became a partner and president of Bookazine Co. now in Bayone, NJ. He leaves his children Carolyn and Richard, grandchildren Elizabeth and Jeffery, and great-grandchildren Colin and Alexander. He will be missed by all who were lucky enough to have known him.

SCULLY--John Watson. Born June 24, 1930, John Watson Scully of Vero Beach, Florida; formerly of Rye, New York died of prostate cancer on September 7th, 2012. Beloved husband of Suzanne Marechal Scully and father of his Five Stars, Susan Watson Scully-Cox, Katherine Scully Foote of Greenwich, John Marechal Scully of Winchester (Emily Ault), Cynthia Scully Doolan (Todd), and Christopher Palmer Scully. He was the doting grandfather of Dylan Foote, Eric Foote, Kyle Foote, Katherine Scully, Brooke Scully, John Watson Scully II, Poppy Doolan, George Doolan, Jack Scully, and Charles Scully. Also surviving are his loving brothers, Thomas J. Scully of Jupiter, Florida and William P. Scully (Marlynn Doble) of Dorset, Vermont and Vero Beach, Florida. He was a member of The American Yacht Club in Rye, The Moorings Club and Quail Valley River Club in Vero Beach. A service will be held at St. Marks Anglican Church in Vero Beach, Florida on Monday, September 10, 2012 at 4:00pm. A celebration of his life will take place at The American Yacht Club, Rye, NY, on Monday, September 17, 2012 at 3pm. In Iieu of flowers, the family is requesting contributions to St. Mark's Anglican Church, P.O. Box 6994, Vero Beach, Florida, 32961-6994 or to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in honor of Dr. Howard Scher at 353 East 58th Street, New York, NY 10021. He was able to keep John alive for almost 18 years.

OSCAR DE LA RENTA was singing in his Madison Avenue boutique. Lines of people waited behind barricades to get into Bergdorf Goodman. Most of SoHo and the meatpacking district looked like a police state for fashion victims. All in all, Fashion's Night Out, now in its fourth year, looked much the same as in years past, with the exception, perhaps, that the big crowds stayed mostly downtown. The Calvin Klein store at 654 Madison Avenue, where Dwyane Wade was signing autographs, was hopping, but north of that looked pretty ordinary, though others would probably disagree.

9 P.M. (13, 49) WALLANDER III: AN EVENT IN AUTUMN Kenneth Branagh, above, returns as Inspector Kurt Wallander, Henning Mankell's scruffy Swedish sleuth, in a new season of this ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' production. In this first of three episodes, a pregnant woman appears to have leapt to her death from a ferry. Or was she pushed? The case seems to have little effect on Wallander's new life with Vanja (Saskia Reeves). But then the couple discover the corpse of a woman who was murdered a decade ago on their property. And as the two investigations become entangled, a calamity strikes one of Wallander's colleagues, leading him to blame himself. Turns out he has a good reason to do so. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK George Stephanopoulos interviews Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, the Republican vice presidential nominee.

W Hotels has announced that 11 of its 28 North American properties are undergoing a $100 million renovation, the biggest overhaul in the nearly 15-year history of the brand. But guests aren't the only ones in mind: much of the change is focused on public spaces. ''We want to be a destination for city residents as much as guests,'' said Carlos Becil, the vice president of brand management.
The five most viewed articles on nytimes.com/sports from Aug. 31 to Sept. 6. 1. TO THE BOYS, HER ROLE IS SIMPLE:

On Monday, what may be Frank Capra's best film, ''The Bitter Tea of General Yen,'' finally came to DVD as part of ''Frank Capra: The Early Collection.'' Jessica Chastain stars in he director's cut of Dan Ireland's sexy and bittersweet road movie ''Jolene,'' which arrived Tuesday. Also that day: the Blu-ray release of the wild horror comedy ''Re-Animator''; brilliant work from Van Heflin and Maureen Stapleton amid the phoniness that is ''Airport''; Buster Keaton's poetic comedy ''The Navigator''; and, Vittorio De Sica's indelible ''Umberto D.'' Get out of the way! It's ''Titanic'' in 3-D on Wednesday, and the irresistibly titled ''Nympho Diver: G-String Festival,'' one of Impulse Films' releases from the Japanese studio Nikkatsu. The entire Indiana Jones franchise comes to Blu-ray on Sept. 18, so those chilled monkey brains in ''Temple of Doom'' will look extra yummy. On the same day comes one of this year's best and least-seen films, ''Oslo, August 31,'' as well as Orson Welles's ''Macbeth'' and, Aaliyah bringing the ludicrous ''Queen of the Damned'' to slinky life. On Sept. 25 ''Bond 50'' presents every official 007 release in a whopping Blu-ray box. Also on Blu-ray: the complete Japanese martial arts series ''Lone Wolf and Cub.'' Oct. 2 brings Tony Leung Ka-Fai and Maggie Cheung in Wong Kar-wai's ravishing ''In the Mood for Love.'' ''E.T. The Extra-Terrestrial'' appears in an anniversary edition on Oct. 9. Also arriving that day: the musical version of ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' and Bette Davis and Joan Crawford chewing up the scenery in ''What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?'' Tobe Hooper's horror film ''The Funhouse'' has its Blu-ray debut on Oct. 16, and Liza Minnelli stars in Alan J. Pakula's ''Sterile Cuckoo.'' Oct. 23 offers the release of Sarah Polley's unflinching marital drama ''Take This Waltz,'' with fine performances from Michelle Williams and Seth Rogen. Nov. 4 makes Robert Aldrich's hard-to-find thriller ''Twilight's Last Gleaming'' available once again, and also Sidney Lumet's searing 1962 film of the greatest of all American plays, Eugene O'Neill's ''Long Day's Journey Into Night.'' The cast -- Ralph Richardson, Katharine Hepburn, Jason Robards and Dean Stockwell -- were all honored at that year's Cannes Film Festival. CHARLES TAYLOR

The climber Chris Sharma tackles the toughest peaks in the world. But when it comes to skin care, he's totally down to earth. Let's face it: when you're clinging to the side of a cliff hundreds of feet above sea level, wrinkles are the last thing on your mind. At that moment, the only two lines you care about are the one you are making up the rock and the one that will keep you from free-falling into oblivion if you slip.

An article this weekend on Page 102 about the American intellectual Gene Sharp refers incorrectly to his work on a master's degree. He received his master's at Ohio State University in 1951; he was not working on his master's thesis in New York in 1953. And because of an editing error, the article also misstates, at one point, part of the name of a nonprofit organization he founded. As the article correctly notes elsewhere, it is the Albert Einstein Institution, not Alfred Einstein Institution.
Protect (and correct) your face, neck and scalp with the latest targeted skin care. Related article: Rock Star

CROCKETT--Sir Andrew Duncan, died peacefully at home in San Francisco September 2, 2012, after a five year battle with pancreatic cancer. Andrew had a long career as a banker and international public servant. After completing his studies at Queens' College, Cambridge, and at Yale, he began his career at the Bank of England and then held various positions at the IMF. In 1989, he returned to the Bank of England as an Executive Director. He was appointed General Manager of the Bank for International Settlements in 1993, where he served two 5-year terms. After retiring from the BIS in 2003, he joined JP Morgan Chase, where he was Special Advisor to the Chairman and a member of the Executive Committee until shortly before his death. Andrew was a leader in the international financial and banking systems. At the request of the finance ministers of the G-7 countries, he served as the first chairman of the Financial Stability Forum (now the Financial Stability Board). He also served as Chairman of Working Party 3 of the OECD, Alternate Governor of the IMF for the United Kingdom, member of the Monetary Committee of the European Union, Trustee of the International Accounting Standards Committee Foundation, member of the Group of 30, Chairman of the Per Jacobsson Foundation, member of the International Council of the China Banking Regulatory Commission, member of the International Council of the China Development Bank, Director of the International Centre for Leadership in Finance (Malaysia), and Trustee of the American University of Beirut. Andrew was honored by Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II as Knight Bachelor in 2003 and was named European Banker of the Year in 2000, among other honors. He also authored several books on economic and financial subjects, as well as numerous articles in scholarly publications. Andrew was born March 23, 1943, in Glasgow. He was a devoted husband to Marjorie, his wife of 46 years, a revered father to his three children, Alexander (Sarah), Keith (Lucia) and Inja (Jordan), and a doting grandfather to his two grandsons, Andrew and Eben. He is also survived by his beloved mother, Sheilah, and dear brothers John (Helen) and Douglas (Jennie). He was preceded in death by his father, Andrew Stuart. He leaves many other loving family members and friends throughout the United Kingdom, the United States, and the world. A memorial service for Andrew's life will be held on Monday, September 10, at 11:00am at the San Francisco Columbarium. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations in memory of Andrew Crockett to the San Francisco Botanical Garden Society (heidi@sfbg.org) or the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (www.pancan.org). The family is also collecting personal remembrances of Andrew. Please send to: (sandy--crockett@hotmail.com).

LARTIGAU--Maurice. September 10 , 2011 A private memorial service was held August 22, 2012 in St. Jean de Lier, France after which Maurice's ashes were interned in the family tomb. "You can go home again" - Helenmarie

I'm not going to lie; there are easier people to share a closet with. People who wouldn't flinch at the idea of hanging more than one shirt on a coat hanger; people who could forgive an ad hoc filing system, one that, say, mixed colors with neutrals, formalwear with casual wear, or - heaven forbid - anything sequined next to anything silk. (The risk of snagging? Who does that?) I'm precious about clothes and looking after them, but my husband, Alfie, who has a 40 percent share of my closet (awarded after a negotiation that rivaled the 1949 Israeli Armistice Agreements), is not. And so the co-habitation of our wardrobes - after I so meticulously designed the space with my carpenter Mario (glass drawers for easy viewing, pull-out shoe shelves, all lovingly wrapped in a very specific hue of blue leather edited down from thousands of swatches), while Alfie and our architect concerned themselves with the minor task of building the rest of the house - has been something of an education. For him.
Dates are subject to change. SEPTEMBER

After seven years of navigating sporadic film and stage work, Mamie Gummer is happy to have a steady job on series television, even if it means extended periods away from her Park Slope, Brooklyn, home and her husband, the actor Benjamin Walker. Ms. Gummer, the star of ''Emily Owens, M.D.,'' CW's new drama having its premiere Oct. 16, is spending most of her time on the Vancouver, British Columbia, set, while Mr. Walker, most recently in the film ''Abraham Lincoln, Vampire Hunter,'' is, as she put it, ''a little bit of all over the place,'' still riding the erratic professional waves she knows so well. But temporary separations are familiar to Ms. Gummer, who grew up coping with the demanding career of her mother, the three-time Oscar winner Meryl Streep. Having been raised largely outside Hollywood's glare in Connecticut, Ms. Gummer said she identified with her character, a smart but socially ill-at-ease neophyte surgeon. ''She's the kind of self to me that is bubbling right below, that I try to keep at bay, keep tempered all the time,'' Ms. Gummer said. ''So it's really fun to be able to take her out to play.'' Ms. Gummer, 29, doesn't worry about a career that will doubtless be compared with her mother's: ''I don't live and breathe and bleed and sweat for it. I really don't have to win an Academy Award.''

SLOAN--Edward W. , III A memorial service celebrating the life of Edward W. Sloan III (Yale '53), Charles H. Northam Professor of History Emeritus at Trinity College, will be held at 11:00am on Saturday, September 15th at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, 232 Durham Road, Madison, CT 06443.

Prepare to love a poet, to get poems stuck in your head like they were pop songs - like it was the age of Homer or Milton or Poe, when poets were pop stars. According to the 24-year-old M.F.A. dropout Steve Roggenbuck, "We are entering a golden age of literature" that is perfect for poetry. Chunks of verse should populate the "content streams" on phones and Facebook feeds. His do. Roggenbuck might be the first 21st-century poet. The Internet's staccato vernacular comes alive in his work, as does the vernacular of everyday life. References to Justin Bieber - even repeatedly calling things "beautiful" or saying "I want you" - feel profound.

TAKEOUT joints and rough-edged bars have long characterized Toronto's west-side Bloordale Village, where a vast Value Village thrift emporium has provided the main draw for outsiders. But Bloordale's relatively cheap real estate did not go unnoticed by the city's growing creative class. A couple of years ago, artists began colonizing Sterling Road's boxy brick buildings for studio space, and dealers are now transforming once unoccupied industrial and retail spaces into buzzy galleries. Along Bloor Street West, hip restaurants and shops are popping up to serve both Bloordale's new arrivals and the curious rediscovering a once-neglected part of town. MICHAEL KAMINER

SHELTON--Peter Laros. Peter will be forever missed and remembered as a loving Father, devoted Husband, Partner, Mentor and a key Driver of the Creative Force that is Shelton, Mindel & Associates. Peter did everything you couldn't see because his humble nature kept him behind the scenes. Peter was a visionary architect who invented the seemingly inevitable. He had a creative mind that always strived for perfection. Whenever we look at anything, are posed with a problem or asked for a solution we quietly reflect ... what would Peter think? He was extremely private and chose to keep his courageous and dignified battle with cancer just that. Peter and partner, Lee Mindel received the Cooper Hewitt Smithsonian National Design award from the First Lady, Michelle Obama, at the White House. The night before the event, he expressed to Lee, that although he had a hard time believing in religion he would never lose his faith in the value of the creative. We at SMA are deeply saddened by our loss but embrace moving forward with his inspiration and how he taught us all to challenge and resolve. We console and send our love to his devoted wife Laura Bennett Shelton and his beloved six children Cleo Bennett, Peik, Truman, Pierson, Larson and Finn Shelton. There will be a tribute held in his honor at the Seagram Building, Four Seasons Restaurant located at 99 East 52nd Street on Tuesday, September 11th 2012 between the hours of 4pm and 6pm. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to: The RK Laros Foundation, Elizabeth Mowrer, Executive Director, 4513 Virginia Drive, Bethlehem, PA 18017. 610-867-8452.

Figuring out an itinerary for children can feel like a game of Whac-A-Mole. That puppet show in Boston that your niece loved during her last stay? She's aged out of it. Your 17-year-old son is happy to crash lectures at Georgetown during a trip to Washington ? His 10-year-old brother is not so into it. The makers of Family iTrips may have a solution: they have updated their ''DC With Kids'' app and added apps on New York and Boston as well. ( Virginia and New England are due out next month.) The apps, which landed on iTunes's hot list last month, allow users to nimbly explore listings, including shops, hotels and restaurants. But they also offer filters through which to explore the cities: by budget, by activities that are ''like a local,'' and by attractions according to age group. (Above, a screen shot on what to visit in Washington.)
Five gadgets that track and share your every move. Related article: Sporting News

An article last Sunday about the history of New York as traced through 50 objects included several errors. On No. 18, Edison's Dynamo, the Dynamo No. 9 survives at the Henry Ford historical attraction -- which includes Greenfield Village and the Henry Ford Museum -- in Dearborn, Mich. The Dynamo No. 9 is in a building called the Edison Illuminating Company's Station A, part of Greenfield Village; it is not the case that it is ''at the Henry Ford Museum in Deerfield Village.''

NEUHAUS--Margaret Elder, passed away peacefully at her home in Houston, Texas on Tuesday, September 4, 2012. Born on December 26, 1921 in New York City, Peggy graduated from St. Mary's School in 1939 and attended Smith College, leaving in her sophomore year to pursue a career in the Theater. She reached Broadway as an understudy to Barbara Bel Geddes in the popular comedy Out of the Frying Pan. Peggy played the lead role herself for two weeks on the Broadway stage. Peggy Married Joseph Rice Neuhaus, and following Joe's discharge from the army, Peggy and Joe moved to Houston, Joe's hometown. Peggy loved Houston, making many lifelong friends and participating actively in the social and cultural life of the community. She is survived by a large and devoted family, including her brother, John Elder, her four children and their spouses, and her grandchildren and great grandchildren. Services in Houston are with Geo. H. Lewis & Sons, The Funeral Directors Since 1936, www.geohlewis.com

LUKE KELLY is British, but his heart belongs to the newer of the Englands. The area ''has such a rich history with heavy industry, industrial design and even modernist furniture design,'' Mr. Kelly said, but Americans consider it ''this bucolic, seaside, leaf-peeping place.'' His love for New England's grittier side drives Mill Goods, the antique and design store he opened in May with his partner, Emily Eisen, in the tiny town of Harrisville, N.H. At Mill Goods, in the former boiler house of a textile mill, Mr. Kelly and Ms. Eisen sell antiques salvaged from local mills and factories, as well as vintage furniture, most either made in the area or found there. Current offerings include an 1884 topographic map of America (above); hand-pinched stoneware by Alexander Pope, a local ceramist; and a 1969 Wegner Wishbone chair that the owners say came from the estate of Eddie Fisher. The owners are particularly proud of one find: notebooks containing hundreds of sketches made during the 1940s and '50s for the Gardner, Mass.-based Conant Ball furniture company. ''It's quite amazing,'' Ms. Eisen said. Mill Goods, 6 Mills Alley, Harrisville, N.H.; (603) 827-3039; millgoods.com . JULIA FELSENTHAL
STEWART--Joyce. What a lady! Beautiful and courageous, you left us much too soon. Your Pine Hollow Friends

It's a trenchant footnote that one of the great lost romantic comedies is a picture so disliked by its writer-director that she sought to have her name removed from it. In ''A New Leaf'' (1971), the directorial debut of Elaine May, Walter Matthau plays a spoiled heir who, after running through all his money, alights on the idea of finding, marrying and then offing a woman of means; his target is Ms. May (above, with Matthau), as a brainy but dippy botanist who also happens to be very rich. When Matthau, wooing her with great calculation, asks her to tell him about her life, her hopes and her dreams, Ms. May obliges haltingly, her eyes alight with eager optimism: ''My hope is to discover a new variety of fern that has never been described or classified.'' She waits a beat and continues: ''I don't know what my dream is. Do you think it could be the same as my hope?'' That's the kind of deadpan doozy Ms. May had been known for as one half, with Mike Nichols, of a late-'50s, early-'60s comedy team. ''A New Leaf'' is filled with gags that shimmer with the same kind of subtle brilliance, jokes that seem headed straight for the outer limits of the galaxy until they boomerang, with a resounding zing, back to earth. (When Matthau first learns he's become penniless, he wanders the streets of New York bidding goodbye to all his overgrown-rich-kid haunts, tracing the letters on the awning of Lutèce with the fingertips of a departing lover.) Ms. May's original cut was reportedly some three hours long and included two murders; its structure and tone must have been very different from the only version of the picture the world has ever seen, and the one that appears on this DVD. But the ''New Leaf'' we've got is so much better than none at all, with Ms. May's genius, gentle as a butterfly's wing and efficient as a nutcracker, on full display. It's a model of what latter-day romantic comedies could be, if only they'd harness brains to their hopes and dreams. (Olive Films, Sept. 4, Blu-ray $29.95, DVD $24.95) STEPHANIE ZACHAREK

The cover article last week, ''Supersizing the Empty Nest,'' reported on homeowners who go against the tide when their children move out of the family home and decide to upsize rather than downsize. Following is a selection of edited reader comments from nytimes.com :

IN his recent review of the 2013 Cadillac XTS for the Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman noted that Cadillac's new luxury sedan would soon colonize the curbside check-in areas of airports throughout the United States, supplanting the discontinued Lincoln Town Car as the country's livery workhorse. Would-be fleet buyers of the XTS have grander designs on the sedan, and judging by a photo posted recently to the Web site of G.M.'s fleet and commercial division, General Motors is happy to oblige them. There, the XTS is depicted in three distinct guises -- livery sedan, limousine and hearse -- suggesting that the XTS is primed to inherit the mantle vacated by the DTS full-size sedan, the brand's former fleet chameleon, that ended production this year.

WHEN the photographer Emily Berl visits a place for the first time, she said, she likes to go to its farthest edges, because she knows she will find something interesting happening there. In New York this instinct took her to Coney Island, the neighborhood defined by the two things it was not: the amusement park and the beach. ''Thousands of people go to the amusement park and never walk the three blocks into the neighborhood,'' she said. ''There was just so much life there that I didn't know existed.'' Ms. Berl, 27, began exploring the neighborhood in March 2011, ''just driving around, taking pictures,'' she said.

The men's floor of Milan's groundbreaking new department store Excelsior Milano offers a mix of difficult-to-find designers, cutting-edge style and old-school Italian panache. WHILE IN MILAN Maurizio Purificato goes to Il Liberty for simple but sophisticated food and to the Straf Hotel for Aperol spritzers. For something more casual, Dario Spadea Pandolfi likes Mandarin 2 , a local Chinese place. Saturday nights he heads to Plastic , a longstanding club with great music.

With only one or two exceptions, Venus and Serena Williams have proved to be not only great athletes but also the personif cation of grace under pressure. As for Richard Williams, I agree with him -- those of us who were raised by African-American parents in the South in the '40s and '50s know what it's like to steel ourselves emotionally against Indian Wells-like situations and decide, as Serena did, that we don't need to go back there. As a New Yorker and a tennis fan, I hope Serena and Venus continue to play the U.S. Open. It just wouldn't be the same tournament without them. ROBIN ROBINSON, New York, posted on nytimes.com

BRAIDS have been around forever, but they are morphing from a Nordic, tight style into chic, messier plaits, thanks to the actresses Jennifer Lawrence (as Katniss Everdeen in ''The Hunger Games'') and Kate Bosworth, who has been wearing the look a lot as of late. The hairstylist Sean Gallagher at Sally Hershberger picked up his favorite styles from Pinterest and Tumblr; a friend's 14-year-old daughter showed him how to perfect them. His tips: A part down the back of the head is dated and therefore unattractive. Hair needs to be pulled apart at the side or front and needs to be messy. No lines.

A review on Aug. 19 about ''The Twilight War,'' by David Crist, misstated the year of the truck bombing that killed 241 American servicemen in Beirut during the Reagan administration. It was 1983, not 1985.

In the days before the stadium's electronic signs, my father used to spend vacations hand-lettering the names on the brackets at the U.S. Open . My twin brother and I would go with him after the matches were over to watch as he updated who had advanced toward the finals each day. While he worked, my brother and I played in the empty stadium that was filled to capacity just hours before. We hunted stray tennis balls and often returned home to Brooklyn with shopping bags full of those discarded treasures. While we never saw any tennis matches played in the stadium, we still have our own vivid memories of the greatness of Forest Hills. MARVIN S. MEDOW, Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

With his perfect game on April 21, Philip Humber of the Chicago White Sox pulled off the ultimate single-game achievement for a pitcher. Last Tuesday, he experienced the opposite. Humber has been in the bullpen since early August, having gone 4-5 with a 7.21 E.R.A. in 14 starts after the perfect game. Working in relief against Minnesota last Tuesday, he became the first pitcher in the majors this season to allow at least eight runs while recording no more than one out.

''Everything starts out raw and goes straight on the tart,'' says Julianne Jones, explaining why her pastries have gained a cult following. At Vergennes Laundry, the bakery Jones opened in 2010 with her French husband, Didier Murat, in a former laundromat in Vergennes, Vt., all tarts are made to order with the freshest seasonal ingredients. Summer brings berries or tomatoes; the spring months asparagus with goat cheese and mint. In fall and winter it's Gilfeather turnips, potatoes, rosemary and crème fraîche. Jones won't use glaze, and she insists on an open kitchen. ''I prefer that somebody can see the tart as I'm making it,'' she says. ''They see the bag of potatoes or the crate of berries. They see the wheel of cheese.'' Though Jones and Murat are also renowned for their slow-rise bread and nougat, a few locals have yet to register the boulangerie. ''We still have people come in with their laundry bags from time to time,'' Murat says.

Last summer, when a friend was turning 40, Prada came up with the perfect joke gift at the Milan men's shows: a golf bag patterned with stylized flowers. I still tease the birthday boy about it being time to take up golf. And although I did not invest in the ultimate man bag, it made me think about how those fancy accessories from the 1980s have become just another easily accepted branch of leather goods. Not that a man's bag has to be made of leather. It might be a canvas satchel, a nylon backpack or recycled parachute cloth made into a messenger bag.

Tiana Polomaine was stretched out on a bench sleeping next to her fiancé, Dave Merritt, when their number came up just before noon on Thursday at the marriage bureau on Worth Street in downtown Manhattan. She and Mr. Merritt, both 22, picked up their soiled backpacks and shuffled over to a clerk's window and filled out the forms for a marriage license.
BRIDGEPORT CONTEMPORARY $1,975,000

BECKER--Esther Cone Campbell, passed away on August 22, 2012 at The Osborn, a retirement community in Rye, NY where she was a resident since July 2001. She had formerly lived in Forest Hills, NY for 46 years. She was 96 years old. Esther was born in Geneseo, NY, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald John Campbell. She was the widow of Gilbert Valentine Becker. She is survived by a daughter, Anne, son-in-law, Gregory J. O'Connell, and grandchildren John and Elizabeth of Rye, NY, a daughter-in-law, Debra, and grandsons David and Gregory Becker of Downingtown, PA, and several nieces and nephews. Her son, Duncan Rutherford Becker, brother, Duncan P. Campbell, and sister, Anne Campbell Ward, predeceased her. Esther was a Junior Choir mother, President of the Women's Guild and served on the vestry of St. Luke's Church. She was a member of the Women's Club of Forest Hills, the West Side Tennis Club, and Nichibei Fujinkai, an American Japanese cultural exchange society. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Church on Saturday, September 15th at 10:30am. Following the service, the family will meet friends in the Parish House. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate a donation to the Endowment Fund of St. Luke's Church, 85 Greenway South, Forest Hills, NY 11375.

FASHION WEEK may induce cravings for an ''It'' bag or a pair of shoes that last only a season, but the jewelry designer Pamela Love, left, is hoping to leave showgoers with something a bit more permanent. In the ultimate test of designer devotion, Ms. Love nixed her usual presentation to host a pop-up tattoo parlor at Milk/Made's Digital Bar this weekend. ''I wanted a break from showing, while still being involved in Fashion Week somehow,'' said the ink-happy designer, who has 16 tattoos of her own. ''Tattoos are the ultimate and most permanent form of adornment, and I love that about it.'' Two of Ms. Love's best friends, Minka Sicklinger, right, and Patrick King, known as Fish, are handling the tattoo guns. Sessions are by appointment only, with a selection of designs illustrated by her husband, Matthew Jameson Nelson Love, and inspired by the same motifs that made her classic collection a hit: arrowheads, skulls, dream catchers and moon phases. ''I figure either it will work -- rad people will come and get cool tattoos -- or people won't be that interested in it, and me and my friends will just get tattooed over and over for two days straight,'' she said. ELIZA BROOKE
Manhattan Less Than $400,000

DUHL--Doris, (nee Becker), age 88. Born in the Bronx, raised her family in Malverne, taught in Valley Stream, retired to Florida. Pre-deceased by her husband, Arthur. Survived by her children, Joanne and Steven, and her grandchildren: Joshua, Caitlin, Samuel, and Aryanna.

KWOK--Lorraine B.,passed away peacefully at her home in Rego Park, NY on Wednesday, at the age of 92. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Francis Kwok, loving mother of Francis J. Kwok and cherished grandmother of Tynan Leigh Kwok. Friends may call on Monday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Boulevard, Rego Park, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 9:45am at Our Lady of The Angelus Church followed by interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, 200 Connecticut Ave., Norwalk, CT 06854.

SCHWARTZ--Lois C.,beloved daughter of Dorothy Blaine and Arthur H. Schwartz; devoted sister/sister-in-law of Anne S. and Arthur E. Toft; infamous eccentric Auntie Lolo to Lee Toft and wife Lou, Dory Toft Bleich and husband Jeffery Bleich, Adam Blaine Toft and wife Donna; wacky great aunt to Leah and Paul Bleich, and Henry, Hannah and Emily Toft; alumna of the University of Michigan, LSA Class of 1957, recipient of the 2007 Distinguished Alumni Service Award; lifelong enthusiast of opera and all things musical. Lois passed peacefully in the early hours of Saturday, September 8, after a brief, but valiant battle with leukemia. A memorial service will be held at a time and place to be determined. Friends are asked to make a donation in her memory to a charity of their choosing.

In observance of National Yoga Month ( yogamonth.org ) in September, hotels at home and abroad are offering incentives to pose on the road. Mirbeau Inn & Spa ( mirbeau.com ) in Skaneateles , in the Finger Lakes region in New York, offers five kinds of classes -- from yoga with essential oils to slow flow hatha yoga -- in its weekly fitness schedule. Rooms start at $285.

Ali Adler, a co-executive producer of ''Glee,'' recalls the moment the show found its swim coach, who holds her own against that badger Sue Sylvester. Ms. Adler and the show's co-creator, Ryan Murphy, saw a clip of a woman verbally decimating her foes. ''Her takedowns were so hypnotic,'' Ms. Adler said. The clip was not from a scripted drama but ''Celebrity Apprentice,'' and the contestant was NeNe Leakes, best known from Bravo's ''Real Housewives of Atlanta.'' Now Ms. Leakes, 44, has landed something most of her genre peers only dream of (or grasp at): a regular role on '' The New Normal ,'' a comedy created by Ms. Adler and Mr. Murphy and starting Tuesday on NBC. But ''Real Housewives'' was not Ms. Leakes's first foray in showbiz. An aspiring actress, she flew to Los Angeles for pilot season for years, chasing roles while her husband, Gregg (they have since separated but are close), stayed with their son. Then ''Glee'' came, and ''New Normal,'' about a gay pair trying to become parents. As an assistant, Rocky, Ms. Leakes plays opposite Ellen Barkin as a racist grandmother. Now, she shuttles between Hollywood and Atlanta. (''Housewives'' faces Season 5.) ''I feel odd coming back,'' she said. Referring to script pages like a pro, she added: ''I'm always looking for my sides and my trailer. But I'm going back into my house.'' MEGAN ANGELO
PISCATAWAY COUNTRY MANOR HOUSE $729,995

In the early 1980s, the artist Sophie Calle found an address book on a Paris street and, after tracking down the people listed inside, composed a very controversial secondhand portrait of its owner, Pierre D. Her titillating detective work finally appears in English as ''The Address Book'' (Siglio, $30). In ''How Music Works'' (McSweeney's, $32), David Byrne approaches his personal passion with the clear-minded intensity of a scholar. Antoine Wilson's novel ''Panorama City'' (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $24) contains one of the season's more endearing characters: a binoculars-wearing, soliloquizing doofus named Oppen Porter. And among the utilitarian rarities collected in ''Vintage Menswear'' (Laurence King, $50) are a fin de siècle firefighter jacket and a ''walking suit'' made specially for Alpine rambling.

LANGHAMMER--Linda Lee. Dr. Linda Lee Langhammer, 61, died of heart failure May 26th at her home in New York City. Linda was the beloved daughter of Deborah Langhammer and the late Frank L. Langhammer Jr. of Morristown, New Jersey, and the cherished sister of Frank Langhammer, III of Washington, D.C., and Lisa Langhammer of West Roxbury, Massachusetts. A graduate of Barnard College in New York City, she received the Doctor of Philosophy degree in clinical psychology from Union Institute and University, Cincinnati, Ohio. Her family and friends deeply mourn her loss.

SCHERR--Lawrence, MD, 83 of New York, passed away on September 6, after a noble fight. Born in Brooklyn, NY on November 6, 1928 to Harry and Sophie Schwartz, Dr. Scherr graduated from Brooklyn technical high school and Cornell University, and proudly served in the United States Navy in active combat in Korea as an officer in the United States Navy Amphibious Force. Dr. Scherr received his MD from Cornell university medical college in 1957. from 1967 to 2001, he was David J. Greene Chairman, Department of Medicine, North Shore University Hospital and Professor of Medicine, Cornell University Medical College and New York University School of Medicine. He was Professor Emeritus of Medicine, Weill Medical College of Cornell University. Dr. Scherr was Chairman of the New York State Board for Medicine and Chairman of the New York State Council on Graduate Medical Education. He served with President Clinton's white house review group on health care reform as well as numerous other committees nationally. Dr. Scherr is survived by his beloved and devoted wife Peggy of 58 years; daughter Cynthia Rosen (Alan) and son Robert; grandchildren Sabrina; Benjamin; Natalie; and Sophie. Funeral services will be held Sunday, September 9th at 2:00pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the North Shore-LIJ Health System Foundation.

A LUMINOUS TriBeCa penthouse at 45-47 Warren Street, acquired in 1999 by Thomas Krens during his provocative tenure as the director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation in New York, sold for $6.3 million and was the most expensive residential sale of the week, according to city records. The centerpiece of the four-bedroom three-and-a-half-bath triplex condominium, which had been listed at $7 million with Amalia Ferrante, a broker at the Corcoran Group, is a 50-foot-wide living room with 22-foot ceilings, dramatic skylights and a wood-burning fireplace. The commodious dining room, also brightened by skylights, was populated by 20 dining room chairs designed by Frank Gehry (Mr. Krens has a fondness for functional artwork), and the studio on the third level is embraced by a 900-square-foot terrace.

We pitched our tent on the eastern edge of the Plage du Midi, just south of the Quai Saint Pierre where moneyed skippers, their yachts moored offshore, disembark in loafers from inflatable runabouts. It should have been a two-minute drive from the Carlton Cannes Hotel, three minutes from the equally star-studded Martinez, were it not for the suffocating crush of the Cannes Film Festival's crowds: the paparazzi, the tourists, the industry geeks with their dangling I.D. lanyards, the film students in rented tuxedos holding up signs begging for just one ticket ''s'il vous plaît,'' the gendarmes directing them all -- and occasionally stopping traffic so that this or that star might pass through in a chauffeured ride to the immense red-carpeted stairs of the Palais des Festivals. Who knows how Nicole Kidman made it through all that to arrive at our studio on the sand, but arrive she did, her ''The Paperboy'' co-star Zac Efron waiting to greet her. Michael Haneke spoke only German with our photographer, Peter Lindbergh, and his crew. Tahar Rahim arrived in Balenciaga, while Xavier Dolan explained that he'd designed his own tux. Harvey Weinstein, aside from posing with the cast of his film ''The Sapphires'' (he joked that the photo release referred to him as a ''model''), moved mountains -- possibly literally -- to make sure we had Brad Pitt in a shot. Jeremy Irons rolled his own cigarettes. David Cronenberg posed for camera-phone pictures with his daughter Caitlin, a photographer there on assignment for T's Web site. And Sam Riley and Garrett Hedlund, the studiedly disheveled stars of ''On the Road,'' displayed an insouciance that could not have been better suited to a suiting story shot on the French Riviera.

KLEGER--David S.,age 72, died peacefully at home on September 1, 2012. Born in Cleveland, Ohio to Fannie and Joseph Kleger, David was the devoted and beloved husband of Eve for 43 years; adored father of Alison, Mark, and Laura and father-in-law of Scott, Dorsey, and Justin; loving grandfather of Garrett, Cordelia, Max, Brayley, Jackson, and an expected grandson; dedicated brother of Barbara; cherished family friend of Susan, Jenny, Iam, and Logan; and dear friend and mentor to many. His earnest enthusiasm for life, his love for family and friends, and his kind generosity will be sorely missed. David received a BS from Cornell University School of Engineering and an MBA from Harvard University. He had been the founder and President of Kellogg Properties Inc. of NYC since 1977. David also served on several school and non-profit boards to support his commitment to expanding education and social services. A memorial service will be held at Frank Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue on September 10, at 5pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in his name to either The Kleger Family Cornell Tradition Scholarship, attn: June Losurdo, Cornell University, 259 Carpenter Hall, Ithaca, NY 14853 or The Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services at 135 W. 50 St, NYC 10020.

How to master the latest look from Paris: East Coast trad crossed with Left Bank tradition. Guillaume Henry, the very French designer who revived the venerable Parisian fashion house Carven , worships Brooks Brothers and that Ivy League look. At his last spring men's presentation, he said that the collection, replete with penny loafers, was inspired by "John-John Kennedy" and a "weekend at the Hamptons." He was recently spotted wearing Ralph Lauren pants.
An obituary last Sunday about the novelist and historian Alexander Saxton included several errors. The title of his first novel is ''Grand Crossing,'' not ''Grand Crossings.''

FELDMAN--Neil C.,67 of Palm Beach Gardens, FL and Marlboro, NJ passed Thursday. He was a well respected and admired veteran of Wall Street. Neil will be deeply missed by his beloved wife Jan and his children: Jill, Randi and Peter to whom he was a loving and caring father. Services will be at "Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels" Manalapan, NJ on Monday at 10:30am.

GOLDBERG--George J.,died August 10 at the age of 96 at home in Pound Ridge, NY. George was a man of strong intellect and had a life-long passion for the arts and world-wide travel. George, a friend to all, businessman and civic leader, was born in New York City in 1916, graduated from Yale in 1938, and served in WWll. He is survived by his children by his previous marriage: Alexandra Leitstein, Alice Kreindler, Georgia J Goldberg and James Goldberg; by his sons from his marriage to Nicki: John and Graham Goldberg, and by nine grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. A memorial will be held and he will be greatly missed.

SCHERR--Lawrence, MD. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System mourn the death of a beloved leader, Lawrence Scherr, MD. A preeminent physician and nationally known authority on graduate medical education, clinical practice issues, and physician manpower policies and standards, Dr. Scherr served North Shore-LIJ for 43 years, helping to shape its growth into one of the New York metropolitan area's leading healthcare organizations. From 1967 to 2001, he was the David J. Greene chair of the North Shore University Hospital (NSUH) Department of Medicine, Manhasset, NY. He also served as the hospital's director of academic affairs and medical board chair, advancing medical education and practice. Later, as senior vice president of academic affairs, Dr. Scherr played a crucial role in standardizing the development of academic training programs. Prior to his retirement in 2010, Dr. Scherr was the Betsey Cushing Whitney Academic Dean Emeritus and Historian. He was preparing a history of the health system, addressing improved access to healthcare and health outcomes, and chairing the NSUH Ethics Committee. Dr. Scherr was a past president of the American College of Physicians, and professor emeritus of medicine at Weill Medical College of Cornell University. He was instrumental in establishing North Shore-LIJ's affiliation with that medical institution. The Lawrence Scherr, MD, Professorship of Medicine at the Hofstra North Shore-LIJ School of Medicine was endowed to honor Dr. Scherr's dedicated service as a physician, educator and leader. In 2011, Dr. Scherr received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the NSUH Medical Staff Society in recognition of his commitment to the highest standards of the medical profession, mentoring of countless colleagues, exceptional devotion to patients, and his role in establishing NSUH as a preeminent institution. A Life Trustee, Dr. Scherr and his wife Peggy were devoted benefactors of the health system, generously supporting numerous initiatives over the years to ensure that North Shore-LIJ would continue to meet the healthcare needs of residents in the communities it serves. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Peggy, daughter Cynthia Rosen and her husband Alan, son Robert Scherr, and grandchildren Ben, Sophie, Sabrina and Natalie. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 9 at 2pm, Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. Shiva will be held at the Rosen home, 388 Oyster Bay Road, Locust Valley, NY, on Sunday, September 9th from 6-8pm and on Monday, September 10 from noon - 8pm. Contributions in Dr. Scherr's memory may be made to the North Shore-LIJ Health System Foundation, 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021. Michael Dowling, Pres. & CEO Richard Goldstein, Chairman North Shore-LIJ Health System

Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy. It's that time of year again: when blood pressure rises and productivity drops; when the health of 20-something athletes whom you've never met means more than your own; when fantasy football is the focal point of your life.

Dilshad Vadsaria's first experience with the ABC soap ''Revenge'' was typical of many. ''I had my iPad and was just scrunched up in the corner, watching episode after episode,'' Ms. Vadsaria said. ''It's really addictive.'' The drama about passion and payback in the Hamptons was last season's guilty-pleasure breakout . Ms. Vadsaria, 26, didn't have the luxury of turning her brain off while watching. She was prepping for a chemistry read with Gabriel Mann , who plays Nolan, the heroine Emily Thorne's henchman. With Jennifer Jason Leigh joining the cast as Emily's mother, Mike Kelley, the show's creator and executive producer, felt Nolan needed someone new to play with as well. Enter the Pakistani-American Ms. Vadsaria, who had appeared in the film '' 30 Minutes or Less '' and starred on the ABC Family series '' Greek .'' Now she knows the scope of the ''Revenge'' fan base: ''One person tweeted at me: 'Welcome to the Hamptons -- good luck getting out.' ''

You don't need an invitation to New York Fashion Week to gawk at the latest styles. Flooded with fashion editors, bloggers, celebrities and, of course, models, hotels will be celebrating with parties, panels, shopping and specialty drinks (care for a Kate Moss Cosmo?). Here are 10 places to rub shoulders with the tastemakers. THE EMPIRE HOTEL 44 West 63rd Street, (212) 265-7400; Empirehotelnyc.com. Not all the presentations (by Küning, Isa Tapia, Spanx), lounges and programs in this hotel across the street from Lincoln Center are closed to the public. During New York Fashion Week, the Empire will enable would-be models to get free makeovers inspired by the latest runway looks at the Allure Lounge Colored by Maybelline New York (updates @AllureLounge), Thursday through Sept. 13, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. on the 63rd Street side of the Empire Hotel, off of the lobby. (Members of the news media and V.I.P.'s have their own lounge, Allure Upstairs). The public lounge will have live streams of fashion shows, free samples and refreshments. Maybelline makeup artists will offer touch-ups, the Ricardo Rojas Salon will give women "high fashion" ponytails, SkinMedica will offer skin consultations and Bioxidea will provide hand treatments. There will be iPads located throughout the lounge to allow guests to shop online with the hotel's partners. And at a fragrance bar, visitors who make a purchase from certain designers on Macys.com or Sephora.com will receive a gift.

An article this weekend on Page 52 about new knits of the season, modeled by the actor Nico Tortorella, misidentifies his role in ''Scream 4.'' He plays a suspect (and eventual victim); he is not the killer.

The San Francisco-based artist's urban-inspired paintings and installations may pack a serious visual wallop, but his family's cozy Colonial Revival-style house, in the city's Mission district, is completely chill. Artworks by friends and treasures culled from vintage stores and antique markets around the world stand in for formal décor. ''Everything in the house is connected to us personally,'' McGee says. As much can be said of his no-frills fashion sense. ''Some of my favorite pieces are from thrift shops. When I find something I really love, I live, work and sleep in it.'' Some things, however, he'd sooner let go of. Asked about his current midcareer retrospective at the Berkeley Art Museum, he says, ''It's very intense to go back to the past and revive work that I've already experienced and moved forward from. It's like seeing an old girlfriend -- awkward at times, nostalgic at times and downright maddening and embarrassing.''

RABINOR--Arnold. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Arnold Rabinor. Arnold was a dedicated philanthropist who was generous with both his time and resources. A cherished leader of the Long Island Jewish community, his legacy will live on through the kindness he showed to those in need. We extend our condolences to his wife Irene and to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

KING--Stanley L. 91, native Californian and formerly of Chatham, NJ, died August 16, 2012 in Wilmington, DE. Born May 8, 1921, in Berkeley, CA, he was a graduate of U Cal--Berkeley and a World War II veteran. A Sr. Executive of AT&T-Bell Systems in New York City, he retired at 64. His contributions included service as the Chairman of the Board of New York Blue Cross Blue Shield, a member of Westminster Presbyterian Church (DE) and an Elder at Chatham, NJ, Presbyterian Church. He is survived by his wife Tee Jay (Cox) King; sister, Juliette Watkins and her family; and three sons by his late wife, Martha Anne (Blakeney) King and their families. Memorial service: Thursday, September 13 at 11 at Westminster Presbyterian Church, Wilmington, DE. Donations: Westminster Presbyterian Church 1502 West 13th Street, Wilmington, DE 19806 www.wpc.org; or the Delaware Symphony, PO Box 1870, Wilmington, DE 19899, www.delaware-symphony.org. For online condolences, please visit: Chandler Funeral Homes & Crematory. chandlerfuneralhome.com

GEARNS--Mary Jane Mary Jane Gearns, 81, of Garden City, NY and Manhattan died at home on August 31, 2012. Born and raised in Sterling, IL, the youngest of six children of Leo and Verna Wahl, she received a B.A. from St. Mary's College and M.A. from the University of Notre Dame, becoming the first female layperson to receive a Notre Dame degree. Mary Jane taught English at Duquesne University until her marriage to William Gearns, with whom she had two children, Jack and Mary Gail. Mary Jane was a devoted mother, faithful friend, and amazing and loving grandmother with boundless energy and enthusiasm for life. She traveled with family and friends all over the world and delighted in taking each of her grandchildren on their own annual trips (no parents or siblings allowed!) to destinations of their choosing, including Kenya, Australia, New Zealand, the Galapagos Islands, and many other exciting destinations. Mary Jane served for more than 20 years as a Director of Wahl Clipper Corporation, the world's largest manufacturer of electric hair clippers, founded by her father in 1919. Mary Jane was a generous supporter of many charities, including Covenant House, where she volunteered for many years, and The Sharing Foundation, which cares for severely disadvantaged and orphaned children in Cambodia. The family is deeply indebted to her extraordinary caregivers, who kept her smiling and comfortable throughout her illness: Ann, Kathy, Marylynne, Maureen, and Kathleen. Mary Jane is survived by her children Jack (Carolyn) and Mary Gail (David Russo); grandchildren Christopher and Colleen Gearns, and Sarah and Matthew Russo; brother, Msgr. Raymond Wahl; and many nieces and nephews. Contributions in Mary Jane's memory may be made to The Sharing Foundation, Concord, MA (www.sharingfoundation.org) or Catholic Relief Services (www.crs.org). The family will receive visitors at Fairchild Sons, 1201 Franklin Ave., Garden City on September 7 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Joseph's Church in Garden City on September 8 at 9:30am.
The Trend The turtleneck, humble neck warmer and clothing of choice for the late Steve Jobs, took a high-fashion turn on the runways of Neil Barrett, Hermès and Lanvin.

A COUPLE of years ago K. MICHELLE seemed like a possible heir to the throne of Mary J. Blige. A deeply able singer with a penchant for overemoting and high anxiety, she detailed the wages of torturous love as well as anyone around. But despite a handful of strong singles she never released an album and appeared to fade away. Her recent return has been improbable. She may have found her ideal creative role as the spitfire character on the uproarious, toxic and riveting VH1 reality show ''Love & Hip-Hop: Atlanta.'' She's been a reliable troublemaker, sparring with other cast members, and also the show's most bruised star, reliving what she describes as abuse at the hands of an ex. While many of her peers on the show are reality stars first, and maybe solely, K. Michelle is looking to use this second career to jump-start her first one, recently releasing a handful of new songs and performing on Thursday at S.O.B.'s. 9 p.m., 200 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village; (212) 243-4940, sobs.com .

Is work good or bad? With unemployment such a pressing national concern, it may seem a fatuous question. Even apart from current worries, the goodness of work is deep in our culture. We applaud people for their work ethic, judge our economy by its productivity and even honor work with a national holiday. But there's an underlying ambivalence: we celebrate Labor Day by not working, the Book of Genesis says work is punishment for Adam's sin and many of us see a contented retirement as the only reason for working.
A Bourgie touch gives the preppy look a Parisian Accent _1 Forgo the rep-stripe tie and tuck a patterned scarf

HEEBNER--Charles. A retired fixed income portfolio manager, loving husband, and doting father died of cancer on Saturday, August 25th at his home in Boynton Beach, Florida. He was 76 years old. Charlie graduated from Episcopal Academy and then Yale University, class of 1958, where he enthusiastically played on the Varsity soccer team. After graduating, he continued to play soccer at the Merion Cricket Club where he met his wife of 44 years, Patricia Ruth Wilson. During his distinguished career as a bond sell and buy sider culminating with his contributions as Group President at Greater New York Savings Bank and a Senior Tax Exempt Portfolio Manager at Value Line, he served in the US Navy Reserve for 22 years where he attained the rank of Commander. A committed member of St. Timothy's Church in Fairfield, Connecticut, he was a vestry member and treasurer for two terms. Charlie was passionate about all sports. He was a die-hard Eagles fan and loved playing tennis and soccer. However, Charlie will be best remembered for his favorite pastime being with his family, sailing up and down Long Island Sound. Charlie is survived by his wife, Patricia, two daughters: Alexandra O'Dell of Boynton Beach, Florida and Susan Cushman of New Canaan, Connecticut, four grandchildren and one sister, Barbara Legakis of Scarsdale, NY. The memorial service will be Saturday, September 15 at 11:30am at St. Gregory's Episcopal Church, in Boca Raton, Florida. A private internment will be in Muncy, Pennsylvania in October.

RABINOR--Arnold J. on September 6, 2012. Beloved husband of Irene. Loving father of Zachary and Rebecca, Rachel and Miki, Ali and Kevin. Cherished grandfather of Samuel, Nathaniel, Jett, Max and Marin Lily. Devoted brother of Judy and Joan. Services 11:30am Monday Boulevard-Riverside Chapels 516-295-3100 www.boulevardriversidechapel.com

EVETT--The Rev. Douglas Paul, died August 24 at home, Ann Arbor, MI., after a long illness. He was 74. Doug was the rector of St. Clare of Assisi Episcopal Church, Ann Arbor, from 1972 until 2001, where he was deeply loved by his congregation as a friend and for his preaching. He was a graduate of the University of the South (Sewanee) in 1960 with a B.A. degree and of the Episcopal Theological Seminary in Cambridge, MA in 1962 with a Masters of Divinity degree. In 1974 he was instrumental in establishing Genesis of Ann Arbor, Inc., a covenant with Temple Beth Emeth, Ann Arbor, that provided for their joint ownership of the worship and educational facilities, a relationship then unique in the history of the Episcopal Church that continues. Mr Evett is survived by a large family. A Service of Remembrance was held at St. Clare's on September 7. Those interested in making a memorial donation may do so to either the Douglas Evett Fund at St. Clare's or to the Civil War Trust, an organization which reflects one of Doug's many interests.

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week: Jennifer Egan on Michael Chabon's new novel, ''Telegraph Avenue''; Daniel Smith, the author of ''Monkey Mind: A Memoir of Anxiety''; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles with best-­seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. The cover story on Aug. 5 about traveling in Myanmar misstated the one day of the year that the government allowed the Bogyoke Aung San house museum in Yangon to open in recent years. After being closed between 1999 and 2007, the museum was opened every July 19, the anniversary of Gen. Aung San's assassination -- not every July 17. (The government allowed it to reopen full time to the public in March.)

SULLIVAN--Richard A.,85, of Alexandria Township, NJ passed away on Friday, September 7, 2012 surrounded by his loving and devoted family. WWII Veteran, Physician, Past Medical Director Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation, Former Chairman of the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine UMDNJ, Pioneer in the Management and Treatment of Spinal Cord Injuries, Stroke, and Brain Trauma. He was the devoted husband of Lucille (Haubner), loving brother of Francis and the late Mary Jane; loving father of Richard (Judy), Brian (Cathy), Katherine (James) Dowdle, Suzanne (Joseph) Quick, and Philip (Patricia); grandfather of Matthew, Daniel (Sarah), Meghan, Patrick, Emily, Lisa, Caroline, Timothy, Katherine, Sean, Joseph, and Amelia; and great-grandfather of Daniel. Mass of the Resurrection 10am Monday, September 10, 2012 at Immaculate Conception Church in Annandale, NJ. Visiting Sunday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Kearns Funeral Home in Whitehouse Station, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to the Kessler Foundation 300 Executive Drive, West Orange, NJ.

FARBER--Elsie R. Pre-deceased by her husband Irving. Survived by her children Jon, Adam and Jill. Daughters-in-law Michaela and Jean. Son-in-law Philip. Grandchildren Matthew, Kate, Steve and Wesley. She kept on keeping on and we will miss her. Donations in her memory can be sent to Meals on Wheels, either in NYC or locally.

DENKER--Warren Zev, 70, beloved husband, father and friend, passed away with his family by his side on Tuesday, September 4, 2012, after a courageous battle with cancer. Zev was born on April 28, 1942 in Brooklyn, NY to the late Morty and Evelyn Denker and grew up in Forest Hills, NY. In 1973 Zev married the love of his life, Carole, and they relocated to Suffern, NY to raise their family. Zev enjoyed opera, was a voracious reader and cherished sharing time with friends and family. Passionate about his work, he spent his entire career of over thirty years working for ABC Television, where he was Director of Affiliate Relations. Due to his integrity and charismatic personality, he developed numerous lifelong friendships. Zev was a gregarious people person, who was loved by all. He will forever be remembered for his intelligence, warmth, humor and generosity. Zev is survived by his loving wife Carole; son Michael (Pinar); daughter Heather (Jason); and brothers, Bruce and Stephen. Contributions in Zev's memory may be made to Temple Beth El c/o The Rabbi's Discretionary Fund, Spring Valley, NY or The American Cancer Society.

KLEGER--David S. The Dalton School mourns the loss of David Kleger, husband of Board member Eve Kleger and parent of Alison '90, Mark '92 and Laura '94. We extend our love and support to Eve and her family. Ellen C. Stein, Head of School

WOHLBERG--Deborah Miller, Died peacefully on September 5, 2012 after a long battle with Alzheimer's. Loving mother to Cynthia Bluming, Regina Glasser and Dr. Gary Wohlberg. May she find peace and finally be reunited with her beloved husband Sandy.

MADRID -- Sheldon G. Adelson, the American billionaire casino magnate, is set to build a giant gaming and leisure resort on the outskirts of Madrid, ending a lengthy bidding battle between the Spanish capital and Barcelona, the country's second-largest city. But the project, called EuroVegas, remains clouded in uncertainty. Mr. Adelson's company, Las Vegas Sands, offered few clues on how it would be financed amid a deepening recession and banking crisis in Spain, how big it would be or where it would be situated.

SCHERR--Lawrence MD. I had the privilege of serving as a Trustee for 25 years of North Shore University Hospital with Larry Scherr as Chief Medical Officer. I watched him turn a small suburban hospital into a great teaching hospital for interns from the best medical schools. He formed the alliance with Cornell Medical School and served as a Dean. He was not only a talented physician but a great administrator who had the respect and affection of the entire North Shore University Hospital "family". But above all he was determined that all who entered North Shore University Hospital whether wealthy or penny less would receive the highest level of care. Arnold Saltzman

3:30 p.m. | Updated One of the most expensive - and troubled - musicals of the Broadway fall season, "Rebecca," is once again in limbo, with producers announcing on Saturday that a major investor in the show has died and they are in protracted talks with the estate to secure the promised money. The investor was responsible for an investment pool of $4.5 million for the musical, more than one third of its $12 million capitalization costs for Broadway, according to the producers, who declined to divulge the investor's name. The investor, who lived in Europe, had been expected to provide $2 million for the show, and he had also secured pledges totaling $2.5 million from three other people. That money is still being sought as well. One of the "Rebecca" producers, Ben Sprecher, left for Britain on Sunday to continue the estate negotiations.

Fittingly for a festival where about half the titles in the official competition had religious themes, the 69th Venice Film Festival awarded its top prize, the Golden Lion, to "Pieta," a mother-and-son drama with a sadistic streak from the prolific Korean director Kim Ki-duk. The film sharply divided critics - as do most of Mr. Kim's confrontational movies - but it was deemed the best of the 18 competitors by a jury led by the filmmaker Michael Mann. Other members of the jury included the actress Samantha Morton, the filmmakers Matteo Garrone and Pablo Trapero and the artist Marina Abramovic. There was some confusion at the awards ceremony Saturday evening, at which the special jury prize and the Silver Lion for best director were apparently presented in the wrong order - and to the wrong people. A festival press release confirmed that the best director prize went to Paul Thomas Anderson for his hotly anticipated new film, "The Master." The film's leads, Philip Seymour Hoffman and Joaquin Phoenix , shared the best actor prize. (Mr. Seymour Hoffman accepted both awards, his collaborators having already made their way to Toronto, the next stop on the festival circuit.)

For the fifth straight year, the United States Open men's final was pushed back a day, to Monday, because of weather problems. This tournament had its share of interruptions -- which means the chorus of complaints resumed about the lack of a roof over courts at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center. The Australian Open has retractable roofs on two courts at Melbourne Park and plans for a third; Centre Court at Wimbledon added a retractable roof in 2009; and the new Roland Garros stadium with a retractable roof is expected to make its debut at the French Open in 2017. But United States Tennis Association officials have said that Arthur Ashe Stadium, built on a swamp-like ash dump, could not absorb the weight of a roof that would cover its expanse.

A map last Monday with an article about the effect of the Bloomberg administration's school choice program and its effect on students in Harlem misidentified the river east of Harlem. It is the Harlem River, not the East River.

The Personal Health column on Aug. 21, about the benefits and risks of medical radiation, misstated the amount of radiation exposure from CT scans of coronary arteries to look for calcium buildup. The scans deliver an estimated 50 to 150 times the radiation of a chest X-ray -- not 600 times the radiation of a chest X-ray. (That amount has been associated with another type of scan, known as cardiac CT angiography .)

STACKS--John, was by our side for the last 8 years. In the jungles of Brazil, the streets of Iran, Calcutta, Lagos, Buenos Aires. In a Polish cafe he regaled us with tales of journalistic intrigue in Washington. Eating innards in Azerbaijan he revealed his love for the ravishing Carol. In northern Cambodia, sipping bambu wine, we learned of his pride in son Benjamin. Stacks was our intellectual interpreter, cultural guide and on occasion would join us with a glass of spirits, raised on high. On our voyages to come we will miss him as no other. The Outer Borough Dining Society

SILBIGER--Sharon, MD, 56, of New York, passed away on September 6. She was born in Buffalo, NY and graduated from the SUNY, Buffalo, School of Medicine in 1982. She received her training in internal medicine and nephrology at the U.Mass Medical Center and joined the faculty of Albert Einstein College of Medicine in 1982, rising to the rank of Professor of Clinical Medicine. Dr. Silbiger became the Residency Program Director for the Department of Internal Medicine at Montefiore Medical Center in 2001 and served in that position until 2009, when she became the Associate Chairman for Undergraduate Medical Education in the Department of Medicine and the Site Director for the Nephrology Division. A noted nephrologist, she was active in the American Society for Nephrology and was elected President of Women in Nephrology in 2008. She was the author of numerous peer-reviewed scientific articles and an invited lecturer at a number of institutions. Dr. Silbiger is survived by her husband, Alan Gaynor, her son Jonah Gaynor, her sister Laurie Silbiger, her mother Lilli Silbiger, a survivor of the Holocaust, brothers-in-law Mark and Barry Gaynor, and by nieces and nephews. She was beloved by the many medical residents and fellows she trained, and was known for her commitment to her patients, wit and sense of humor. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Sharon Silbiger, MD Fund at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, which will support an annual lectureship in her honor: www.einstein.yu.edu/donate - In Honor/Memory - Sharon Silbiger, MD.
BEDDARD--Anita. We love, honor and remember you, not only today, but always. Devon, Fred and Michael

In a recent article I wrote on faked book reviews on the Internet, a Chicago researcher, Bing Liu, estimated that a third of all online reviews are suspect. Perhaps that seems hard to believe. Surely the bright promise of peer reviews on the Internet has not degenerated so far so fast. Or maybe it has. A new review scandal that erupted over the weekend in England confirmed the worst suspicions of how some authors act when given the cloak of anonymity: They praise themselves and trash the competition.

An obituary last Monday about the songwriter Hal David misidentified the first Top 10 song for which he wrote the lyrics. It was ''The Four Winds and the Seven Seas,'' recorded by Sammy Kaye and His Orchestra in 1949 -- not ''Magic Moments,'' recorded by Perry Como, which became a hit in 1958 and was the first Top 10 song Mr. David wrote with the composer Burt Bacharach.

Years ago, David Risher, a former Amazon executive, came up with the unlikely plan of distributing Kindles to children in the developing world to help increase literacy. Why take a fragile piece of technology that requires charging and Internet connections to places where infrastructure can be sparse, especially when there's an inexpensive, low-tech alternative in print books?

An article on Tuesday about the controversy over a plan by the Hong Kong government to teach courses in contemporary Chinese history included erroneous information from the government's education commission about the content of Chinese history courses during British rule of Hong Kong. During the later years of that rule, which ended in 1997, those courses covered Britain's capture of Hong Kong from China during the Opium Wars; they did not omit that part of history.
