Very soon, we will see inside ourselves like never before, with wearable, even internal , sensors that monitor even our most intimate biological processes. It is likely to happen even before we figure out the etiquette and laws around sharing this knowledge. Already products like the Nike+ FuelBand and the Fitbit wireless monitor track our daily activity, taking note of our steps and calories burned. The idea is to help meet an exercise regimen, perhaps lose some weight. The real-world results are uneven . For sure, though, people are building up big individual databases about themselves over increasingly long periods of time. So are the companies that sell these products, which store that data.

Bengals at Ravens 7 p.m. Eastern Line: Ravens by 7 In his rookie season, Cincinnati quarterback Andy Dalton was 9-5 against teams that were not the Ravens and 0-2 against Baltimore. It was nothing to be ashamed of, as the Ravens' defense ranked No. 3 in the N.F.L. in total yards.

KATZ--Diana, passed away peacefully September 5, 2012. She will be sorely missed by her family and devoted friends. Diana received her BA from St. John's College and her MBA from Boston College. She was a marketing executive, an international travel publisher and a community activist. Memorial on September 12 at 2pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. NYC.

The fall movie season got under way, just barely, with what may turn out to be one of the least-attended weekends at cinemas in years. The only new release of note was "The Words" (CBS Films), a poorly reviewed drama about a plagiarizing novelist. It placed third, taking in about $5 million; CBS paid $2 million for domestic distribution rights. The No. 1 movie was a holdover: "The Possession" (Lionsgate) took in an estimated $9.5 million, for a two-week total of about $33.3 million, according to Hollywood.com , which compiles box-office data. The Weinstein Company's "Lawless" was second, selling about $6 million in tickets, for a two-week total of $23.5 million. In its fourth weekend "The Expendables 2" (Lionsgate) placed fourth, grossing about $4.8 million and lifting its total to $75.4 million. "The Bourne Legacy" (Universal Pictures) was fifth, taking in an estimated $4 million, for a five-week total of $103.7 million. Deadline.com summed up the weak box-office results this way: "The weekend of Sept. 5, 2008, was the last time no films grossed over $10 million. Ouch!"
Dear Diary: Thursday, Aug. 9, 2012, 8:30 a.m. Overheard on the M96:

SAFFER--Alfred. The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our esteemed member, Alfred and extend our heartfelt sympathy to Billie and his entire family. Board of Governors Howard Smith President

Eeew. Did that filthy old pile of rags just move? If you live in urban America, you've doubtless had the experience of seeing an abandoned bedspread or cardboard box, some random bit of city flotsam, come to life on the sidewalk. There's something -- or worse, someone -- inside it. And so you look away and walk faster.

SHELTON--Peter Laros. Peter will be forever missed and remembered as a loving Father, devoted Husband, Partner, Mentor and a key Driver of the Creative Force that is Shelton, Mindel & Associates. Peter did everything you couldn't see because his humble nature kept him behind the scenes. Peter was a visionary architect who invented the seemingly inevitable. He had a creative mind that always strived for perfection. Whenever we look at anything, are posed with a problem or asked for a solution we quietly reflect ... what would Peter think? He was extremely private and chose to keep his courageous and dignified battle with cancer just that. Peter and partner, Lee Mindel received the Cooper Hewitt Smithsonian National Design award from the First Lady, Michelle Obama, at the White House. The night before the event, he expressed to Lee, that although he had a hard time believing in religion he would never lose his faith in the value of the creative. We at SMA are deeply saddened by our loss but embrace moving forward with his inspiration and how he taught us all to challenge and resolve. We console and send our love to his devoted wife Laura Bennett Shelton and his beloved six children Cleo Bennett, Peik, Truman, Pierson, Larson and Finn Shelton. There will be a tribute held in his honor at the Seagram Building, Four Seasons Restaurant located at 99 East 52nd Street on Tuesday, September 11th 2012 between the hours of 4pm and 6pm. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to: The RK Laros Foundation, Elizabeth Mowrer, Executive Director, 4513 Virginia Drive, Bethlehem, PA 18017. 610-867-8452.
DEAR DIARY: Thursday Aug. 9, 2012, 8:30 a.m. Overheard on the M96:

TORONTO - Films that take an outsider's view of business are routine at the Toronto International Film Festival. In 2010, for instance, financial corruption was in vogue, as "Inside Job," "Client 9," and "Casino Jack" all exposed the seamy underside of Wall Street and the lobbying business. But at least one picture turned the tables this year, by taking a businesslike look at an outsiders' world: street drugs.

If you've ever flown Virgin America, you will have seen the cartoonlike safety video that plays before the flight takes off. In one scene, about a minute into the video, a man is shown sitting next to a large bull as he fumbles with his seat belt. A voice-over says, "For the 0.0001 percent of you who have never operated a seat belt before, it works like this."

Interactive One , a digital media company best known for creating content for African-Americans, is set to announce on Monday that it has started a Web site aimed at urban Latinos. The site is called Zona De Sabor , which, roughly translated, means Flavor Zone.

CLAREMON--Irving. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Irving Claremon, a leader in the New York Jewish community. Together with his late wife, Ruth, they strengthened our ability to help people in need in New York, in Israel, and around the world. We extend our condolences to Ronni and Neil and to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

Sy J. Schulman, who smoothed the way for a controversial sewage plant in Harlem by offering state financing for a park with playgrounds and ball fields atop the structure, now known as the popular Riverbank State Park, died on Sept. 1 at his home in White Plains, where he once served as mayor. He was 86. The cause was pancreatic cancer, his son Ethan said.

You have close elections and the real possibility that people will say their votes were not counted when they should have been. That's the nightmare scenario for the day after the election. LAWRENCE NORDEN,

An article on Aug. 20 about F.C. Sheriff Tiraspol, a soccer club in the self-declared republic of Transnistria, referred incorrectly to President Yevgeni Shevchuk's association with the Renewal party. He is a former member, not a current one. (He now belongs to the Revival party.)

The knuckleball pitcher R. A. Dickey is putting together a historic season for the Mets. He's also been busy building a literary career. Mr. Dickey, the author of an acclaimed memoir, has now signed a deal to publish three children's books with Dial, an imprint of the publisher Penguin. The first book, to appear in fall 2013, will be an adaptation of his memoir "Wherever I Wind Up," which chronicles Mr. Dickey's unorthodox athletic career and sensitive subjects including the trauma of sexual abuse he suffered as a child.
International GERMAN ENVOY TO GREECE

3 P.M. (ABC) KATIE In the premiere of her syndicated talk show Katie Couric, left, speaks with Jessica Simpson about her career, motherhood and the state of her business empire since she gave birth to a daughter in May. Later Sheryl Crow, who wrote the show's theme song, joins in the conversation. In ''The Jeff Probst Show,'' at 2 on NBC, Mr. Probst, the ''Survivor'' host, highlights the spirit of adventure. ''The Ricki Lake Show,'' at 4 on Channel 11, represents the return of Ms. Lake to this genre since leaving in 2004, with a focus on parenting, weight loss, beauty, career and relationships. And a new season of ''Dr. Oz'' begins at 4 on Fox as 100 women test a fat burner. 7 P.M. (AMC) THE GREEN MILE (1999) Michael Clarke Duncan (above center, with Tom Hanks, left, and David Morse) plays a mysterious stranger with a healing touch who was convicted of the rape and murder of two girls in 1935 Louisiana in this drama adapted by Frank Darabont from the serial novel by Stephen King. Mr. Duncan, who died last week at 54, received Academy Award and Golden Globe nominations for his performance.

Financial regulators may face a new obstacle in their efforts to police Wall Street. Lawmakers are pushing a bill that could curb the influence of the Securities and Exchange Commission , the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and other regulators, according to Congressional staff members and government watchdog groups.

WOHLBERG--Deborah Miller, Died peacefully on September 5, 2012 after a long battle with Alzheimer's. Loving mother to Cynthia Bluming, Regina Glasser and Dr. Gary Wohlberg. Inspirational grandmother and great-grandmother. Deborah's commitment to Judaism and zest for learning are well-known, as was her rugallah. May she find peace and finally be reunited with her beloved husband Sandy.
Dear Diary: I left New York City in 1999, and brought my three children there for the first time this July. It was a wonderful week of sharing favorite spots and creating new ones.

An article on Friday about efforts by Pakistan to expel foreign staff members of the aid agency Save the Children misstated the year in which Shakil Afridi, a Pakistani doctor who told interrogators a Save the Children official had recruited him to help the C.I.A. track Osama bin Laden, ran a vaccination program in Abbottabad as part of the C.I.A. effort. It was 2011, not 2009.

FORT PIERCE, Fla. - Scott Van Duzer, pizza parlor owner and blood donator, can bench press 350 pounds. So he had no trouble with the 6-foot-1, 176-pound, skinny President Obama . Mr. Obama got a huge lift - literally - from the registered Republican during an unscheduled stop at Mr. Van Duzer's Big Apple Pizza and Pasta Italian Restaurant here on Sunday. "Look at that!" Mr. Obama exclaimed after the ebullient pizza shop owner lifted him a good couple of feet off the ground after he walked into the restaurant. "Man, are you a power lifter or what?"

Replacement referees will be under the microscope early this season. The New York Times will monitor games for plays that appear to be incorrectly called. THE PLAY On first-and-15 from the 49ers' 16, Jermichael Finley of the Packers went across the middle of the end zone and was defended by Perrish Cox and Donte Whitner. Quarterback Aaron Rodgers's pass appeared well out of Finley's reach, making any contact incidental, but pass interference was called on Dashon Goldson, a player who was nowhere near the action. After the play, Cox stepped on Finley's calf, which should have been a penalty, but it was not called.

LARTIGAU--Maurice. September 10 , 2011 A private memorial service was held August 22, 2012 in St. Jean de Lier, France after which Maurice's ashes were interned in the family tomb. "You can go home again" - Helenmarie

Dear Diary: My day started badly when I had to take a cold shower; the boiler in our Washington Heights building was on the fritz, apparently. The next treat was when I was running from the A train 207th Street stop up the stairs to take the BX-12 bus to Fordham, where I take the Metro-North to my job in Scarsdale.

As many Washington-area news outlets continue their hiring sprees to feed the appetite for political news, two political newspaper stalwarts, Roll Call and CQ Today, are following what recently has been a far more common path in journalism. They are cutting back and merging. Starting Nov. 13, Roll Call and CQ Today will become a single daily newspaper called Roll Call and will merge both newsrooms, which have already been working alongside each other. Executives say the new publication will combine the kinds of gossipy items that Capitol Hill experts rely on Roll Call for with the deeper policy reporting and legislative schedule printed in CQ Today.

MODELL--Art. We are so saddened by the loss of our dear cousin Art Modell. Brilliant, a great visionary, innovative with a delightful sense of humor. We have been saddened by his loss. We have been enriched by his life. Rest in peace. The Modell Family The Tipograph Family

The Treasury Department said on Sunday that it was planning its biggest sale of shares in the American International Group to date, making the federal government a minority shareholder in the bailed-out insurer for the first time since it took control of the company four years ago. With the sale of at least $18 billion worth of shares in A.I.G., a number that could grow to $20.7 billion if investors prove enthusiastic, the Treasury Department could reduce its holdings to as little as 15 percent from 53 percent.

DAY'S BEST Shannon Eastin was the line judge in the Rams-Lions game, making her the first woman to be an official in a regular-season game. She is among the replacement officials hired by the league while the regular officials are locked out. A resident of Tempe, Ariz., Eastin, 42, has worked as a referee in the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference - part of the Football Championship Subdivision - and has 16 years of officiating experience.

PASTOR--Naomi. March 18, 1914 - September 7, 2012. Lifelong advocate for social justice, and devoted mother and grandmother, died quietly in her sleep on Saturday, September 7, at age 98. She leaves a loving family; son Michael; daughter-in-law Ella; granddaughters Kate and Julia; and sister-in-law Joyce, to mourn her passing and carry on her legacy of informed engagement in the world. Memorial will follow.
Dear Diary: The little girl upstairs is rather small. I don't think she is even three feet tall. But every time she runs along her hall I wonder if my ceiling fan will fall.

Eight feature films and TV series collections were released in the week ended Sept. 1, including ''Pirates! Band of Misfits,'' above. Most have an audience of fans waiting to make a purchase or pick up their remotes, so movies and shows typically hit a peak and drop from the top 10 within two weeks. Blockbusters have longer staying power. ''The Hunger Games,'' which took in $408 million in theaters, is still in the top 10 and is the top DVD rental. During the week ended Aug. 11, the No. 5 title, ''Mission: Impossible -- Ghost Protocol,'' had been out for 17 weeks. SHELLY FREIERMAN

The scene unfolded like something out of one of W.C. Fields' movies. A quick-handed, wisecracking entertainer wowed a packed house, only to find himself grabbed by two police officers after the show, paraded before the flashbulbs, and hauled before a judge, where he was charged with torturing a canary. The great comedian was, in fact, the star of just such an episode. But it was in the real-life Broadway and environs of 1928, when Fields was topping the bill at the Earl Carroll Theater on Seventh Avenue in a Ziegfeld Follies knockoff called "Earl Carroll's Vanities."

Claire Vaye Watkins's first book, "Battleborn," a collection of short stories, arrives with notable provenance (the stories originally appeared in The Paris Review and elsewhere) and an unusually compelling author biography. Ms. Watkins's father, Paul Watkins, was once a member of Charles Manson's "family." In Vincent Bugliosi's "Helter Skelter," he's described as "a good-looking youth with a way with women" who "had been Manson's chief procurer of young girls." In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Watkins discussed learning about her father's life, the hold Nevada has on her imagination, her "obsessive and controlling" sense of play when she was a child and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation: Q.

The City Room column in some editions on Thursday, about an appearance on ''The Colbert Report'' by Yvette D. Clarke, a three-term Brooklyn Democratic congresswoman, referred incorrectly to Brooklyn's history as a separate city. It became part of New York City on Jan. 1, 1898, therefore it was not a separate city in 1898.

Forming a wall of players in front of the goal remains a common but imperfect way to defend free kicks, as the United States learned in its World Cup qualifier loss to Jamaica.

A jury awarded the casino mogul Steve Wynn $20 million in his slander case against Joe Francis, founder of “Girls Gone Wild,” who claimed Mr. Wynn threatened to kill him over a gambling debt.

Mr. Taylor, an Australian marine conservationist, helped film some of the most terrifying moments in American film, as a scientist suspended in an iron cage under water is attacked by a 26-foot Great White that bends the cage wide open.

MOGGRIDGE--Bill. It is with deep sadness that the Board, staff and friends of Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum mourn the loss of our esteemed director Bill Moggridge. Bill worked to transform the museum into the Smithsonian's design lens on the world and we are grateful for his extraordinary leadership and friendship. He will be truly missed. The Museum extends its deepest sympathies to Bill's wife Karin, and his sons Alex and Erik. In lieu of flowers, donations in Bill's memory may be made at www.cooperhewitt.org in support of the future exhibition galleries.

TOKYO - Japan Airlines set the price of its initial public offering on Monday at a level that could value the bailed-out carrier at 663 billion yen, or $8.5 billion, setting the stage for the world's second-largest I.P.O. this year, after that of Facebook . After robust investor demand, particularly from retail investors, the airline, also known as JAL, will seek a price of 3,790 yen (about $48.40) a share, the airline said in a news release.

O'NEILL--Amy Pauline. In the prime of her life, Amy passed away after a courageous battle with cancer on Saturday September 8th. An extraordinary spirit, Amy was outgoing, loved life and her vivacious laugh uplifted everyone around her. Born November 20th, 1965 in Plainfield N.J., Amy started her career in advertising at Deutsch and Lucky Magazine in Manhattan, later successfully transitioned to the creative side as an editor of commercials. In 2006 Amy moved to Bernardsville, N.J., to establish a family, and a career in real estate at Keller Williams. With a strong will and a tender heart, Amy moved through this world, making it lighter and more wonderful for everyone she touched. Amy will be forever missed and remembered as a devoted mother (Alexis O'Neill Assaad), loving wife (Simon Assaad), daughter (Marguerite O'Neill), sister (Erin Toto, Dana McKee, Tara Tranter, Andy O'Neill) and loyal friend (too numerous to list). Amy, we know where ever you are, you will laugh and laugh and laugh. . . and will always be in our hearts. A memorial service will be held for Amy on Wednesday September 12th 11am at Hilltop Church, 20 Hilltop Road, Mendham, N.J.

WASHINGTON - A day after it began drilling its first well in the Arctic Ocean, Shell has been forced to temporarily abandon the work because of sea ice moving into the area. The delay was the latest setback for Shell, which has invested six years and more than $4 billion

THE FACTS In today's gadget-obsessed world, sleep experts often say that for a better night's rest, Americans should click the "off" buttons on their smartphones and tablets before tucking in for the night. Electronic devices stimulate brain activity, they say, disrupting your ability to drift off to sleep. But according to the National Sleep Foundation, more than 90 percent of Americans regularly use a computer or electronic device of some kind in the hour before bed.

Ginkgo biloba extract is widely marketed as a preventive for Alzheimer's disease , but a new randomized placebo-controlled study indicates it does not work. French researchers studied 2,820 mentally healthy people over age 70 who had complained to their family physicians of memory problems, randomly assigning 1,406 to take the plant extract and 1,414 to take an identical placebo.

An article on Sept. 2 about Tampa Bay Rays pitcher Matt Moore misidentified the location of his start against the Yankees last week. It was in St. Petersburg, Fla., where the Rays play, not in the Bronx.

WRUBLIN--George, passed away peacefully on Sunday, September 9, 2012 at the age of 92. Predeceased by his wife of 52 years, Lucille Pearl Temple, George is survived by his children Elizabeth Novak (Jay), Judith Silbert (Alan), and Andrew Wrublin (Nancy), four loving grandchildren Jennifer Oneil-Dunne (Aengus), Lauren Sosnoff (Jason), Daniel Wrublin (Lauren), and Alana Wrublin (fiancee Andrew) and two great grandchildren Phineas and Luciene. A veteran of WWII, George founded G. Wrublin Company, Inc., a wholesaler of watches and electronics and he was fortunate to work with his son and grandson until his retirement at age 86. George will be remembered mostly for his kindness, generosity and love of family. A warm smile greeted everyone he met and his gentle manner made being in his presence a pleasure. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Burial will be at a private ceremony at Old Montefiore Cemetery in St. Albans, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of George can be made to the Making Headway Foundation, Inc., 115 King Street, Chappaqua, NY 10514.

At its ongoing conference in South Korea, the International Union for Conservation of Nature released a report on Friday indicating that live coral coverage on reefs in the Caribbean has plummeted from nearly 50 percent in the 1970s to less than 10 percent today. Yet describing the entire Caribbean as a region where reefs are in a state of general collapse tends to cloud the problem's complexity, the study suggests. Michael Lesser , a program director for biological oceanography at the National Science Foundation , acknowledges that the region is the "poster child" for the global destruction of reefs. "The pronouncement that the Caribbean itself would be in dire straits is no surprise - we've been talking about this for a long time now," he said.

Predeceased by his best friend and devoted wife Martha, brother Jack and sister Mildred. Loving father of Amy and Stephen Sills, Suzin Weinstein Rubin, and David and Denise Weinstein. Cherished grandfather of Adam and Casey, Jacob, and Daniel Sills, Ali, Matthew and Sam Rubin, and Sara and Zach Weinstein, the pride and joy of his life. Devoted brother of Edward and Helen Weinstein. Everyone who knew Seymour/Papa, had their story to tell of this larger than life one of a kind man. The world will be a sadder place without him, but his legacy will live on in our stories and memories. Services will be held Wednesday 12 Noon at Weinstein Garlick Kirschenbaum Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY Entombment Beth David Cemetery. When children learn to play a musical instrument, they strengthen a range of auditory skills . Recent studies suggest that these benefits extend all through life, at least for those who continue to be engaged with music. But a study published last month is the first to show that music lessons in childhood may lead to changes in the brain that persist years after the lessons stop.

When fear gripped the European markets in April, the money manager Robert Tipp decided to buy more Portuguese government bonds. He figured that European officials wouldn't let the country turn into another Greece. "They wanted to have some success stories, and Portugal was one they wanted to keep in," said Mr. Tipp, who runs the Prudential Global Total Return Fund.

Actors aren't the only stars trying to help the president get elected . Artists are doing their bit, too. In a Talk of the Town piece in this week's New Yorker, Calvin Tomkins reports that Chuck Close -- who made a tapestry based on a larger-than-life size portrait of the president that was on view at the Mint Museum in Charlotte, N.C., throughout the Democratic National Convention -- is making other artworks to raise money for the Obama campaign. He is planning to sell 10 tapestries based on different images of Mr. Obama that will cost $100,000 apiece; ten large prints at $50,000 apiece; 40 medium-sized ones at $25,000 each and 200 small ones at $5,000 each. The artworks will be sold at an invitation-only event at the Lever House in New York on Oct. 3. (The small prints will also be offered online .) The proceeds, which could well reach $3 million, will go to the Obama Victory Fund.

FOGELMAN--Lillie. The American Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors and Their Descendants mourns the death of Lillie Fogelman, beloved mother of our vice president Dr. Eva Fogelman and Gila Fogelman-Unger. She who overcame the suffering of the Shoah to infuse her daughters, sons-in-law, grandson Adam, and all who were blessed to know her with love, wisdom and integrity. May her memory be for a blessing.

KILBOURN--William Douglas , Jr. died at his retirement home in Center Sandwich, New Hampshire surrounded by his family on September 9, 2012 at about 2:44 and 34 seconds. Doug was 87 years old and is survived by two children Jonathan and Katharine and four grandchildren, Cy and Dorsey Hoadley Kilbourn and Tyson and Emily Kilbourn-Shear. He was predeceased by his wife, Barbara Neff Kilbourn. A child during the Great Depression, Doug had a paper route to support his single mom Clara and sister Charlotte. Graduating from Grant High School in Portland Oregon, Doug volunteered to serve in the US Army during The War and spent his service in Italy as a Technician Fifth Grade in the Ordnance Overseas Maintenance Modification Detachment, Ballistics and Technical Service Team where he calibrated the "Big Guns". He received a full scholarship and graduated with a BA at Yale and obtained a law degree from Columbia University. During the 1960's he founded the Boston University Graduate Tax Program where he taught, and he practiced law at Palmer & Dodge in Boston. Later he taught in the University of Minnesota Law School and practiced law at Oppenheimer in St Paul, Minnesota until his retirement. Gifts may be made in his name to the Native American Rights Fund at http://www.narf.org/ or the American Indian College Fund at http://www.collegefund.org/

SCHERR--Lawrence. Larry was our friend and doctor for over 40 years. We were so privileged to have him care for us. More than that, our family learned so much from him. His deep concern for patients, for society in general and for his hospital - the hospital he was instrumental in helping grow while focusing on improving medical delivery. He taught us and so many young doctors the great pleasure derived from implementing very high performance standards. Larry was a very special guy and we miss him almost daily. Our condolences to Peggy, his family and the medical family he so ably lead. Cecile & Jerry Shore

"We know some of you are hurt. We want to help you," boomed a bullhorn on top of an armored police vehicle. "Please come out with your hands on your heads and you will be treated. There is no place for you to go. The building, the block and the entire area is surrounded." It was the winter of 1973 in Bushwick, Brooklyn, and four men in their 20s who had vowed to fight to the death were holding about a dozen hostages inside John and Al's, a sporting goods store on a busy commercial block of Broadway. The siege would last 47 hours , one of the longest such dramas in the city's history, and mark a turning point in the New York Police Department's approach to hostage situations.

An article on Monday about the conviction and sentencing of an Iraqi political figure on murder charges referred imprecisely to the convicted man, Tariq al-Hashimi, a prominent Sunni Muslim. While he does hold the office of vice president, he is not the only Iraqi who holds that position. (The country has two vice presidents; the other is Khudayr al-Khuzai, a Shiite.)

The Sheepshead Bay Journal on Saturday, about plans for a mosque in Brooklyn, misspelled the name of a street where it is being built. It is on Voorhies Avenue, not Voorheis. (The error was repeated in a picture caption.)

Roxana Sorina Buta, dark-eyed and lithe, hurried home from work as a waitress on May 24, scurrying through rain and 1:30 a.m. darkness toward the subway. She got to Broadway and stepped into the crosswalk when the light turned green. At the same time a New York City dump truck rumbled eastbound on 14th Street and turned south on Broadway. On the video taken in a Citibank on that corner, you can see the truck making a fast, seamless turn. If you look very closely, you will also see a shadow flicker in front of the truck's right headlight.

RIGLER--Honorable William, 88, of Brooklyn passed away on Monday, September 10, 2012. Born in New York, NY on August 27, 1924 to Nathan and Pauline Rigler, he graduated from New Utrecht High School, a decorated veteran of World War II serving in the European Theater having earned five battle stars, graduated from Brooklyn College and Brooklyn Law School. From 1971 to 2000 he served as a Judge in Family Court and the dedicated matrimonial part of Kings County Brooklyn Supreme Court. He made landmark decisions concerning international custody; protecting women in Jewish divorces, one of his decisions became the basis for state legislation regarding religious divorces; and protecting the rights of HIV positive parents. He was the beloved and devoted husband of Hannah Sarah of 59 years, brother of Saul (Raleigh) and the late Harold and Charlotte, loving father of Lionel (Nancy Suchman) and Gail (Michael Milner), and cherished grandfather of Matthew and Danielle Milner. Services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Ave. (91st) on Wednesday September 12th at 10am. Shiva at Lottie Knoller's home 170 West End Avenue, Apt 18D on Wednesday, September 12th from 3pm to 9pm.

(13) DAS RHEINGOLD PBS is broadcasting Wagner's complete Ring cycle for the first time in more than two decades in a staging for the Metropolitan Opera by the Canadian director Robert Lepage that features a 45-ton set of 24 rotating planks nicknamed ''the machine.'' The story begins as the evil dwarf Alberich (Eric Owens) steals gold from the Rhine to forge a ring of unimaginable power. Bryn Terfel (above right, with Mr. Owens) sings the role of Wotan, the king of the gods, who uses magic to steal the ring, leading Alberich to put a curse on it, guaranteeing misery for its possessor. Wotan's refusal to part with the ring leads him to break a contract with the giants who have built the gods' new castle in the sky in exchange for Freia (Wendy Bryn Harmer), the goddess of love and the sister of Fricka, Wotan's wife (Stephanie Blythe). ''In many ways, even with all the high-tech elements, Mr. Lepage's production is fairly traditional,'' despite ''breathtaking stage tricks,'' Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times, saying that he had ''mixed feelings'' about Mr. Lepage's work. Still, Mr. Tommasini added, he ''deserves credit for coaxing vivid portrayals from his cast.'' The three remaining operas in the cycle will be shown nightly through Friday. 6:35 A.M. (HBO Signature) TOM JONES (1963) Albert Finney (below, with Joyce Redman) stars as an 18th-century English foundling turned Casanova in Tony Richardson's Academy Award-winning adaptation of the classic novel by Henry Fielding. Susannah York is Sophie, the passionate daughter of the blue-blooded Squire Western (Hugh Griffith), and the woman Tom hopes to wed -- through her father has other plans. Writing in The Times, Bosley Crowther called the film ''surely one of the wildest, bawdiest and funniest comedies that a refreshingly agile filmmaker has ever brought to the screen.''

11:38 a.m. | Updated After a summer hiatus and several key departures from its cast, "Saturday Night Live" said on Monday that it had added three new performers to its ensemble as it begins work on its 38th season.

The Tony Award winner Anthony LaPaglia will play Richard Nixon and Kathryn Erbe ("Law & Order: Criminal Intent") will play Pat Nixon in the world premiere of Douglas McGrath's play "Checkers" this fall at Off Broadway's Vineyard Theater, executives there announced on Friday. The play, set during the 1952 presidential election, is a character study of Nixon (then the Republican nominee for vice president) as well as a rendering of the Nixon marriage in a moment of crisis, as he delivered his so-called Checkers speech addressing allegations of financial improprieties. Mr. LaPaglia won the Tony for best actor in a play in 1998 as Eddie Carbone in that season's Broadway revival of "A View from the Bridge"; his last stage role in New York was in the 2010 Broadway revival of "Lend Me a Tenor." Ms. Erbe, whose television credits also include "Oz," and who is a member of the Steppenwolf Theater Company ensemble in Chicago, was nominated for a featured Tony in 1991 for "The Speed of Darkness."

Drinking red wine may help lower blood pressure, but a new study from Spain suggests that alcohol is not the reason. In a small randomized clinical trial, 67 men ages 55 to 75 who were at high risk for cardiovascular disease were assigned to daily drinks: four weeks drinking one ounce of gin, 10 ounces of red wine or 10 ounces of nonalcoholic red wine. All the men tried the three programs in succession.

KAHN--Judith Marilyn. Devoted daughter of Morris and Lillian, beloved sister, aunt, cousin, and friend, and especially 'Mater Canis' of Eleanor Ruth passed away peacefully on September 6. She will be missed by her family and her many friends at Lincoln Towers.

Mark Teixeira, the Yankees injured first baseman, will miss the next 10 to 14 days after irritating a Grade 1 strain of his left calf Saturday. Teixeira had a magnetic resonance imaging test Monday that revealed the extent of the injury. If he were to miss two weeks he would only be available for the final nine games of the regular season.

Japan's cabinet on Tuesday approved a plan to purchase three uninhabited islands in the East China Sea at the center of an emotional territorial dispute with China. Japan will buy the islands, part of a chain called the Senkaku in Japanese and Diaoyu in China, for about $26 million from their current owner, a Japanese citizen. Japan already administers the islands, which are also claimed by China and Taiwan. The purchase plan was originally floated by Tokyo's nationalist governor, and it has drawn angry reactions from China. In a statement on Monday reacting to the plan, China's Foreign Ministry said that Beijing would not ''sit back and watch its territorial sovereignty violated,'' adding that if Japan carried it out ''it will bear all the serious consequences that follow.''
ALPREN--Barbara Parsonnet, died September 8, age 92. Antique dealer and author of My Couplet Runneth Over.

How do we decide whether to trust somebody? An unusual new study of college students' interactions with a robot has shed light on why we intuitively trust some people and distrust others. While many people assume that behaviors like avoiding eye contact and fidgeting are signals that a person is being dishonest, scientists have found that no single gesture or expression consistently predicts trustworthiness.

HONG KONG -- At least one protester was detained and an HSBC guard was hospitalized on Tuesday as bailiffs and police exercised a court order for the eviction of Occupy Hong Kong demonstrators from the street-level plaza underneath the Asia headquarters of HSBC, where they had camped for nearly a year. A bailiff approached the demonstrators at 11 a.m. and gave what he said was the second of three warnings for them to leave. Hong Kong laws require bailiffs to give three warnings before removing people or possessions pursuant to a court order.

LONDON - Glencore International, the world's largest commodities trader, officially unveiled its new offer for the mining company Xstrata on Monday, although the outcome of the merger remains uncertain. Glencore confirmed that it was offering 3.05 of its shares for every Xstrata share, which it initially proposed on Friday. The deal would value the combined company at $90 billion. Large shareholders, including Qatar Holding, balked at the initial offer of 2.8 shares to one.

Antibiotics are important drugs, often restoring health and even saving lives. But like all drugs, they can have unwanted and serious side effects, some of which may not become apparent until many thousands of patients have been treated. Such is the case with an important class of antibiotics known as fluoroquinolones. The best known are Cipro (ciprofloxacin), Levaquin (levofloxacin) and Avelox (moxifloxacin). In 2010, Levaquin was the best-selling antibiotic in the United States.

After enduring weeks of unflattering attention over the firing of its editor, The Oxford American has hired a successor: Roger D. Hodge, a Texas-born editor and veteran of New York media. Mr. Hodge, who was the editor of Harper's magazine from 2006 to 2010, will become the second editor in the 20-year history of The Oxford American, a feisty southern journal of arts and culture. Warwick Sabin, the publisher, announced Mr. Hodge's appointment in a statement Monday, saying it will begin "an exciting new era."

The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear, indefatigable colleague Lee Thaw, who joined our Board in 1961. Over the years, she contributed enormously to the work of the IRC. She was notably active in our relief programs for refugees from Cuba, Southeast Asia, Bangladesh and Afghanistan. Metabolic syndrome, the combination of disorders that increases the risk of cardiovascular disease and diabetes , is known to be associated with brain changes and cognitive deficiencies in adults. Now a new study , published online in Pediatrics, has found a similar effect in teenagers with the disorder. Researchers compared 49 nondiabetic teenagers who had metabolic syndrome - high blood levels of glucose, low levels of high-density lipoprotein , high triglycerides , abdominal obesity and high blood pressure - with 64 young people who had fewer than three of those symptoms. Participants were given magnetic resonance brain scans and standard tests of memory, learning, attention and psychomotor ability.

WASHINGTON -- The fight for the Senate has shifted significantly over the past weeks, with fierce races breaking out in states where they were not expected and other contests dimming that were once ablaze with competition. With less than two months until Election Day, the Senate landscape is both broader and more fluid than it has been in years, with control of the upper chamber now anyone's guess. Both parties have seen new opportunities and new challenges, but the net result is that Democrats appear to be in less danger of losing the Senate, while Republicans have a more difficult path to gaining the majority.

The photo above of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was taken by an Associated Press photographer in Ohio. It is not, as one might reasonably assume, an edited image to go with an article in The Onion. It is not clear whether Mr. Biden is getting closer to his fictional beer-swilling, chest-baring, bar-fight-starting alter ego dreamed up by the satirical newspaper , or whether images of the real man that seem to reinforce his Joe Everyman character are just getting more popular .

He's dead.). He even talks about the unemployment rate (it is still too high, but job growth has increased 30 straight months after the economic mess that greeted him when he took office). And he talks about Congress (lawmakers should get moving and pass his jobs bill ).

DODSON--Reynolds E.,died peacefully with his wife, Susan, at his side on September 7, 2012, at the VNSNY Hospice and Palliative Care Center of Bellevue Hospital in New York City. He was 74 years old; the cause was bladder cancer. A writer at heart from his earliest childhood in Cincinnati, Ohio, he worked for such publishers as Reader's Digest, Meredith Corporation, Family Weekly, and The New York Times Company. He was the author of five published books: Beyond Valium: The Brave New World of Psychochemistry; Urban Renewal, a novel; Unfriendly Skies: Revelations of a Deregulated Airline Pilot; Splitsville, a compilation of comic strips he co-created; and, most recently, A Cockeyed Guide To The Hamptons. Since 1996, he has been a regular columnist on the editorial page of The Southampton Press, winning five awards from the New York Press Association, including Best Humor Column. After moving from Manhattan to Water Mill, NY, in 1994, he became active in the Southampton community as Chairman of the Bike Lane Committee and, for many years, a mentor in the Big Brothers/Big Sisters program of Long Island. He is survived by his wife, Susan, of Water Mill; his son, Christopher, of Las Vegas; his daughter, Tori, of Haymarket, Virginia; and four grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Reynolds Dodson Creative Writing Award Fund of The Greater Cincinnati Foundation; or to The Reynolds Dodson Writing Fund of Northwestern University, College of Arts and Sciences.

On Sunday, Scott Van Duzer became the Obama campaign's favorite Republican bench-pressing pizza-parlor owner when he lifted President Obama off the floor during a surprise hug in his Florida restaurant. The image made the front pages of newspapers around the country and immediately whizzed around the Internet. But on Monday, Mr. Van Duzer found that fame can be a complicated proposition. The Yelp profile page for his pizza place, which had only two reviews before Monday ("Love the Pizza, wings, subs and the best strombolie [sic] in town") was suddenly inundated with hundreds of reviews, making it perhaps the most politically charged pizza review board around.

Public Theater executives said on Monday that their fall production of the new musical "Giant," based on Edna Ferber's epic novel about a powerful Texas ranching family, will star the Tony Award nominees Brian d'Arcy James ("Shrek") and Kate Baldwin ("Finian's Rainbow") as the patriarch Bick Benedict and his wife, Leslie, the roles played in the 1956 movie by Rock Hudson and Elizabeth Taylor. The actor P.J. Griffith will play the other main character, the poor ranch hand Jett Rink, a role made famous on screen by James Dean. Other notable names in the cast include the Tony winner Michele Pawk ("Hollywood Arms") as Luz, Bick's resentful sister, and Bobby Steggert ("Ragtime") as Jordy Jr., Leslie and Bick's grown son. (Dennis Hopper played Jordy in the film.)

There's a remarkable lack of women in corporate boardrooms around the world. The European Union is considering a remedy that would require that 40 percent of a company's directors be women. This may be a milestone for gender equality, but the question is, will it make any difference in how companies are run? The number of women directors remains stubbornly low. According to Catalyst, a nonprofit organization devoted to furthering women in business, American companies have the fourth-highest average of women directors in the world . The average board of a Fortune 500 company in the United States is 16 percent women.

MONROE--Barbara Sayre, passed away on September 6, 2012, at the age of 75. She was born in Clayton, NM, and during her lifetime lived in Palo Alto, CA, New York City and on her family's historic ranch in the Dry Cimarron Valley of New Mexico before spending the past two years in Bethesda, MD. Barbara is survived by her husband of 56 years, Kendyl Kurth Monroe, a retired tax partner of Sullivan & Cromwell, and her sister Betty Sayre. Barbara was the caring mother of three sons, Sidney, Dean and Loren, and loving grandmother of Veronica, Keenan, Henry, Devon, Miles and Linden. The funeral and burial will take place on Saturday, September 22nd in Kenton, OK. A service in honor of her remarkable life is planned for Saturday, October 13th at Grace Church in New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in memory of Barbara Monroe to the Herzstein Memorial Museum, P.O. Box 75, Clayton NM 88415. Please view and sign family guestbook at pumphreyfuneralhome.com

The headline on a report in the Observatory column on Tuesday about the Swedish warship Vasa referred to the ship incorrectly. The Vasa, which sank near Stockholm on its first sailing in 1628, was not a Viking ship. (The age of the Vikings ended in the 11th century.)

An article on Tuesday about the political strategy in which President Obama and Mitt Romney are focusing on their own campaigns while on the trail and not promoting their party's Congressional candidates misstated the given name of the Iowa Republican congressman who introduced Mr. Romney at an event on Friday near Sioux City. He is Steve King, not Peter. (Peter King is a Republican congressman from New York.)

An article on Tuesday about the electoral fight for control of the Senate described incorrectly the seat being contested in North Dakota. It is held by Senator Kent Conrad, a Democrat, who is retiring; it is not a ''Republican-held'' seat.

LEVINE--Beverly Ann Greenfeder, of Ardsley, NY. Beloved mother of Michael, Richard and Susan and grandmother of Emily, Daniel, Brian and Rachel. Devoted to her family, community and the NY Yankees. Services Saturday at noon at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry, NY.

ALMERINO--Frederick A.,89, who worked tirelessly over a 30-year career with the Port Authority of NY & NJ to develop the World Trade Center into the illustrious business complex it was, passed away September 8, 2012 suddenly at Ocean Medical Center, Brick, NJ, surrounded by his loving family. A native New Yorker, after returning from WWII, Frederick earned a CPA from Fordham University and married Kathleen McCaffrey. Together 35 years before she died, they raised four children in Aberdeen, NJ, after which Frederick resided in Brick. Services for his burial are being handled by O'Brien Funeral Home, Brick, NJ.

WEINSTEIN--H. Seymour, of Boca Raton, but always of the Lower East Side, passed away on September 9th surrounded by his loving family. Predeceased by his best friend and devoted wife Martha, brother Jack and sister Mildred. Loving father of Amy and Stephen Sills, Suzin Weinstein Rubin, and David and Denise Weinstein. Cherished grandfather of Adam and Casey, Jacob, and Daniel Sills, Ali, Matthew and Sam Rubin, and Sara and Zach Weinstein, the pride and joy of his life. Devoted brother of Edward and Helen Weinstein. Everyone who knew Seymour/Papa, had their story to tell of this larger than life one of a kind man. The world will be a sadder place without him, but his legacy will live on in our stories and memories. Services will be held Wednesday 12 Noon at Weinstein Garlick Kirschenbaum Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY Entombment Beth David Cemetery. Donations can be made to the Hospice by the Sea, 1351 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL 33486

Here is what you need to know to protect yourself and your loved ones from Medicare fraud. PROTECT YOUR NUMBER Keep track of your Medicare card, and never give your number over the phone. If a thief calls to offer diabetic supplies, for instance, you may well get those supplies, but the thief will use your number over and over again for false charges.

The 11 largely faceless members of the New York City Board of Health who will decide Thursday whether to ban the sale of super-size sugary soft drinks in certain establishments trace their authority to 1805, when the power to monitor the city's health was formally vested in a city "inspector," John Pintard, a Renaissance man who is most famous for popularizing Santa Claus . Meeting for the first time, a board of health ordered the evacuation of neighborhoods plagued by yellow fever and began collecting mortality statistics to "furnish data for reflection and calculation." (Sometimes, though, epidemics were declared only belatedly because they were bad for business.)

RIGLER--Honorable William, 88, of Brooklyn passed away on Monday, September 10, 2012. Born in New York, NY on August 27, 1924 to Nathan and Pauline Rigler, he graduated from New Utrecht High School, a decorated veteran of World War II serving in the European Theater having earned five battle stars, graduated from Brooklyn College and Brooklyn Law School. From 1971 to 2000 he served as a Judge in Family Court and the dedicated matrimonial part of Kings County Brooklyn Supreme Court. He made landmark decisions concerning international custody; protecting women in Jewish divorces, one of his decisions became the basis for state legislation regarding religious divorces; and protecting the rights of HIV positive parents. He was the beloved and devoted husband of Hannah Sarah of 59 years, brother of Saul (Raleigh) and the late Harold and Charlotte, loving father of Lionel (Nancy Suchman) and Gail (Michael Milner), and cherished grandfather of Matthew and Danielle Milner. Services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Ave. (91st) on Wednesday September 12th at 10am. Shiva at Lottie Knoller's home 170 West End Avenue, Apt 18D on Wednesday, September 12th from 3pm to 9pm.

CHAIT--Marilyn. It is with great sadness that we share the passing of our beloved aunt, Marilyn Chait. Marilyn was born in Willimantic, CT but lived most of her life in New York City. Preceding Marilyn in death, were her loving husband Abraham Chait and her devoted brother and sister-in-law, Stanley and Esther Shapiro. Marilyn is survived by her niece Barbara Shapiro, her husband, Mark Lewis, and their daughter Nora and by her nephew George Shapiro, his wife, Sheila, and daughters Alissa and Rachel. For those wishing to attend a graveside service for Marilyn, join us on Thursday, September 13 at 1:30pm at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, 80 Commerce St., Hawthorne, NY.

KELTER--Joseph John, M.D.,91, of Edison, NJ died on Tuesday, September 11 at home. He was a physician with a private practice in Internal Medicine and Cardiology in Brooklyn for many years, retiring 12 years ago. He earned his M.D. degree from NYU. He was a veteran of the army during peace time from 1945 to 1947. Born in Middletown, CT, he lived in Brooklyn before moving to Edison 25 years ago. He is the beloved husband of the late Viola (nee Ades), father of Dr. Richard Kelter, Dr. Julie Timins-Lupatkin and the late Jonathan David Kelter, brother of the late Murray Kelter, grandfather of five, and great-grandfather of eight. Funeral services at Menorah Chapels, 2950 Vaux Hall Rd., Union, NJ on Wed., Sept. 12 at 11:30. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge.

As Spain tries desperately to meet its budget targets, it has been forced to embark on the same path as Greece introducing one austerity measure after another, cutting jobs, salaries, pensions and benefits, even as the economy continues to shrink.

The legal battle over a 45-year-old banana -- in this case, one that Andy Warhol created for the debut album by the Velvet Underground -- can continue, even after a federal judge threw out a portion of the suit brought by the band against Warhol's foundation. In January the Velvet Underground co-founders, Lou Reed and John Cale, sued the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts, saying it illegally licensed the familiar banana image Warhol designed for the cover of "The Velvet Underground & Nico" (the one that peeled away to reveal a pinkish-colored fruit underneath). The appearance of the image on costly iPad sleeves and other items, the band members said in their complaint, improperly suggested that they gave their "sponsorship or approval" to these products.

An article on Sept. 1 about the modern-day use of ice picks as weapons in crimes misstated part of the location of an attack last month involving an ice pick. It was in the Bronx at Perry Avenue and East 209th Street, not 208th Street.

Visiting hours on Wednesday, from 6-9pm.

It was an uneventful Week 1, in a good way, as the N.F.L. replacement referees did not steal much attention from the players on the field. There were the usual complaints and borderline calls, including a flag thrown on a textbook block in the back by Green Bay on Randall Cobb's touchdown return against San Francisco on Sunday. Instead, the referees picked up the flag, and the Packers' score counted. In Arizona, an inexcusable gaffe allowed Seattle to have four timeouts as they frantically attempted to tie the game. But both the Cardinals and the 49ers won, muting any cries about the replacement officials.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about Ron Taylor, a conservationist who shot footage of sharks for ''Jaws'' and other movies, referred incorrectly to the setting of ''Jaws.'' It takes place in the fictional town Amity Island -- not on Martha's Vineyard, although most of the movie was filmed there.

HARWOOD--Sibyl Hine, passed away on September 3, 2012, in Lebanon, NH. Born in 1917, she graduated from the Brearley School and Vassar College and carried with her a deep regard for the ideals of education all her life. She married Paul H. Harwood, M.D., and raised their four children: Frances, Catherine, Paul and Sibyl, in Fairfield, CT. In later years, she lived in Essex, CT, then in Hanover, NH. Her stories and love of fun will be fondly remembered by her family and all her numerous friends, both young and old. She was the devoted grandmother of Laurie Schuur Duncan, John Thorne-Thomsen, Jr., Mary B. Thorne-Thomsen, Sibyl Darcy Heintz-Perkins, and Paul H. Heintz, and great-grandmother of Emily and Molly Duncan. She is also survived by her daughters, Catherine and Sibyl Y. Harwood, who will miss her greatly. Contributions in her memory may be made to one of her favorite schools: The Man-O-War Primary School, Man-O-War Cay, Abaco, Bahamas. There will be a memorial service on Saturday, October 6, at 11:00am at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church, Fairfield, CT.

WALLACE--Mary. Died at her home in New York City on September 1, 2012 after a long illness. She was born Mary Olberg in 1929 in LaCrosse, Wisconsin, to Grace and Archie Olberg, and earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from Stephens College (MO) and a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Wisconsin (Madison). Mary was a model and muse for Emilio Pucci, helping to launch his fashion business and bringing his designs to the attention of the U.S. market. She then went to work in Paris for Vogue Magazine. After returning to the U.S., she became involved in the early days of the television industry, working to book and prepare talent for the television program created by Tex McCreary and Jinx Falkenberg. There she met Frederick Langdon (Ted) Yates, whom she married in 1954. They resided in Washington, DC and had three sons. Mr. Yates was killed in 1967 while on assignment for NBC News during the Arab-Israeli Six Day War. After Mr. Yates's death, Ms. Wallace worked as an independent documentary filmmaker and, from 1974 to 1980, as Executive Producer of the CBS News program "Face the Nation." In 1986, Ms. Wallace married CBS News correspondent Mike Wallace, who had partnered with Ted Yates on television projects in the 1950's, including the early broadcast interview program, Night Beat. They maintained homes in New York City and Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts. Mr. Wallace died in April of this year. She was serving on the advisory board of the International Mental Health Research Organization (IMHRO) at the time of her death. She was a co-founder of the Mike and Mary Wallace House, a journalistic fellowship center at the University of Michigan. In 1991 she was the first recipient of the national Family Achievement Award given by the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill (NAMI). Ms. Wallace is survived by two of her sons, Eames Yates and Angus Yates, and their wives. Her third son, Frederick Jr. (Teddy), died in 1998. She is also survived by two stepchildren, Pauline Dora and Chris Wallace, 11 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to: Citymeals-on-Wheels, 355 Lexington Avenue, NY 10017 or to the Wallace House at the University of Michigan, 3003 South State St, Suite 9000, Ann Arbor, MI 48109.

The architect Deborah Berke has been selected as the first recipient of a new $100,000 prize that honors the advancement of women in architecture. The inaugural 2012 Berkeley-Rupp Architecture Professorship and Prize , awarded by the University of California, Berkeley's College of Environmental Design, was announced Monday. The prize is to be awarded biannually to a practitioner or academic who also emphasizes a commitment to sustainability and the community.
Those in the international community who refuse to put red lines before Iran don't have a moral right to place a red light before Israel. BENJAMIN NETANYAHU,

If you know Jessica Lange only from her Emmy-nominated role as the mother from hell on "American Horror Story" you might think twice before sharing her handiwork with offspring of your own. But performers are not their characters -- nor has Ms. Lange ever worked on a soap opera with a co-star who turned out to be Dustin Hoffman in drag -- and now this Oscar- and Emmy-winning actress is about to become the author of a picture book for young readers. The Jabberwocky imprint of Sourcebooks said on Tuesday that it had acquired a book by Ms. Lange called "It Is About a Little Bird," which is based on a book that she created for her own grandchildren and which will use photographs that she took and illustrated by hand.

Deeply mourned by her beloved sister, Evelyn, brother-in-law Eddie and nephew Rudi and a wide circle of friends. Predeceased by her husband Ted Frederick Castle of New York. Formerly of St. Patricks Training College, Drumcondra, also Washington D.C., New York City and Tragumna, Skibbereen. Funeral on Friday at 2pm in Woodtown Cemetery, Oldcourt Road, Dublin 24.

ZBOROWSKI--Eli, Founder and Chairman of the American & International Societies for Yad Vashem, died on September 10th at the age of 86. He was predeceased by Diana, his loving wife of 57 years. Eli was born in Zarki, Poland. At age 14, he joined the Jewish underground, serving in the dangerous role of courier to the ghettos in western Poland. Together with his mother and younger brother and sister, he survived the war with the help of two Christian families who hid them from the Nazis. His father was murdered during the war. Identifying opportunities and stepping in wherever he was needed became the foundation of his communal and business careers. Following liberation he rescued 100 Holocaust orphans, leading them to the DP camp in Feldafing, Germany, where he established a model youth center. Identifying such opportunities, in the face of seemingly insurmountable odds, he triumphed brilliantly. He came to the United States in 1952 and began by peddling camera parts and within a decade he became president of Sheaffer Pen Latin America. Eli was in the forefront of Holocaust Remembrance in the United States. His remarkable journey from survivor to entrepreneur to communal leader led him to: Open the door to resumption of diplomatic relations between Israel and Poland following the Six-Day War; Inaugurate the first synagogue-based Yom Hashoah (Holocaust Remembrance Day) in 1964; Organize the first umbrella organization of Holocaust survivors in 1970; Publish Martyrdom and Resistance, the first newspaper devoted to Holocaust issues; Establish the world's first academic chair in Holocaust studies at Yeshiva University; Found and chair the American & International Societies for Yad Vashem, an organization with 50,000 members that has raised over $100 million for Yad Vashem; Establish the Diana Zborowski Center for the Study of the Aftermath of the Shoah at Yad Vashem. To ensure the memory of the Holocaust in the future, Eli spearheaded the Young Leadership Associates of the American Society for Yad Vashem that will shepherd the cause of remembrance from generation to generation. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Elizabeth Mundlak Zborowski, his children, Dr. Lilly Zborowski Naveh and Murry Zborowski, his grandchildren, Ori, Tamar, Maya, Shira, Omer, Boaz, Ariel, Zohar, and Erez, his brother Marvin, and his sister Tzila. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Leonard Wilf, Chairman, Board of Trustees, American Society for Yad Vashem

From an old mansion on Mirza Ismail Road in Jaipur, India, the jeweler Munnu Kasliwal presided over an unlikely global empire. To the broader public Mr. Kasliwal's name was not nearly as familiar as those of Cartier or Harry Winston, but his family-owned emporium, the Gem Palace , has for decades been a valued secret passed along via word of mouth by international connoisseurs. Collected by European royals, Italian designers, Arab sheiks, international society queens and the merely moneyed, who could find his designs for sale at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Neue Galerie in Manhattan as well as at Barneys New York, Mr. Kasliwal's baubles were also particular favorites of celebrities, whom he cultivated with unassuming charm.

An article on Tuesday about the plasma arc gasification method of waste disposal misstated part of the name of the organization with which Allen Hershkowitz, a scientist who said he believed that New York City's low recycling rate makes its interest in waste-to-energy technology premature, is affiliated. Mr. Hershkowitz is with the Natural Resources Defense Council, not the National Resources Defense Council.

An obituary on Thursday about the engineer Jack Cermak referred incorrectly to his military service. While he did serve in the Army during World War II, he did not achieve the rank of lieutenant colonel at that time. (He was later a lieutenant colonel in the Army Reserve.)

Robert S. McNamara, secretary of defense during both the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, turns out to have been a meticulous pack rat. Next month Sotheby's is auctioning off his personal memorabilia, including letters, many of them annotated in McNamara's own hand; photographs; the flag and globe from his office at the Defense Department; a collection of North Vietnamese propaganda; crib notes he made before appearing in "The Fog of War," the Errol Morris documentary; and three albums containing the original drawings of editorial cartoons about him, a great many of them unfavorable. A lot of McNamara material has already gone to presidential libraries, according to Selby Kiffer, senior vice-president of books and manuscripts at Sotheby's. The 600 or so items which the auction house will sell off in 100 lots are ones he chose to keep with him at his apartment in the Watergate and his house in Virginia.

GELLMAN--Gloria, died peacefully on September 9, 2012. Beloved sister, aunt and friend. Services private.

STEBBINS--Edward Clinton, 82, of New Canaan, CT, died Wednesday August 29, 2012. "Ned" Stebbins fought Parkinson's Disease in his final years and was able to pass peacefully at the Meadow Ridge Retirement Community in Redding, CT. Ned was born February 26, 1930 in Niagara Falls, NY, the son of Dr. Edward C. Stebbins and Hope (Blodgett) Stebbins. He graduated with distinction from St. Paul's School (1947), Williams College (1951), and Harvard Law School (1954), where he was Law Review Editor. On July 17, 1954, Ned married Bernadine Schildge at her home in Gouverneur, NY. The couple moved to Charlottesville, VA where Ned was serving in the U.S. Army, teaching at the Judge Advocate General (JAG) School at the University of Virginia. After serving three years, Ned moved his family to Connecticut and joined the New York law firm Sullivan & Cromwell practicing corporate litigation. In 1964, Ned joined Freeport Sulphur where he remained for 25 years until his retirement in 1989. At Freeport, Ned held various senior management positions, helping transform the company into the global resources firm of Freeport McMoRan, Inc. (FMI) through dozens of innovative acquisitions, partnerships and restructurings. In 1984, FMI relocated to New Orleans, LA and Ned was promoted to General Counsel and a member of the firm's Operating Committee. After retirement, Ned became an active volunteer at the Norwalk Hospital, Waveny Care Center and the New Canaan Library. He also teamed up at the Norwalk Yacht Club, rowing for "The Ancient and the Honorable," winning numerous senior competitions in the U.S. and Europe. An avid historian, Ned was a hereditary member of the Revolutionary War organization, the Society of the Cincinnati. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Bernadine, and his brother, John Stebbins of Scarborough, ME; three children, Victoria Frelow of Nyack, NY, Charles Stebbins of Fairfield, CT and Robert Stebbins of Weston, CT; and six grandchildren. A memorial reception will be held on Saturday, September 22 at noon at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations in Ned's memory can be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.

SAN FRANCISCO - Mark Zuckerberg spoke to a hometown crowd here Tuesday afternoon, acknowledging his company's "disappointing" performance on Wall Street, hinting at new moneymaking strategies, and casting his company as one that continued to build new things in the face of criticism. "I would rather be in the cycle where people underestimate us," he said at an annual conference sponsored by TechCrunch, the technology blog.

NOCERA--Anthony C.,87, of Nokomis, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died on September 11, 2012. A World War II Army Air Corps Veteran of the 15th Air Force, he earned the European Theatre Ribbon with four battle stars and will be interred in the Sarasota National Cemetery. Survivors include his wife of 62 years, Louise Nocera of Nokomis, FL; sons Robert (Pamela) Nocera of Roswell, GA and John Nocera of New York, NY; sister Mildred Bonino of Brooklyn, NY; brothers Ralph (Kathy) Nocera of Forest Hills, NY and John (Nancy) Nocera, Jr. of Astoria, NY; six grandchildren, Christopher, Britain, Joy, Keith, Michael, and Ginger; and one great- grandchild, Grace.

The Museum of Modern Art announced on Wednesday that it would exhibit Christian Marclay's wildly popular video installation, "The Clock," which won the Golden Lion award at the 2011 Venice Biennale. "The Clock," most recently shown in New York at the Lincoln Center Festival this summer, uses thousands of film excerpts from car chases, bank robberies, high-noon shootouts, romantic pairings and more to chronicle the minutes and hours of one 24-hour period. The installation will run from Dec. 21 through Jan. 21. The museum plans to keep its contemporary galleries open round-the-clock on three weekends in January to show "The Clock" in its entirety.

GLAZER--Mia, age 94, died on September 12, 2012 after a long, full and eventful life. She was the widow of the late David Glazer, a world-renowned clarinetist, and loving mother of Paul and Peter Brest. She adored, and was adored by, her grandchildren, Hilary Meltzer, Jeremy, Matthew, Phillip and Eric Brest, and her great-grandchildren, Julia and Elijah Meltzer, and Aaron, Adam and Joshua Brest. Mia was born in Vienna at the end of WWI. Immersed in the city's musical and intellectual life, she escaped to America just after the Nazis marched into Austria and spent the first decade in Jacksonville, FL, where she married Alexander Brest, a local businessman. She later moved to New York City and married David, who brought her both love and a house full of music. She became a professional photographer but was always, first and foremost, a gracious Viennese hostess. She was a lifelong liberal, worried about the state of the world and the less fortunate. She will be greatly missed by her family and friends. The funeral will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Friday, September 14 at 9:45am. Gifts in her memory may be made to: Camp Treetops/North Country School at: www.camptreetops.org. or the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty at: www.metcouncil.org

LEIBOWITZ--David S.,passed away September 11, 2012 after a long illness. He had a wonderful career for over 45 years on Wall Street as a Financial Analyst - Vice President of Research for Horizon Kinetics, known for his work with the toy industry, cruise industry and special situations. Survived by his wife Wendy and brother Howard.

A TREND so big it's an option in hair salons, the ombré look is now having a moment in denim. A more subtle spin on summer's crazy-print jeans, the dip-dye styles are also more versatile. The stylist Kusum Lynn suggests wearing them with a loose tank or chambray shirt and a Rick Owens-style leather jacket. ''Keep it casual and effortless-looking with a little tuck of the shirt at the front of the jeans,'' she said. ''Pair with high-heeled ankle boots, a satchel bag and, for a little toughness, some chunky metal bracelets.'' From left: Rag & Bone ombré jeans, $220 at Bergdorf Goodman; ( 800) 558-1855 ; Levi's Made & Crafted ombré jeans, $198 at Smith + Butler, 225 Smith Street, Brooklyn, (718) 855-4295; Balmain ombré jeans, $680 at ssense.com ; Helmut Lang

An article on Aug. 1 about a caseworker at the city's Human Resources Administration who asked a welfare recipient to watch his pet ferret misstated the circumstances under which his employment ended. The worker, Kempe Hope, resigned as part of a settlement with the agency and the city's Conflicts of Interest Board in which he admitted to misconduct. He was not fired. (The error was brought to The Times's attention this week by Mr. Hope.)

A motorist survived a 40-foot plunge into a construction pit in Brooklyn on Wednesday after she struck a bicyclist with her sport utility vehicle, lost control, hit several other vehicles and crashed through a plywood barrier along Coney Island Avenue in Midwood, according to witnesses and Fire Department officials. The woman, who was not immediately identified, was rescued by construction workers and was taken to Kings County Hospital Center with injuries that were not life-threatening, a Fire Department spokesman said. Another person sustained non-life-threatening injuries and was taken to Maimonides Medical Center, the Fire Department said.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about big-box retailers' use of renewable energy misidentified the location of a Walmart distribution center that will be partly powered by a wind turbine. It is in Red Bluff, Calif. -- not in Pittsburg.

SIMON--Robert G.,85, passed away September 8, 2012 at his home in Pelham, NY. Bob, from New Rochelle, graduated Cornell University in 1947 and Georgetown Law in 1950. He was a WWII veteran. He was a senior VP at McCann-Erickson and became the Chief Broadcast Attorney at the Interpublic Group of Companies. Bob was president of the NY Chapter of the Television Academy (1981-2) and a trustee of the National Academy. Bob was a founder of the Pelham Guidance Council, legal consultant to the Hemlock Society and an arbitrator in New Rochelle small claims court. Bob is survived by his wife of 62 years, Norma (Plavnick), his son, Mark of NYC, daughter Susan of California, grandson Gabriel of NYC and many others. Bob's singular wit and sense of humor brought great pleasure to all who knew him. The family will be at home of his son Friday, September 14th, from 4-8pm and on Saturday, September 15th, 1-6pm at the family home in Pelham.

Updated, 11:16 p.m. |A 73-year-old woman was raped and beaten in Central Park just before noon on Wednesday, the police said, and the attacker's assault was preceded by a chilling question: "Do you remember me?" The woman, a bird-watcher who goes to the park every day, had indeed encountered the man before. About a week and a half ago, she had seen him masturbating in the Ramble area and taken a photograph of him. The man demanded that the woman delete the photo at the time, and when she refused, he tried unsuccessfully to take her camera, the Police Department's chief spokesman, Paul J. Browne, said. Late Wednesday, the police said investigators were questioning of person of interest.

An article on Sept. 4 about the decline of union jobs in the private sector in New York City misstated the number of construction jobs that the city had lost in the past four years. It was 23,000, according to the Fiscal Policy Institute, not 59,000 (that is the number lost statewide).

TORONTO - The front-loaded schedule at the Toronto International Film Festival has yielded a few expected payoffs and a few unpredicted ones. Eagerly-awaited movies like Ben Affleck's "Argo" (which earned good word-of-mouth at a sneak preview at the Telluride Film Festival last month ) delivered, earning a standing ovation at its packed premiere on Friday. Reviews called the film, about the Iranian hostage crisis in the 1970s, Mr. Affleck's coming-of-age moment as an actor-director. At the after-party last week, Mr. Affleck was jovial, ordering pizza and chatting with friends like Matt Damon, John Krasinski and Emily Blunt late into the night. He talked eagerly about shooting at CIA headquarters in Langley, Va., but admitted to some worry that the geo-political theme would make the film "challenging" to market. "I'm working harder to promote this movie," he said. "I can furnish you with endless" material. (We will expect it.) The two big-budget, big-expectation tentpoles, " Cloud Atlas " (from the Wachowski siblings and Tom Tykwer, distributed by Warner) and " The Master " (from Paul Thomas Anderson, and released by the Weinstein Company) had audiences waiting for hours and industry speculating. "Cloud Atlas" played well at its premiere on Saturday night, although some reviews called the nearly three-hour historical sci-fi fantasy movie muddled. And "The Master," which won several top prizes at the Venice Film Festival on Saturday, was praised for its visual sophistication and performances by Joaquin Phoenix and Philip Seymour Hoffman, but also criticized for being too cerebral.

ALBANY - Following mass shootings this summer in Colorado and Wisconsin, a majority of voters in New York State favor more stringent laws restricting the purchase of guns, according to a poll released Wednesday . Sixty-one percent of voters said they believed the state's laws pertaining to gun sales should be stricter, according to the poll, conducted by Quinnipiac University. And 68 percent of voters said they supported limiting handgun purchases to one per person per month.

LEVINE--Beverly Ann Greenfeder, of Ardsley, NY. Beloved mother of Michael, Richard and Susan and grandmother of Emily, Daniel, Brian and Rachel. Devoted to her family, community and the NY Yankees. Services Saturday at noon at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry, NY.

SCHMERLER--Isabel R. of Tenafly, NJ and Portland, ME, died September 10 after a year-long battle with Myelodysplastic Syndrome. Mrs. Schmerler was an artist and a retired executive of ABC News. Mrs. Schmerler was born in 1942 in New York, the daughter of Alex and Ida Schwartz. She graduated magna cum laude from Brooklyn College, where she studied Romance languages and art. After graduation, she worked for NBC News. She later became managing director of production and finance for ABC News. She retired in 1999 to devote herself full-time to her artwork. Her watercolors of Maine and France were exhibited last year in a one-woman show. She is survived by her husband of 44 years, David Schmerler, a retired NBC television news executive; brother Laurence Schwartz; sisters-in-law Gladys Demick and Ruth Schwartz; nieces Barbara Demick, Diane Bindler and Ellen Schwartz; and nephew Steven Schwartz. Funeral services will be held Sunday, September 16 at 10:30am at Gutterman and Muiscant Jewish Funeral Directors. 402 Park Street Hackensack, NJ Telephone 1-800-522-0588 (www.guttermanandmusicant.com.) Burial will follow at the Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. In place of flowers, the family suggests contributions to the Villa Marie Claire Hospice of Saddle River, NJ where Mrs. Schmerler spent the last days of her life in tranquility. http://www.villamarieclaire.org/support.asp.

The Paul Taylor Dance Company will be among the many arts groups celebrating the 100th anniversary of Stravinsky's "Rite of Spring" in the coming year. The troupe will revive Mr. Taylor's "Sacre Du Printemps (The Rehearsal)" as part of its spring season, which will run from March 5 to 24 at Lincoln Center, the company announced. The engagement will also include the New York premiere of "Make Crops Grow," to music by Ferde Grofé, as well as the world premiere of Mr. Taylor's 138th dance. Among the pieces will be one having its 50th anniversary, "Scudorama," and two that are having their 25th, "Brandenburgs" and "Speaking in Tongues." A celebration of the two 25th-anniversary pieces will take place on March 6, when every seat in David H. Koch Theater will cost just $5. The season will feature 21 dances.

The City Room column on Monday, about the 1928 arraignment of the actor W. C. Fields, who was charged with torturing a canary, misstated the trajectory of his career up to that time. While he had lost top billing and had no movie contract at the time of his arraignment, he had previously achieved fame in the movie industry. It is not the case that ''Fields was not yet a movie star.'' (Fields left court a free man and again became a top star in the 1930s.)

He was predeceased by his wife; his parents, Noble and Dorothy Brice; five siblings, Noble Brice, Jr., Elsie Owens, Gloria Brice, Joseph Brice and Shirley Brice. Surviving are his step-sons, Chris Gooding and Tim Gooding; two brothers, Maurice Brice and David Brice; and two sisters, Linda Brice and April Hinton. All services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Cow Neck Peninsula Historical Society, 336 Port Washington Blvd., Port Washington, NY 11050.

An article on Tuesday about new labor issues at Foxconn, a Chinese factory that makes Apple products, misstated the number of explosions that have occurred at the company's plants. Only one explosion has occurred at a Foxconn plant, not ''several.'' (There have been several explosions at other companies that make Apple products in China.)
