An article on Sept. 2 about new developments in the Court Square area of Long Island City misspelled the given name of a broker who works in the area. He is Doron Zwickel, not Doran.

KAPLAN--Henry Paul, MD, JD, died on September 9, 2012 at home in Saratoga, CA, age 77, of melanoma. Henry was a devoted husband and father and beloved grandfather. He is survived by his wife of 54 years Marcia Orol Kaplan and sons Joshua (Stefanie Fox), Seth (Kari Danziger), Daniel (Lyn Katzman) and Jonathan (Suzanne Heald); eight grandchildren; and brother M. Howard Kaplan (Joyce Gumbiner). Predeceased by one grandson. Henry was born April 17, 1935 in Brooklyn, NY to Louis and Rose Steigman Kaplan. He graduated from Erasmus High School, the College of William Mary in 1956, Harvard Law School in 1959, and Downstate Medical Center - Brooklyn in 1965. Henry practiced medicine at the San Jose Medical Group until 1990, then as its general counsel until 2001. He retired from private law practice in 2007. Henry authored numerous publications, recently blogging on health care, and was a frequent speaker on medical and legal topics. Henry was a strong supporter of Israel and Jewish causes. His interest in the history of Kohanim and his family through genetic genealogy inspired him to locate "cousins" around the world. He also was an accomplished woodworker of furniture and toys for his grandchildren.

FILM FORUM caps its summer of French old wave films with a D.C.P. (digital cinema package) restoration of Marcel Carné's 1938 ''PORT OF SHADOWS'' (''Quai des Brumes''). The movie drips with prewar romantic fatalism whose emblem could be Michèle Morgan's Nelly, hands stuffed into the pockets of her trench coat, its folds catching the light just so. The restoration gives renewed clarity and luster to the black-and-white mist-slicked night world of Le Havre, where Jean Gabin's runaway soldier holes up at Panama's, a waterfront dive housing a collection of misfits. Better a misfit, though, than a bourgeois creep, like Michel Simon's shopkeeper, or a bourgeois rebel like Pierre Brasseur's cowardly gangster.

IT'S not an exaggeration to say that almost everyone wants to see the labeling of genetically engineered materials contained in their food products. And on Nov. 6, in what's unquestionably among the most important non-national votes this year, Californians will have the opportunity to make that happen - at least in theory - by weighing in on Proposition 37. Prop 37's language is clear on two points: it would require "labeling on raw or processed food offered for sale to consumers if made from plants or animals with genetic material changed in specified ways." And it would prohibit marketing "such food, or other processed food, as 'natural.' " (For now, let's ignore the vast implications of the phrase "or other processed food," lest we become overexcited, except to say that the literal interpretation of that sentence has the processed food manufacturers' collective hair on fire.)

Eli Zborowski, a survivor of the Holocaust who made it his mission to ensure that it would never be forgotten, founded an American organization to support Israel's official Holocaust memorial and raised more than $100 million for it, died on Monday in Queens. He was 86. The cause was cardiac arrest, said Rochel Berman, who, with her husband, George, published a biography of Mr. Zborowski last year.

WITH ''DEATH AND THE CIVIL WAR,'' an installment of PBS's ''American Experience'' on Tuesday night (check local listings), what hits you early on is a breathtaking figure that is even more startling so close to the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks. To lose the same proportion of the population today as died in the Civil War, the historian Drew Gilpin Faust says, would mean seven million deaths. Everyone remembers how deeply those 2001 losses traumatized the nation; it is almost impossible to imagine the effects that the Civil War casualties must have had on Americans of the 1860s. The program is interested not in the troop movements and changes in commanders that preoccupy most Civil War documentaries, but in how the country reacted to the shocking death toll. When the war began, it notes, the infrastructure for dealing with mass death -- including the simple notion that the government has an obligation to notify families when a soldier is killed -- was not in place. Nor were psychological coping mechanisms. Society had an ideal of dignified death: peaceful, at home, surrounded by loved ones. The gruesome deaths on Civil War battlefields must have been quite a jolt to the collective American mind.

The weekend-long festivals by the London promoter All Tomorrow's Parties have often been in faded vacation spots -- English holiday camps and their counterparts in the Catskills and Atlantic City. As musical experiences the American events have been blissful but not boffo; costs ran high and attendance ran low . So the company is trying a new model with ALL TOMORROW'S PARTIES AMERICA PRESENTS I'LL BE YOUR MIRROR -- nearly 40 acts across three days at Pier 36, an entertainment complex on the Lower East Side. Frank Ocean, the R&B man of the hour, headlines on Friday, after a day including the comedian Hannibal Buress, a collaboration between Tyondai Braxton and Philip Glass, and Lee Ranaldo's ''Hanging Guitar'' project, involving suspended, swinging Fender Jaguars. The reunited Afghan Whigs headline next Saturday, and other bands that day include the Roots, José González, Dirty Three and Chavez; for next Sunday the organizers have a slate including Godspeed You! Black Emperor, along with the Make-Up, the Washington punk-soul band, in reunited form. 5 p.m. to 1 a.m. Friday; noon to 1 a.m. next Saturday and Sunday; South and Montgomery Streets; atpfestival.com ; $60 to $199.
Manhattan

The Local Stop column in some editions last Sunday, about the Fordham Road subway station in the Bronx, misidentified the northern boundary of the Grand Concourse. It is Mosholu Parkway, not Van Cortlandt Park.

The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about Yasuo Matsui, the Japanese-born architect who helped design 40 Wall Street and the Starrett-Lehigh Building, misstated the name of a project he worked on in 1931. It was the Whist Club, not the Regency Whist Club.

NIGRINE--Henry. On September 9, 2012 in Olney, MD. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy B. Nigrine. Survived by children Jenny Spillman and Jon Nigrine, and four grandsons. Memorial gathering Saturday, October 27, 1-3PM at Barber Funeral Home, 21525 Laytonsville Road, Laytonsville, MD. Memorial gifts may be made to The Juillard School. More information at: Barberfhlaytonsville.com.

SMITH--Kathleen B.,of Coral Gables, Florida passed away on September 7, 2012 at University of Miami Hospital after a four year battle with Hodgkin's Lymphoma and MDS. KB was born in Staten Island, NY, the daughter of Philip and Eileen Brown. She attended the University of Salamanca in Spain and was a graduate of Springfield College in MA. She spent her entire career with Marsh & McLennan Companies in New York and Miami. Most recently, she was a Managing Director and Latin American Regional Head of Placement and Marketing and Communications for Marsh Inc. Kathleen is survived by her Husband of 31 years, Stephen L. Smith; Children, Stephanie and Timothy; her Mother, Sisters, Suzanne, Lisa and Victoria; Brothers, Barry and PJ. The Family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in her name to The American Cancer Society, The University of Miami Miller School of Medicine, or The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society. The Family also asks that all who can, register to become a bone marrow donor by registering with the National Marrow Donor Program. A celebration of her life is planned for October 20, 2012 at 10:30 a.m. at St. Thomas Episcopal Parish, Coral Gables. The family has entrusted her care to Van Orsdel Funeral Home-Kendall Chapel 11220 North Kendall Drive. Miami, Fl. 33176. (305)279-6644. www.vanorsdel.com

An article on Aug. 12 about the composer Pauline Oliveros misstated her involvement with the San Francisco Tape Music Center, a scrappy hub of musical creativity and technological advance founded by Ramon Sender and Morton Subotnick. Ms. Oliveros collaborated with Mr. Sender and Mr. Subotnick before the center's founding but was out of the country when it was formally established and became involved when she returned. She was not one of the center's founders. The article also misstated the year the center was established. It was 1962, not 1961.

An article on Sept. 2 about the changing roles of men and women in the economy, as experienced by a number of families in Alexander City, Ala., misstated the time it takes to drive from Alexander City to Montgomery, Ala., where some people have found work. It is about an hour, not three hours. And a contributors' note on the contents page for the author of the article, Hanna Rosin, gave an outdated name for a publication where she is a senior editor. It is The Atlantic, not The Atlantic Monthly. (She is also with Slate.)

FOR worshipers of Mozart's Serenade No. 10 for 13 instruments, the ''Gran Partita,'' this concert sounds as if it falls somewhere between sacrilege and gimmick. But maybe we should give it a chance. The ST. LUKE'S CHAMBER ENSEMBLE'S superb wind players are performing the work's seven movements interspersed with Ligeti's Six Bagatelles for wind quintet. The ''Gran Partita'' is a glorious piece for pairs of oboes, clarinets, basset horns (lower members of the clarinet family) and bassoons, as well as four French horns and a double bass. The Ligeti work is charming, engaging and extremely well made, but from an entirely different universe. If anything, the rich sonorities of the dark, flute-less larger wind grouping may lay bare the sparse texture of the wind quintet combination. The organizers suggest that the millisecond of surprise at hearing an unexpected movement will help the audience hear ''just music and not something old, new, standard or nonstandard.'' Maybe. On the other hand, ''just Mozart'' is pretty good too. With set design by Anne Patterson, a visual artist, and lighting design by Matt Frey. 8 p.m. Thursday and Friday, Baryshnikov Arts Center, 450 West 37th Street, Manhattan; (866) 811-4111, bacnyc.org ; $25.

An article last Sunday about Playwrights Horizons' coming season misidentified the director of the opening play, ''Detroit,'' which was a Pulitzer Prize finalist last year. The director is Anne Kauffman -- not Austin Pendleton, who has directed the play at the Steppenwolf Theater in Chicago and at the National Theater in London.

This summer, a case of mistaken identity earned me a seat at a formal dinner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The invitation - to an intimate evening with the museum's president - was addressed to a good friend of mine. It certainly seemed like an extravagant perk, but his $100 membership renewal was coming due. Maybe times were tough, he reasoned, and the museum was rolling out the red carpet to keep even its smallest contributors. He replied that he would be delighted to attend. But there was another name on the invitation, one he didn't recognize. Could he bring someone else - his friend Jon Methven - instead? Of course he could; the Met sent a confirmation on official museum letterhead.

GOODSTEIN--Arlene, of Manhattan, passed away Saturday September 8th. College Professor, respected teacher. Gallery educator at the Museum of Jewish Heritage. Central Park was her oasis and refuge. Arlene led a life of style and grace. Impassioned mother and grandmother. Survived by children, Larry and Paget Berger, Vivian Goodstein, Shari Goodstein and Craig Lambert, grandchildren Zach, Sara, Rebecca, Aaron, Joshua, and Juliette, and brother Jerome Hornblass. Donations in her memory may be made to the Museum of Jewish Heritage.

JOSEPH ALTUZARRA'S downtown studio was thumping to the track ''Pull Marine'' by Isabelle Adjani during preparations for the Altuzarra spring runway show, which took place on Sept. 8. Images of sand dunes and ballerinas performing ''The Arabian Nights'' were on the designer's mood board. ''We've never built a piece with embroidery in mind before,'' said Mr. Altuzarra (pictured left), pointing to the series of dresses that were inspired, more specifically, by a scene from the film ''Orlando'' in which the protagonist wakes up as a woman in a Tuareg desert tribe. The dress he was fitting that day is one of these. ''It's incredibly complicated to hand-sew it all: no two will be alike,'' he said of the curious conglomeration of peplumed striped linens, blue silk covered in Swarovski crystals and sunburst embroideries, and gold-plated tassels glistening from every end. ''Usually you find these very elaborate and delicate embroideries on silks and very couture fabrics,'' Mr. Altuzarra said, ''but I wanted to try it on nubby and hand-woven cottons.'' CHELSEA ZALOPANY

An entry in the December film listings in the New Season issue last Sunday for ''The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey,'' using information from a publicist, erroneously included five actors among those who will appear in the first of what is a planned trilogy. Orlando Bloom, Evangeline Lilly, Lee Pace, Luke Evans and Benedict Cumberbatch will not be in the film.

The cover article on Sept. 2 about driving a circuit of ancient towns near Moscow , Russia 's Golden Ring , misidentified the instrument the author used to determine she had gone more than 800 miles; it was an odometer, which measures distance -- not a speedometer.

PATTERSON--Edward, 91, died peacefully at Lenox Hill hospital on September 11, 2012. Son of Arthur C. Patterson and Evelyn Crimmins Patterson. Attended St. Marks School and Yale University class of 1943. In 1946 he married Joan Metzger, step daughter of the late E.F. Hutton. He began his career as an associate at E.F. Hutton and in 1956 joined Allen & Company as a director for the remainer of his career which ended in 2007. Ned was a long-time close friend to Charles and Herbert Allen, served as president of Deepdale Golf Club and was an avid Yankees fan. He is survived by his three daughters, Patricia Patterson Kean, Lucinda Dear Patterson and Christina Patterson Fay. His late daughter Elizabeth Burgett Patterson passed away in 1998. He is survived by his eight grandchildren. His late grandson Robert W. Kean IV passed away in 2011. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Lighthouse International www.lighthouse.org, or contact dbrickman@lighthouse.org

Before it became the highest form of culinary praise to describe something as ''trés Brooklyn,'' before the resonance of a sentence like ''X is a writer living in Brooklyn'' could be lost on virtually no one, there was the work of Paula Fox. Beloved when she arrived on the scene, Ms. Fox was forgotten, and then her work was cultishly pored over at the dawn of the new millennium. It is high time that the Big City Book Club read her most-celebrated novel, ''Desperate Characters,'' published in 1970. The plot follows a middle-class Brooklyn Heights couple as their relationship bears the strains of the city's declining fortunes. Club members can join the discussion live with questions and comments on Oct. 10.

THE Republican and Democratic conventions weren't merely forums for the presidential candidates to attract voters. They were also chances for the host cities, Tampa, Fla., and Charlotte, N.C., to reap economic benefits from an onslaught of visitors. Those cashing in included vendors selling campaign-related wares like pins, T-shirts, cutout figures and dolls featuring the race's dramatis personae. Will saving these trifles make anyone rich in the future? It doesn't seem likely. What might be considered a prime find now -- an 1864 campaign pin for Abraham Lincoln's re-election, as the Civil War raged -- is valued at less than $1,000 . Still, it probably wouldn't hurt to hang on to a 2012 ''Mitt Happens'' button or a Michelle Obama cutout doll to see what it's worth in 20 years.

An article on Sept. 2 about the brand-conscious Web comedy series ''Srsly'' misstated part of the name of the branded-content behemoth for which Barry Blumberg is the executive vice president. It is Alloy Digital, not Alloy Entertainment.

The 36 Hours column on Sept. 2 about Sofia , Bulgaria , misstated the country code for Les Fleurs hotel. It is 359, not 35. (The number is 359-2-8-100-800.) And the column, using information from the nightclub Kino Vlaikova, misidentified a beer offered there. It is Pirinsko -- not Zagorka, which the club no longer serves.

MEYER--Barbara S.,92, of Dover Plains, NY died suddenly on September 1 at Sharon Hospital, Sharon, CT. Barbara was the wife of the late Schuyler M. Meyer, who predeceased her in 1997. A memorial service will be held 1pm Sunday, September 23 at Millbrook School Chapel, Millbrook, NY. Memorial donations may be made to Millbrook Rescue Squad, PO Box 609, Millbrook, NY 12545.

Even when journalists throw the rare hardball question to a candidate, I've noticed that they almost never follow up with another hardball after the candidate ducks. Despite the work by fact-checking organizations, reporters often quote obvious lies and distortions by both sides in their ''he said, she said'' reporting. Why do journalists choose to highlight these distortions by repeating them? Why spend so much time reporting on candidates' obvious gaffes, which any human being is bound to commit from time to time, rather than attempting to represent fairly and accurately the real policy positions candidates are attempting to communicate? ELLEN HERSHEY, Albany, Calif., posted on nytimes.com
An obituary last Sunday about the theologian Gabriel Vahanian misstated the given names of two members of his family. His son is Paul-Michel, not Jean-Michel, and his father was Mesrop, not Mestrop.
WALLACH--Richard W. Hon. 9/16/27-6/1/03 Loved on your birthday and every day by your Marli.

The Neighborhood Joint column in some editions last Sunday, about the Modern Art Foundry in Astoria, Queens, referred incorrectly to a program there in which Victor Velastegui teaches high school and college students. The program is sponsored by two nonprofit organizations for the arts; Mr. Velastegui does not rent part of the space for private classes for the students.

The Rif column on Sept. 2, about Michael Jackson's album ''Thriller,'' omitted a word n a quotation from Jackson's autobiography, ''Moonwalk.'' The full quotation should have read,'''Thriller' sounded so crappy to me that tears came to my eyes,'' not ''came my eyes.''

A brief article in the New Season film section last Sunday about Lizzy Caplan, who stars in the new movie ''Bachelorette,'' misidentified the actor who appears with her in the Showtime pilot ''Masters of Sex,'' about the sex researchers Masters and Johnson. He is Michael Sheen, not Martin Sheen. And the credit with an accompanying picture of Ms. Caplan misidentified the source of the photograph. It is Radius - TWC, not the Weinstein Company.

KOSS--Leopold G. MD, passed away at his home in New York City, September 11, 2012. Born in Gdansk, Poland in 1920, Leo (as he was known to all who loved him) miraculously survived the Holocaust and became a refugee in Switzerland where he finished the medical studies he had started in Vienna before the War and continued in Brussels and Montpellier. When he arrived in New York in 1947 with his wife and baby son and $20 in his pocket, he spoke no English. Yet, with his prodigious intellect and devotion to science, he rose to the top of his field in his adopted country. He was a pioneer in the field of Cytopathology and was the author of the seminal book on the subject, "Diagnostic Cytology and It's Histopathologic Bases," which appeared in five editions and was recently translated into Chinese. Over his long career, he also wrote numerous other medical books and hundreds of scientific papers. Dr. Koss was chairman emeritus of the Department of Pathology at Montefiore Hospital and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, which was renamed in his honor. He will be remembered by all who knew him as a man of great intelligence, culture and wit. He was a gifted storyteller who could, depending on his audience, recite French love poetry, sing bawdy ditties or quote Caesar's Gallic Wars in the original Latin. He is survived by his three sons, Michael, Andrew, and Richard as well as four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on October 26 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his honor to the Visiting Nurse Service of NYC whose dedicated employees cared for him at the end of his life with unquestioned respect and love.

GORDON--Joni September 24, 1936 -- September 11, 2012. Joni passed away peacefully after suffering a massive brain hemorrhage on September 1, 2012 at the family vacation home in Central Oregon. She is survived by her husband Monte, son John, daughter-in-law Sun Xin, and grandchildren Dean and Otis. Joni was born in Cleveland, OH, the daughter of the late Helen Epstein and Jerome Toffler, and at nine moved to Los Angeles and attended Fairburn Elementary, Emerson Jr. High, University High and UCLA. She was the director of Newspace Gallery in Hollywood for more than 38 years where she discovered, showed and mentored numerous Los Angeles-based contemporary artists, many of whom have become nationally and internationally recognized. Joni's life contributions are part of the history of the visual arts in the United States and may be found in the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution as well as in articles in the Los Angeles Times and other publications. Services will be held at 10am, Sunday, September 16, 2012 at Hillside Memorial Park, 6001 W. Centinela, LA. If a tangible form of tribute is desired, in lieu of flowers, a donation may be made in her name to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society.
LABIANCA--Vincent, MUNOZ--Isabel. Ten years. Still true. No one ever dies who lives in hearts left behind.

A picture caption last Sunday with the Big Deal column, about Chinese buyers in New York City , referred incorrectly to the address of a building in Battery Park City where the lobby was designed with feng shui in mind. It is 225 Rector Place (not Street).

KATZ--Pearl, 95, September 12, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Katz and mother of Leonard, aunt and great-aunt, but always a child at heart. Remembrance gathering Friday, 1pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St.

COX--John P. John P. Cox, 65, died on September 12 from complications following a stroke. Until recently he was Vice-President and Chief Information Officer for the Hospital for Special Surgery. His gregariousness, warmth, generosity, and fun-loving sense of humor will be deeply missed by his family, friends, and colleagues who adored him greatly. His contributions to the Hospital for Special Surgery, built upon his being at the forefront of the transition to computer technology in hospitals, have greatly benefitted that institution and will be felt for years to come. The greatest day in John's productive and impactful life occurred in January 1969 when, as an adventurous student at Columbia he met a buoyant, vivacious student from Skidmore College, Diane Dow. In less than a year they were married and Diane has been his life-long mooring, beginning with moving to Charleston, South Carolina where John was a Lieutenant J.G. in the United States Navy, an experience which greatly added to his knowledge and skill with all things nautical that had been developed over his childhood years in the waters of the St. Lawrence River. John is survived by his beloved wife and soul-mate Diane, his devoted children, Sarah and Tyler, his son-in-law, Tom Francis, his cherished eight-month old granddaughter, Eliot Jane, and his fond brothers Holly and David. And his spirit will remain in the hearts of everyone who has been fortunate enough to know him. A funeral service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York located at 12 West 12th Street, where John was an elder, on Sunday, September 16th at 4pm. Contributions in his memory to the Information Technology Department for the Hospital for Special Surgery (535 East 70th Street, New York City) would be fitting.

MANDELBERGER--Arthur Sandy Arthur Sandy Mandelberger, 57, on August 29, 2012. Film Professional and Journalist, most recently Editor-in-Chief of FilmFestivalToday. Sandy is survived by his mother, Eta, his loving partner of 37 years, Richard, and devoted sisters Miriam and Fanny. His courage and spiritual devotion in his nine year battle with cancer was an inspiration to all who knew him. Donations may be made in his name to Film Society of Lincoln Center, 165 West 65th St., NY, NY 10023, att: Rachel Denny (212-875-5615).
WANKOWICZ--Andrew Talbot. 2/6/20-9/16/02 UNFORGETTABLE! Helen

SELDIS--Jeanette, August 26: Jeanette's career with the United Nations spanned over 40 years, including serving on the mission reviewing the death of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold and broadcasting radio news from the Congo during the conflict of the 1960's. Jeanette was also a member of the United Nations Singers. Her commitment to the U.N. resulted in years of volunteer work after retirement. Born in Britain, Jeanette was a world traveler who adopted New York as her hometown. Beloved aunt of Jacqueline Seldis of England, Steven Dewan and Lawrence Dewan of California. Jeanette's passion for life, her love, kindness, great wisdom and beauty will be dearly missed by family and friends. Donations in Jeanette's memory can be made to UNICEF.

The image of the new building for the Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill, N.Y., was from Cully EEFAS, not from Selldorf Architects. And a photograph of a new building for the Museum of Contemporary Art in Cleveland was taken by Kevin Reeves; it was not supplied by Cully EEFAS.

COLLABORATING with Tabitha Simmons for their second season, the designers Christopher Peters and Shane Gabier paired Creatures of the Wind's fanciful spring collection with these: cheerful Mary Janes wrapped like little gifts in crystal-embellished ribbons and bows. Vaguely reminiscent of a ballroom dancing shoe, the heel (pictured here in yellow with pink piping) partnered gracefully with the show's happy geo-jacquards and bright bubble-gum colors. JANE HERMAN

AMARO--Robert A.,II. After a courageous battle with Lou Gehrig's Disease/ALS, Robert A. Amaro II succumbed to the disease on September 10, 2012. He was born in Manhattan, KS on January 12, 1963. He lived in Kansas City, KS; Lewisville and Dallas, TX; San Francisco, CA; and New York City, NY; but was a man-of-the-world. Robert traveled extensively due to his work for Etro in Milan, Italy. Robert worked in the fashion industry for over 20 years, and was currently a buyer for the Etro Men's Collection dealing in Italian luxury goods. Robert graduated from Lewisville High School and Southern Methodist University in Texas. He went on to receive many awards for his accomplishments throughout his lifetime, the most recent of which is the 2012 ALS Spirit Award from Wings Over Wall Street MDA/ALS. It will be awarded posthumously on September 27, 2012 at their yearly fundraiser Gala. Robert was featured by them in an interview at this year's New York MDA Telethon broadcast. Robert is survived by his mother, Susan Amaro, of Texas; his sister, Amy Amaro Yakubovsky, and her husband Mike, along with nephews, Adam and Trevor Stevenson. He also leaves an aunt, Nancy Gardner, in California; and many other close family and friends. Robert is also survived by his father, Robert A. Amaro, and step-mother, Jana, along with brothers, Christian and Matthew, all of Indiana. His family wishes to express their gratitude to his "Etro Family" of close friends and caregivers: Greg, Kim, Rena, Rosa, Jeffrey, Marco, Michael, Dean, and, Gregory,. They brought him so much love and support. They honored him with a Celebration of Life luncheon and memorial service on Friday, September 14, 2012. In lieu of flowers, donations in Robert's memory can be made to: Lou Gehrig MDA/ALS Research Center at Columbia University Medical Center. https://giving. columbia.edu/giveonline or the Robert Amaro Fine Arts Scholarship Fund established as a living legacy to be awarded annually to a graduating High School senior in his hometown of Lewisville, TX. Go to: www.lisdef.com and click on donate.

BRISTOL--Michal Wild, 80, of Carversville, PA and Madeline Island, WI died of pancreatic cancer at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital on September 8, 2012. Michal was born May 25, 1932 in Brooklyn, NY to William M. Bristol, Jr. and Madeleine Wild Bristol and was the youngest brother to William M. (Mac) and Atherton (Toni), both deceased. Michal graduated from Pingry School, received a B.A. from Harvard and an MBA from Rutgers. He attended the University of Virginia School of Law. He began his career working for the Bristol-Myers Company and shifted to Wall Street where he became an investment advisor. As a board member for the Short Hills Country Day School, now Pingry School, Northland College, the Madeline Island Music Camp and for forty years, the Job Haines Home in Bloomfield, NJ, Michal actively supported each through periods of challenging transition. Treasurer of the Bristol Fund for 50 years, he facilitated the philanthropic efforts of the family. He possessed a devastating wit and a generous heart, never missing a birthday. Michal was a student of history, a lover of books and is fondly remembered for his enjoyment of crossword puzzles, hiking and good wine. A gifted cook, he made many memorable meals for family and friends, the lucky ones fighting over his chocolate mousse. Michal is survived by his beloved wife of 30 years, Edith Wells Bristol, with whom he shared many wonderful adventures and an ever-growing extended family. He will be deeply missed by his five sons: Theodore, Robert, David, Steven, and James by his first marriage to the former Joan Hoxie, and his eight grandchildren as well as by his four stepchildren, the Rev. Edward Pardoe, Margarita Rooke, Edith Webb and Louise Hastings, and their 11 children. Michal was a beloved uncle, friend, father figure and advisor to many. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on Saturday, September 22nd at the Solebury Friends Meeting House, 2680 North Sugan Road, New Hope, PA. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in memory of Michal Bristol, designated to pancreatic cancer research, payable to the Abramson Cancer Center, attn: Katie Detzel, 3535 Market St, Suite 750, Philadelphia, PA 19104 or to the Madeline Island Music Camp, 118 E. 26th St., #

KOSS--Leopold. The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center and the entire Montefiore family are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and cherished colleague, Leopold G. Koss, MD, Chairman Emeritus of the Department of Pathology of Montefiore Medical Center and Professor, Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Dr. Koss was a world-renowned physician and cytopathologist, researcher, author, teacher and mentor, whose association with Montefiore began in 1973. Always an advocate for innovation, Dr. Koss led the Department of Pathology for more than 20 years where he created an unforgettable academic legacy. He made indelible contributions to our understanding of human disease patterns, particularly in the area of gynecological pathology and trained hundreds of pathologists during his career. He was a true translational researcher before the term became popular. He would see the pathology clinically and then ask questions, design experiments and search for mechanisms. He passed this on to his trainees especially nurturing those that had, as he called it, a fire in the belly to understand human disease by doing research. Born in Poland in 1920, he earned a medical degree at the University of Bern in Switzerland after the war and shortly thereafter came to the United States where he served at numerous prestigious medical institutions before joining Montefiore and Einstein. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his three sons, Andrew, Michael and Richard, and his four grandchildren. Steven M. Safyer, MD President and CEO, Montefiore Medical Center Allen M. Spiegel, MD Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean, Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University Michael B. Prystowsky, MD, PhD Leopold G. Koss, MD Chair, University Chairman, Department of Pathology, Montefiore Medical Center Professor, Albert Einstein College of Medicine

WEINBERG--Louis, a resident of Tenafly, NJ for more than forty years, died peacefully on August 27, 2012 at the age of 93. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on July 15, 1919. His wife of fifty years, the former Isabella Goldin, predeceased him in February 2002. Survivors include his daughter Amy (Robert Taurozzi) of New York, sons Mark (Leslie) of Tenafly, and Paul (Shay Londre) of Los Angeles, and five grandchildren. Dr. Weinberg graduated from Brooklyn College in 1941 (AB in English), received an MS in Applied Physics from Harvard in 1947 and an ScD in Electrical Engineering from MIT in 1951. He served as a Lieutenant in the US Army Air Forces during WWII. From 1965 until his retirement in 1990 he was a Professor of Electrical Engineering at City College in New York. Louis Weinberg authored the classic text Network Analysis and Synthesis, and had published over 90 technical papers. He was elected a Fellow of the IEEE in 1960 for his contributions to network theory.

BOWERS--George A. July 6, 1944 August 18, 2012, a highly esteemed film editor and director, died recently in Los Angeles of complications related to heart surgery. A member of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, his editing credits include "The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai," "True Believer," "Harlem Nights," "Sleeping with the Enemy," "A League of Their Own," "Money Train," "The Preacher's Wife," "How Stella Got Her Groove Back," "Roll Bounce," and "Welcome Home, Roscoe Jenkins." He also directed, "The Hearse," "Body and Soul," and "My Tutor." He is survived by his wife Irene, daughters Tanya and Natalie. A memorial will be held in New York on Friday, September 28 from 79pm at the National Black Programming Consortium, 68 East 134th St., Suite 700, NYC.

NEVER daunted by curatorial challenges, the Institute of Contemporary Art on the campus of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia is tackling the first midcareer museum survey of the British artist and relational aesthetician JEREMY DELLER, known largely for socially conscious, participatory efforts that frequently delve into subcultures (rock music, for example) and push vigorously at the boundaries between art and life. ''Jeremy Deller: Joy in People,'' which opens Wednesday, will feature nearly all of his significant works to date, starting with a larger-than-life reconstruction of ''Open Bedroom'' of 1993, an exhibition that he staged in his parents' house while they were away. It includes a two-part archival installation concerning his epic film, ''Battle of Orgreave (An Injury to One is an Injury to All)'' of 2004, a gripping restaging of a violent 1984 confrontation between thousands of picketing Yorkshire miners and armed police officers, albeit with a cast of around 800. The disparate works show Mr. Deller in the various roles of producer, publisher, curator, parade organizer and cultural archivist. He will represent Britain in the 2013 Venice Biennale. 118 South 36th Street, (215) 898-7108, icaphila.org .

ONE way to think of dance is as a set of interlocking nomadic cultures whose riches accrue, collectively and individually, in the mind and spirit. These cultures leave plenty of enduring traces, often manifested in nonmaterial forms. There is, for example, the rich network of conversations that explode ahead of and around and behind performances. Monday brings two of these. At Danspace Project the choreographer LUCINDA CHILDS will lead a discussion around works she created in the 1960s as part of the groundbreaking Judson Dance Theater movement. (She will also screen archival films -- useful but, to my mind, less compelling artifacts than memories.) The evening is part of Danspace's celebration of the 50th anniversary of Judson. 7 p.m., 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (866) 811-4111, danspaceproject.org ; $18. Uptown at the French Institute Alliance Française's CROSSING THE LINE FESTIVAL, the choreographer Faustin Linyekula and the director Peter Sellars will discuss their work in the context of artistic activism. (Mr. Linyekula will perform ''Le Cargo'' the next night.) 8 p.m., 55 East 59th Street, Manhattan, (800) 982-2787, fiaf.org ; $20 to 25.

Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy. Week 1 is always the toughest week to predict in the N.F.L., for obvious reasons that include not knowing how good some defenses are. For example, who would have expected the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, a team that allowed Carolina Panthers quarterback Cam Newton 74 fantasy points in two games last season, to limit Newton to a modest 14 points and completely shut down the Panthers running game, Newton included?
ABRAMS--Maureen, of Pompano Beach, FL passed away September 11, 2012. A memorial Mass will take place at 11am on Saturday September 22 at St. Sebastian Church, Woodside, NY.
Saints (0-1) at Panthers (0-1) Sunday, 1 p.m.

An opinion essay last Sunday criticizing the use of seclusion and restraint to discipline students described an episode on Jan. 6, 2006, in which the writer's daughter, then a kindergartner, was kept in an isolation room at her school in Lexington, Mass. Several details of that episode have since been disputed. The girl wet herself while being confined in a closet for misbehaving. But school officials, and a 2008 deposition by the girl's mother, state that she was then cleaned up and dressed while her parents were notified -- and that it was not the case that the parents found her standing alone, unclothed, in her urine.

ELIOT RABIN, the founder of the Upper East Side temple of navy blazers and sherbet-colored sweaters that is Peter Elliot, is a retailer of a bygone era of gentility. He loves to amuse a customer with a good cliché, like his store motto: "The whimsical mood of timeless elegance." Mr. Rabin is the kind of shopkeep who says things like this: "Yesterday was a canceled check. Tomorrow is a promissory note. Today is cash." Or this: "You want to be successful in business, you learn to fold a cashmere sweater with your left hand and clean the toilet with your right."

BRITTAIN--May. May Sandoz McDonnell Brittain, of Greenwich, Connecticut. Born 1932 in Switzerland, died September 9, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Kenneth McDonnell, and the late Alfred Brittain III. She is survived by her children, Candace McDonnell Hanau, Peter H. McDonnell and Isabelle McDonnell Catino, as well as five grandchildren and two step-grandchildren. A funeral service is scheduled for Saturday, September 29, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 200 Riverside Avenue, Riverside, CT at 2:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation, 1-888-733-6741. She will be sorely missed by her family and devoted friends.

A starkly modern penthouse duplex with a Pop Art pedigree - the Andy Warhol alumna Jane Holzer once owned it - which fills the top two floors at the Volney, a former hotel built in 1928, sold for $17.5 million, making it the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The penthouse, at 23 East 74th Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, had been on the market since 2011, but a $5 million price reduction to $18.5 million this spring inspired a trio of serious bids.

IN a review of the drama ''HARPER REGAN,'' The Guardian's chief critic, Michael Billington, said the British playwright Simon Stephens writes well about ''a national vice,'' described as ''the capacity for emotional evasion.'' Mr. Stephens's play, which begins previews at the Atlantic Theater on Thursday, is about a 41-year-old woman struggling during tough economic times. In response, she simply leaves. She flees home, not telling her family. Mr. Stephens is a dizzyingly prolific dramatist who remains far less known here than in England, but that may change with this play. Of course fantasizing about running away is not exclusive to any country. It was a potent theme of the great French film ''Time Out'' and even of the recent episode of ''Louie,'' in which the title character visits his father, only to decide at the last second to run away, far away. The Atlantic is positioning itself as the New York home of Mr. Stephens, having last year presented his ''Bluebird,'' starring Simon Russell Beale. This production will star Mary McCann, a founding member of the company. 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea; (212) 279-4200, atlantictheater.org .

Like so many young 21st-century artists, the pianist Robert Glasper bristles at the straitjacket of genre. His album early this year, ''Black Radio,'' worked toward a synthesis of jazz, R&B and hip-hop. You can check out Mr. Glasper's ideas on Oct. 16 at S.O.B.'s. And a kind of sequel to ''Black Radio,'' ''Black Radio Recovered: The Remix EP,'' is due out Oct. 9 from Blue Note ( sobs.com ).

Eli Zborowski, a survivor of the Holocaust who made it his mission to ensure that it would never be forgotten, founded an American organization to support Israel's official Holocaust memorial and raised more than $100 million for it, died on Monday in Queens. He was 86. The cause was cardiac arrest, said Rochel Berman, who, with her husband, George, published a biography of Mr. Zborowski last year.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption last Sunday with an article about friends and families divided by changes to immigration policy misstated, in some editions, the age at which one man illegally entered the United States. As the article correctly noted, the man, Alex Cruz, entered the country six years ago; he did not immigrate at 18, his current age.

BEEMISH--Franklyn R.,Jr., on September 8, 2012. Devoted father of Franklyn Robert III, Jennifer, Edwin, Marie and Ann. Dear brother of Elizabeth Lehigh. Cherished grandfather of six. Friends may call at Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Ave, Floral Park, NY on Monday 2-5 and 7-9:30pm. Memorial Service will be at 8:00pm. Interment on Tuesday, 11:30am at Greenwood Cemetery, Hamilton, NJ. Frank Beemish was an engineer and a creator of the D-Patch and multi-line cable. He began work with Berry Gordy. He was a Chief Engineer at the Video Tape Center, a non-for-profit company connected to 3M and AMPEX pioneering the use video tape for time-shifting and for commercials. Founder of JEM-FAB Corporation, he designed and developed AV systems and TV studios and trucks. In retirement, Frank excelled as a fine furniture maker. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Compassion International Leadership Development Program (compassion.com) or Alzheimer's Association (ALZ.org).
HAYES--Bryant Teal, May 30th, in England. Beloved by all his family. Memorial September 29th, NYC. See www.bryanthayes.org

TODD--Lewis. Born July 22, 1930, died September 3, 2012 was a prominent figure in Greenwich Village life and Democratic politics for more than 40 years. An early pioneer in the Gay Civil Rights movement, he remained a leader in it up until his death. He was a founder of The National Lesbian and Gay Task Force as well as of The Stonewall Democratic Club and The Village Reform Democratic Club. In the 1970's and 1980's he owned several restaurants, including The Ballroom, one of the most celebrated cabarets in New York, and brought attention to the growing art scene in Soho. During the Korean War he enlisted in the Navy and served on the USS Smalley. From 1985-95 he worked for the FDNY. Lew was a fiercely loyal friend and is mourned by the many that he helped and touched.

BARNOUW--Elsa, 105, died July 1, 2012 of natural causes in her home at 39 Claremont Ave. in NYC. Her body was given to the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. There will be no obsequies.

Eisenhower started painting when he was 58, after World War II , in part to calm his nerves. In 1950, the five-star general wrote to his friend Winston Churchill: ''I have had a lot of fun since I took up, in my somewhat miserable way, your hobby of painting. I have had no instruction, have no talent, and certainly no justification for covering nice white canvas with the kind of daubs that seem constantly to spring from my brushes.'' When Eisenhower became president three years later, he assigned a sergeant posted to the White House the job of preparing his canvases and paints.

In his late 20s, the jazz icon was battling a heroin addiction. He became inspired to change his life by the world-champion welterweight and middleweight boxer Sugar Ray Robinson, who ''was one of the few idols that I have ever had,'' Davis wrote in his autobiography. ''I figured if he could be as disciplined as he was, then I could do it, too.'' In 1952, Davis showed up high at New York City's Gleason's Gym and asked the trainer Bobby McQuillen to take him on as a boxing student. McQuillen initially turned Davis away, but within two years, Davis had cleaned up enough to begin training. Davis wrote, ''You've got to have style in whatever you do -- writing, music, painting, fashion, boxing, anything.''

Although Chrysler Group has made significant strides toward rehabilitating its finances since emerging from bankruptcy in 2009, the company has avoided the complacency that plagued it in previous times of growth. Sergio Marchionne , the chief executive of Chrysler and Fiat, introduced 66 car and truck models to the company's dealers at a meeting in Las Vegas on Monday. According to a report by Reuters , among the new models shown was a Chrysler 100 subcompact that would give the brand an entry in that growing segment; a redesigned Chrysler 200 said to resemble the well-received Dodge Dart ; various Jeep models that mimic the styling of the brand's successful Grand Cherokee; and a couple of Alfa Romeos that would be sold by Fiat dealers in the United States.

I RECENTLY had a long-postponed dinner with a dear male friend of mine. After comparing cholesterol scores and the frequency of workouts, we got down to business. My total cholesterol being higher, I ordered an arugula salad , hold the shaved Parmesan, please, and the grilled salmon. My friend looked at me, his gaze cool and steady, and without averting his eyes from mine instructed the waiter to bring him an antipasto of salami and cheese, followed by the sautéed calf's liver.

GROSSMAN--Rita, born to Irene and Jesse Mendelsohn September 2, 1926, Bronx. Mother of Julie (John)Keane and Stu (Amy) Grossman. Beloved Grandma of Isabel, Ava and Carly. Wife of the late Al Grossman. Weinstein FH September 19th 10am.

WHAT I BROUGHT HOME Have a favorite souvenir from a favorite vacation? We're asking for photos of what people bring home, like the spoons, above, that a reader picked up in Mexico , and for the stories behind them.

In ''Divided by Immigration Policy,'' on the cover of last Sunday's Metropolitan section, John Leland profiled friends and families split by President Obama's recent executive order that gave some illegal immigrants who came to the country before age 16 the chance to avoid deportation for two years. Commenters on NYTimes.com debated the policy and whether illegal immigrants deserved sympathy. Readers also discussed Ginia Bellafante's Big City column, which questioned whether increased charitable giving could replace cuts to government social services, as some Republican have argued. A selection of comments is below. Sad stories, but surely these people, who were mostly teenagers when they came here, understood the concept of ''illegal'' before they got here. They came anyway and now expect us to ignore our laws. There are 23 million Americans unemployed or underemployed; we simply can't provide for the entire world. We need to reduce even legal immigration and deport all illegal aliens that we can find. We just can't afford to be so lackadaisical in enforcing our laws: Our own people need those jobs.

DEESEN--Kenneth C.,DDS, on September 12, 2012. Reunited with his beloved wife, Lillian, in heaven on their Wedding Anniversary. Graduate of MIT and Columbia University College of Dental Medicine. Loving father of Pat Daub, Priscilla Devine, and Phyllis Whittam. Father-in-law of Bill Daub, Mike Devine, and Michael Whittam. Cherished grandfather of Coleen, Megan, Michael, and Mikhaila. Dear brother of Paul. Gifted and caring dentist in Flushing for over 50 years. Professor at Columbia Dental School, on the Board of Directors at the Flushing, YMCA, and Veteran of the Korean War. Inventor of a computer-assisted coaching method and specialty dental camera. Ken was passionate about using his gifts and talents to serve the Lord. His life impacted many people very deeply. Visiting hours on Sunday, September 16, 2-6pm at the Frederick Funeral Home, Northern Blvd. at 193rd St., Flushing, NY. Religious service Monday, September 17th 9:30am at Resurrection Lutheran Church. Interment Flushing Cemetery.

T'S coverage of New York Fashion Week , which ended Thursday, caught hundreds of the show season's best-dressed and most exclusive moments in action. Tireless photographers shot gorgeous and intimate behind-the-scenes pictures for the Photos of The Moment (shown here); Diane von Furstenberg (below), Ohne Titel (left) and Theyskens' Theory (above) were among the collections captured in these beautiful diaries. The Daily Shoe column (bottom left) featured one standout heel, boot or flat from the dozens that walked the runways every day. Editors tracked the making of five extraordinary dresses (Dress Code, center left), the ways two different women wore one single trend (Serene vs. Extreme, bottom right), and the transformative power of proper hair and makeup styling in Backstage Beauty Reports and the interactive Model-Morphosis stories. The fun continues in Europe, where shows are under way in London (Milan and Paris are up next). But first, here's a sampling from The Moment's busy, fashion-fueled week. JANE HERMAN

RODSTROM--Josephine C. 87, of Gainesville, Florida, passed away on September 14, 2012. Josephine was born on City Island in the Bronx, New York City. Her parents were Captain Charles Rodstrom and Cora A. Rodstrom. She attended public schools including P.S.17 and Evander Childs High School. She attended Hunter College and was awarded a baccalaureate degree. She developed a love for math and statistics and secured a position as a statistician at Lever Brothers in New York. Jo was a most unusual personality, since she developed Olliers Disease as a child and required mid-thigh amputation as a young adult. She asked for no quarter for her disability. Her outgoing nature caused her to be admired and much loved. She is survived by a brother Wesley Rodstrom and a sister Cynthia Kinsella. According to her expressed wishes, she will be cremated and her ashes scattered.

Brazil is too expensive for budget travelers. Or is it? Evidence in the affirmative is strong. Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo are now the most expensive cities in the Western Hemisphere , by some measures. The dollar that used to get you 3 or almost 4 Brazilian reais at various points in the last decade now gets you just 2. Flying to Brazil from New York takes at least nine hours and can easily run $1,000.

¿Buscar viajes? Norwegian Cruise Line is making it easier for Spanish speakers to cruise - at least online - by launching a new Spanish language Web site . The new version is largely a translation of the line's English-language Web site , which includes an "español" option for information and booking. The line has also created a toll-free phone number that reaches Spanish-speaking operators.

MINSTEIN--Beatrice Sylvia, 95, on September 4, in Hollywood CA. Widow of Abe. Survived by sons Ethan Mordden, New York; Andrew (Marsha Roffman), Los Angeles; Anthony (Vycki Levine), Louisville, KY. Grandmother of Solange and Harris. Sister of Laura Regenbogen and Samuel Hochberger.

GOLDSTEIN--Joan Love. Joan Love Barnert Goldstein, age 90, died peacefully at home in New Rochelle, NY on September 11, 2012, after a long illness. She is survived by Sam, her husband of 61 years, and her children Dr. Laurie Goldstein, Robert Golan, and Betty Goldstein, and her granddaughters Lynn and Billie Golan. She was a proud Doctor of Social Welfare (DSW), and a lifelong activist with the Peace Movement and Civil Rights. Her passions were folk dancing, folk music, and her guitar. She loved life and will be terribly missed. Anyone choosing to make a donation in Joan Goldstein's memory is asked to donate either to Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester. www.hospiceofwestchester.com, or the Obama Campaign www.barackobama.com.

SAFFER--Dr. Alfred, 93, died on September 7. Dr. Saffer, retired Vice Chairman of Halcon International and President/COO of Oxirane Corp, devoted his career to advancing and building the petrochemical business. His professional distinctions included AIChE Top 100 Chemical Engineers of the Century and membership in the National Academy of Engineering. Dr. Saffer was a member of Glen Oaks Country Club (New York) and Entertainment Chairman and Board Member at Delaire Country Club (Florida). He supported many charities, including leading JARC's Annual Gala (Florida). Dr. Saffer is preceded in death by his beloved wife of 41 years Ruth; second wife Doris and survived by his children Anita (Barry) Horowitz and Martin (Anne) Saffer; grandchildren Andrew (Jill) Horowitz, Sharon Kosloff, Beth and Stephanie Saffer, great-grandchildren Lauren, Erica and Brett Horowitz, and Danielle Castelli, and long-time companion Helen Straub.

He recently signed a bill that would allow a speed limit of 85 miles per hour on a 41-mile toll road between Austin, Tex., and San Antonio. The metropolitan area of his state's capital is preparing to host the first Formula One race in the United States since 2007. And he watched the Ferrari driver Fernando Alonso expand his lead in the driver's championship at the Italian Grand Prix on Sunday. Perhaps nobody was better suited than Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, then, to get acquainted with a 730-horsepower Ferrari F12 Berlinetta or a 462-horsepower 458 Italia on Tuesday on Ferrari's test track at Fiorano. Mr. Perry visited the track after meeting with Luca di Montezemolo, the Ferrari chairman, earlier in the day at the supercar manufacturer's headquarters in Maranello.

AHLGREN--Wynne G.,of Bronxville, on September 12, 2012. Beloved wife of John Ahlgren. She had a very successful business career. Mrs. Ahlgren worked for March of Time and the Dyson-Kissner Corporation where she was the corporate secretary for 50 corporations. She was a very active member of the Siwanoy Country Club, chairing the women's golf committee for many years. She was also very prominent at the Hillsboro Club in Hillsboro Beach, FL. A memorial service will be held at the Reformed Church of Bronxville on Monday September 17 at 11am.

SMITH--Betty Jane September 16, 1921 - April 08, 2012. Extraordinary woman who devoted her career to help young opera singers achieve their dreams, died on April 8th 2012. Today, on her living birthday, her ashes will be scattered in the NYC wind. Betty was the former president of the Gerda Lissner foundation, The Herman Lissner Foundation and The Melchior Heldentenor Foundation. She was born in Bohman, Texas, after graduating from Stephen College, moved to NYC and found a job working for Constance Hope, who promoted Metropolitan Opera singers. At Hope Associates, Ms. Smith first represented the Heldentenor Lauritz Melchior and then Mrs. Gerda Lissner. Some other noteable Met singers she represented included Eleanor Steber, Helen Traubel, also, Jeannette MacDonald and the great pianist William Kapell. She remained president until her retirement in 2006 to write Lauritz Melchior biography, "Journey to Valhalla" and have it freely available at his own website, www.lauritzmelchior.com Today her friends honored her life and are grateful to have met such an incredible woman.

The author of ''War and Peace'' took his first bicycling lesson at age 67, only a month after the death of his 7-year-old son, Vanichka. He was still grieving, and the Moscow Society of Velocipede-Lovers provided him a free bike and instruction along the garden paths on his estate. He became a devotee, taking rides after his morning chores. ''Count Leo Tolstoy . . . now rides the wheel,'' declared Scientific American in 1896, ''much to the astonishment of the peasants on his estate.'' A close friend noted: ''Tolstoy has learned to ride a bicycle. Is this not inconsistent with Christian ideals?''

Boeing's 787 Dreamliner, the lighter, more-fuel efficient and purportedly more comfortable aircraft that has forged fans of hopeful fliers, recently made its American debut with the Chilean carrier LAN Airlines . In late August, LAN received the first of three 787s it expects this year and 32 scheduled over 10 years. The company plans to initially deploy the new aircraft on international routes between South American gateways Santiago, Lima and Buenos Aires and destinations in Madrid, Frankfurt and Los Angeles.

Survived by her daughters Celeste Zellin and Claudia Stern, and five grandchildren. Services Wednesday 11:30am "Sinai Chapels", 162-05 Horace Harding Expy, Fresh Meadows, NY. Though it has no shortage of luxury accommodations, Latin America has long held a reputation as a place where budget travelers can pinch pennies. Times have changed. The average hotel rate in Mexico City, right, rose 30 percent in local currency last year, outpacing the rate of increase in 50 international cities including Dubai and New York, according to a report by the HRG travel management company. In fact, Latin American cities were among those with the highest percentage increase in room rates. It's not just because they started out low to begin with. Rio de Janeiro, whose average room rates were the fifth highest of all the cities included, had rates increase 15 percent and São Paulo, which ranked 15th most expensive, still saw its room rates shoot up 23 percent.

More than 250 New York fashion designers exhibited their spring collections over a week that ended last Thursday. There was not one collection devoted to fashion's hottest item, the shoe. But that was not necessary. Guests at the clothing shows provided a dazzling display of today's shoe designs. The popularity of highly individual footwear has led Macy's, Saks Fifth Avenue and Barneys New York to turn over complete floors to accommodate this passion for shoes.

I am an "almost" writer. A quick and random sweep through a few of my manuscripts reveals the following uses of "almost": almost never, almost always, almost certainly, almost ready, almost willing, almost impulsively, almost as though, almost immediately, almost everywhere, almost kind, almost cruel, almost exciting, almost home, almost asleep, almost dead. She said "Don't" almost before his lips had touched hers.

The end of July had been so seismic for the Philadelphia Phillies that it was easy to miss their first trade of August. By then, they had already traded two veteran outfielders, Shane Victorino and Hunter Pence, and re-signed an ace starter, Cole Hamels, for six years. They were rebuilding for the future and recommitting to their present, all at once. On Aug. 3, two and a half hours before Joe Blanton was scheduled to start against the Arizona Diamondbacks, the Phillies announced their trade of Blanton to the Los Angeles Dodgers, who had claimed him off waivers. The Phillies needed a starter that night, and everybody who followed the team knew who it would be. It was Kyle Kendrick, of course, ever the good soldier.

PITTSBURGH -- In the months after a roadside bomb in Afghanistan blew off part of his left thigh, Sgt. Ron Strang wondered if he would ever be able to walk normally again. The explosion and subsequent rounds of surgery left Sergeant Strang, 28, a Marine, with a huge divot in his upper thigh where the quadriceps muscle had been. He could move the leg backward, but with so much of the muscle gone he could not kick it forward. He could walk, but only awkwardly.

During the run of each party's convention, traffic to President Obama's campaign site averaged 803,000 visitors a day and those to Mitt-Romney.com averaged 151,000 a day. On the day after the conventions, visitors to both typically moved on to information or social media sites. In looking at the five days preceding the Republican Convention and the five days after, Mr. Romney's Web site had a 17 percent drop in average daily traffic. For Mr. Obama, traffic increased 20 percent in the comparable period.

A capsule look at the Giants' victory over the Bucs on Sunday. Key performance Andre Brown barely made the Giants' roster out of training camp, but the No. 3 back on this team certainly elevated his status Sunday. With Ahmad Bradshaw injured and the rookie David Wilson struggling, Brown rushed for 71 yards on 13 carries and scored the decisive touchdown. He also slipped into the end zone for a critical 2-point conversion that tied the game earlier in the fourth quarter.

It might take a village to turn NBC around. Or, at least, an iVillage. NBCUniversal's female-oriented Web site, iVillage.com, has lined up a string of prominent "guest editors" who will handpick content on the site and appear in recorded vignettes. The media company plans to use that content not just on iVillage, but in sponsored video clips to appear on its cable channels and potentially on the struggling broadcast channel.

8 P.M. (13) PIONEERS OF THIRTEEN For its 50th anniversary, the channel kicks off a yearlong celebration with a four-part documentary chronicling a half-century of programming through archival film footage. The first installment, ''The '60s -- Experimental Days,'' features Edward R. Murrow, above, hosting the inaugural broadcast of Channel 13/WNDT -- ''New Dimensions in Television,'' which would later evolve into WNET. It also presents clips from ''Black Journal,'' created by the producer Al Perlmutter; of Andy Warhol introducing the band the Velvet Underground; of the filmmakers Albert and David Maysles following Truman Capote after the publication of his novel ''In Cold Blood''; of a young Dustin Hoffman, a year before his breakthrough role in ''The Graduate'' (1967), performing in ''The Journey of the Fifth Horse''; and from ''Sesame Street.'' Among those interviewed are Richard Heffner, the first general manager of WNDT; the journalist Bill Moyers; the actor James Earl Jones; and Joan Ganz Cooney, a founder of the Children's Television Workshop. The remaining three episodes will be shown later in the year. 3 P.M. (Sundance) ICONOCLASTS The singer and songwriter Alicia Keys and the actress Ruby Dee stroll through Harlem -- and learn that their childhood homes were only a few blocks apart -- as they share their passions for performance and poetry while discussing the social climates of their times. Their excursion includes stops at the American Negro Theater, where Ms. Dee had her start, and the Professional Performing Arts School, Ms. Keys's alma mater, where she performs a song from her album ''As I Am.'' In ''David Bailey: Four Beats to the Bar and No Cheating'' (2012), at 4, Jérôme de Missolz creates a portrait of Mr. Bailey, the British fashion photographer who helped give rise to the Swinging London of the 1960s and was a model for the lead character in Michelangelo Antonioni's ''Blow-Up'' (1966). Mr. Bailey's former wife Catherine Deneuve offers perspective.

In the next month or two, subway and bus riders will find advertising where they have never seen it before: on the face of their MetroCards, always with them and inescapable - at least for that moment they pay their fare. The front of the MetroCard is not the only new territory being given over to commerce. This year, for the first time, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority began allowing ads to cover passenger windows on buses. Calvin Klein and Broadway producers embraced the spot.

BILLIAN--Douglas Charles, of Atlanta, Georgia and New York City, passed away on Saturday morning, September 15, 2012 at his home in Atlanta. After a courageous battle with a brain tumor, he spent his last days surrounded by his loving family, friends, and his devoted wife Louise "Lulu" Billian. Doug was born on March 13, 1928, to Elsie Adelaide (nee Bowers) and Alfred Arthur Billian in Bound Brook, NJ. His lifelong passion for scouting began as a young boy when he followed his brothers into the Boy Scouts. He attained the level of Eagle Scout with bronze, silver, and gold palms and The Order of the Arrow. Through the years he has generously supported the Boy Scouts of America to encourage what he believed contributed to his own success. After graduating from the Kellogg School of Business at Northwestern University (which he attended under the U.S. Navy Holloway Midshipman Program), Billian received his Naval commission just prior to the Korean War outbreak, serving 1950 to 1953. After a twenty-year career with the McGraw Hill Publishing Company on publications such as Purchasing Week, Aviation Week and Business Week, Doug launched Billian Publishing, Inc., in 1978, with the acquisition of Golf World magazine (sold a decade later to the New York Times Group). Subsequent acquisitions include Textile World, Art & Antiques and Boating World. Today, Billian Publishing Inc. thrives primarily serving the healthcare industry with Billian's HealthDATA, Porter Research and Healthcare IT Research (HITR). The Textile Industries Media Group is the leading resource for textile news and information from around the globe. Its international titles include Textile World, Textiles Panamericanos and Textile World Asia. The Billians supported many art shows including The Winter Antiques Show in New York, Grosvenor House Antiques Fair in London, The San Francisco Antiques Show and numerous others. Doug Billian was a member of Cherokee Town & Country Club and The University Yacht Club, and a former member of Pinehurst Country Club and Magazine Publishers Association. He was a proud lifetime member of the National Association of Eagle Scouts sponsored by fellow Scout, Astronaut Jim Lovell. He served on the Board of Trustees of The United States Golf Association, Meals on Wheels Atlanta, and as Chairman of the IFC Senior Citizens Foundation. He is survived by his devoted wife of 26 years, Louise Lindsey Billian. He is also survived by his children, Tracey Billian Krause, Martha Billian Meyer with spouse Dan, Lindsey Perkins Mullen with spouse Tim, Charles Jackson "Jay" Perkins, Jr. with spouse Michelle, Douglas C. Billian Jr. with spouse Jennifer, eleven grandchildren, his brother Alfred Billian Jr. of Ft. Wayne, IN, and many nieces and nephews. Doug Billian will be remembered for his incredibly high moral standards, honorable character, utmost integrity and taking pride in all you do. His unrelenting work ethic, coupled with his love of publishing and investing, contributed to his success. However, his intense belief in providing for his family drove his ambition. He taught us all by the honorable life he led and those whose lives he touched have been inspired by his example. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Boy Scouts of America, Meals on Wheels Atlanta, Hospice Atlanta or your favorite charity.

SFJazz , the Bay Area jazz institution which has for nearly 30 years presented concerts and festivals in rented spaces, announced on Thursday the lineup for a series of opening concerts and a wide-ranging full-season schedule in its new permanent space - with concerts by local as well as international artists and educational programming. The SFJazz Center, designed by the architect Mark Cavagnero, the acoustician Sam Berkow, and the theater designer Len Auerbach, will open on Jan. 21, Martin Luther King's Birthday, in San Francisco's Hayes Valley neighborhood. It will include a 700-seat auditorium in addition to smaller rehearsal and performance spaces and a café.

LIPSET--Ruth, May 9, 1935 - September 15, 2012, devoted wife, loving mother, grandmother, dear friend and most beautiful, intelligent, irreplaceable woman in our lives died peacefully at home after a courageous two year battle with lung cancer. Her absence leaves a deep hole in the lives of everyone she touched. Ruth lived life to the fullest and her friends and family will miss her dearly. She was a great patron and lover of the arts, and amongst her friends was known as the one woman who never missed a broadway show, or cultural event. She worked in business side by side and traveled the world with her devoted husband Marty for 52 years. She leaves behind four loving sons, Alan, Charles, Mark, Richard, and daughter-in-law Debra, and five beautiful grandchildren, Megan, Melissa, Evan, Sophie and Nate. Even in the face of her illness Ruth explained, "I've had a wonderful life and have no regrets." Funeral services will be held at Temple Israel, 14 Coleytown Rd, Westport CT. September 19, 2012 at 11am.

DRISCOLL--Joan (Degnan), 84, of Ridgefield, CT, wife of the late Francis X. Driscoll, died on September 15. Born in Forty Fort, PA, August 9, 1928, a daughter of the late Leo and Nan (Ryan) Degnan. Grew up in Astoria, New York. Attended St. Jean the Baptist High School, graduated from St. John's University and worked for the Department of Social Services in New York City. In 1953, Mr. and Mrs. Driscoll were wed, and resided in Huntington Station, NY for thirty-two years before moving to Wilton in 1986 and Ridgefield in 1998. Mrs. Driscoll was a member of the St. Vincent DePaul Society. Active in athletics, she was a former basketball player, coach and umpire. A natural musician, she loved to sing and play guitar. She also enjoyed following and discussing current political events. A loving mother, she is survived by four sons, Francis X. (Pamela) Driscoll of Milford, CT, Robert P. (Cynthia) Driscoll of Hingham, MA, M. Leo (Nancy) Driscoll of Garden City, NY and Justin L. (Suzanne) Driscoll of Westport, CT; five daughters, Anne (Bruce) Danielson of South Bend, IN, Katherine (Peter) Jacullo of Ridgefield, CT, Celia (John) Fisher of Raleigh, NC, Mariclaire (James) Rourke of Oakton, VA and Megan (John) Kaste of Campbell Hall, NY; son-in-law Michael Driscoll-Kelly of Avon CT; a brother, Robert (Theresa) Degnan of Katonah, NY; two sisters, Mary Degnan of Tarrytown, NY and Nancy (Eric) Waxman of Setauket, LI, NY; thirty-three grandchildren, three great grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. Mrs. Driscoll was predeceased by her daughter, Joan Driscoll-Kelly. Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Tuesday, September 18, 2012 at 10:15am in St. Mary Church, Ridgefield. Calling hours at the Kane Funeral Home, 25 Catoonah Street, Ridgefield on Monday, September 17, 2012 from 4pm to 8pm.

Rick Smolan, the photographer and impresario of media projects, has tackled all sorts of big subjects over the years, from countries ("A Day in the Life of Australia" in 1981) to drinking water ("Blue Planet Run" in 2007). He typically recruits about 100 photographers for each, and their work is crafted into classy coffee-table books of striking photographs and short essays. But Mr. Smolan concedes that his current venture has been "by far the most challenging project we've done."

O'KEEFE--Daniel L.,84, of Chappaqua, NY, a magazine editor, author and self-taught linguist, died August 29 in New York City. He earned a BA from Columbia, Ph.D. from the New School for Social Research, and studied at St. Catherine's College Oxford as a Rotary Fellow. His career in journalism started in high school: Dan gave speeches around the country for Junior Achievement. After one speech he was offered a New York radio show called "Youth Demands the Answer" but was fired when an on-air fistfight broke out between his guests. An editor at Reader's Digest, he worked with writers like Ray Bradbury, Ishmael Reed and Czeslaw Milosz. His book Stolen Lightning: The Social Theory of Magic (1982) was nominated for a National Book Critics Circle Award. In a New York Times review, John Leonard said "Not since Marx, Darwin and Freud has there been anyone so opinionated" and "Mr. O'Keefe is a better writer than Darwin." He invented a family holiday "Festivus" that appeared in a "Seinfeld" episode now celebrated around the world, written by son Daniel. He spoke 40 languages with varying degrees of accuracy, Gaelic to Swahili to Tagalog. Each weekend in a Chappaqua bar he would speak multiple languages with his wife and anyone who would listen. Dan was born February 25 1928 in Jersey City to Charles and Jeanette O'Keefe. He is survived by his wife Deborah; son Daniel, wife Tina and grandson Nikos of Los Angeles; son Laurence and wife Nell of New York; son Markham of Los Angeles; and sister Eileen Duncan of Plymouth, MA.

Nicki Pombier Berger, who is listed as one of the speakers at an event called Underwater New York, is unequivocal: She is "terrified" of diving. She has never wanted an up-close-and-personal look at what she will be talking about at the South Street Seaport Museum, namely, the stuff that has piled up over time at the bottom of the Hudson River or the East River or New York Harbor - the jetsam of New York. "Oh, no. You probably couldn't pay me enough to go down there," she said, adding that she is claustrophobic and that wriggling into diving gear and venturing into the deep "sound so awful to me."

Dear Diary: When I was young, school started for New York City kids the second week of September. Being born on the 11th meant no classroom celebration; it took at least three weeks for your classmates to even remember your name.

HEAD--Glenn Oakes, of Madison, NJ, the former chairman and major shareholder of First Investors Consolidated Corporation (FICC), a national financial services firm based in New York City, died on Friday, September 14, 2012. He was 87. Born in Peoria, IL, in 1925, Mr. Head grew up in Springfield and attended college at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign. He left his home state in 1947 when an actuarial position opened up at the Farm Bureau Life Insurance Company of Iowa. Named a Fellow of the Society of Actuaries in 1952, Mr. Head served as Chief Actuary and Director of the U.S. Life Company from 1953 until 1962. The owners of First Investors hired him in 1962 to start a life insurance company, which became First Investors Life (FIL). Mr. Head and partner David Grayson acquired control of the holding company, FICC, through a leveraged buy-out in 1968. In addition to FIL, FICC owned a broker dealer, First Investors Corporation, and an investment advisor, First Investors Management Company. Later on, Mr. Head was responsible for FICC building a transfer agent and acquiring a savings bank. When Mr. Head and Mr. Grayson acquired First Investors, it was primarily a sales organization, with $55 million in assets. Upon Mr. Head's retirement at the end of 2004, the First Investors Funds had over $6.6 billion in assets. FICC continues to thrive after being sold in early 2011. Mr. Head was a member and president of the Madison, N.J. Board of Education and his success in those slots attracted the attention of local Republicans, who encouraged him to run for mayor. Mr. Head won a three-way contest in 1972, having been elected on the promise of providing administrative excellence. As mayor, he made good on that promise with electric utility improvements, reductions in town expenses, and lower taxes. Mr. Head's interest in business began when he was a boy, working on the floor of a Dr. Pepper bottling plant and setting up bowling pins at a local bowling alley. He welcomed risk, and as a teenager bet an acquaintance that he could take apart a car engine, put it back together, and drive the car again. He won. Mr. Head's pursuits extended beyond business. He took flying lessons and earned his commercial pilot's license, eventually owning and flying a twin-engine Cessna. He bought a series of contiguous farms in Bluffs, Illinois, and flew himself out monthly to examine the soybeans and corn. When the farm grew in size and complexity, he created his own computer software to manage the accounting. Mr. Head embodied the values of honesty, thrift, loyalty, and kindness. He was plain-spoken and friendly, and judged people by the quality of their character. Mr. Head seized his interests with gusto. Having taken up tennis in his 50s, he soon dominated the courts with drop shots and lobs. He discovered Nantucket with his family in the 1970s, and considered the island a rare jewel, even though he didn't care for sand. Years later, he designed and built a house there. Mr. Head and his wife, Carol Atwood, were married in Collins, IA, in 1954. After the birth of their first child in Manhattan, they moved to Madison, NJ, and had four more children. In 2004, Mr. and Mrs. Head celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary. He is survived by his wife; his children, Kathy Head of Summit, NJ, Glenn Head, Jr. of Brooklyn, NY, Marcia Head of Cambridge, MA, Leslie Head of Short Hills, NJ, Linda Flanagan and her husband Robert of Summit, NJ; his grandchildren, Brian Smith, Jenny Smith, Julie Flanagan, Jeff Flanagan, Paul Flanagan, Kate Head, Caroline Scheer, and Jessie Scheer; and his sister Annabelle Thompson. A funeral service will be held at 10:00am on Thursday, September 20, 2012 at the Presbyterian Church of Madison, 19 Green Ave., Madison. Friends may visit at Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St., Chatham on Wednesday, September 19, from 5:30pm to 9:00pm. Contributions in Glenn's memory may be made to Sage Eldercare, www.sageeldercare.org. To send condolences or for further information go to www.bradleyfuneralhomes.com
